description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: This is not a bad game, don't get me wrong. But it is frequently compared to Subnautica and costs almost 2/3 of that. It is NOT 2/3 as good. And at a "overwhelmingly positive" status it can stomach the odd "negative" rating pointing this out. Whenever I do this (reviewing a game based on what it currently offers) I always get comments about seeing it for it's potential. And that potential is certainly there. If you buy games for their potential you'll be happy with Planet Crafter. Update April 2023: After a year the dev has added a bunch more content but I've not had the patience to play that far because he has addressed zero of the QoL criticisms. /Update What it does well: [*]A varied environment to explore [*]Terraforming actively changes the environment, opening possible paths [*]Encountered no serious bugs from what I can recall [*]Meteor showers offer something of a risk reward tradeoff. Getting hit hurts but if you want their resources you need to be out when they happen. These resources also ensure that it's pretty much impossible to get deadlocked by missing resources (as those laying around on the planet are finite) [*]When you die you simply drop some of your inventory and can go pick it up again [*]Can explore crashed ships etc [*]Environments are nice and varied but transitions can be a bit too jarring. Near the aluminium spikes for example it's always dark for no logical reason. What it should do better: [*]Progression system needs massive work. Many of the personal upgrades are completely useless. I have not felt ANY improvement from the walk or mining speed upgrades. None. Meanwhile I'd argue the o2 tank upgrades are actually too powerful. You are quickly able to traverse almost the entire map with only a single spare canister. Similarly upgrading your terraforming machines is more busiwork than satisfying progression. In this area the game feels more like an idle clicker that simply makes you do stuff so number go up slightly faster. Even the rockets fall into this trap. The first provides a massive boost and then returns quickly diminish. Some of the more advanced machines are actually worse proportionally than the earlier ones. [*]The SPAMMY base building. You need massive farms of power plants and terraforming machines to progress, which quickly devalues the experience of building any of them [*]building system in general. Every base is magically hovering in the air and many of the outdoor elements don't snap to each other. [*]You go from being essentially tied to your life pod to casually crossing the entire map in no time. Also you can just plonk down a cheap hab block in each biome and you're never going to die again. [*]Upgrading your exoskeleton usually results in you dropping everything because of how the upgrades chain on each other. How it could do better: [*]Have fewer upgrades, further apart and make them more meaningful in return. You don't need 5 walk speed upgrades of 10% each. Make ONE that doubles your speed. In general upgrades that let you do something new are more fun than upgrades that just let you do something better. [*]Drop most of the O2 upgrades and introduce a rover instead (seamoth analog). This would still allow you to explore further out but without spamming mini bases all around or losing any kind of urgency because your o2 tank lasts for days. [*]Flesh out the genetic manipulation aspect. Instead of simply upgrading obsolete flower to less obsolete trees. What if you could sequence the flower genomes and test what each allele did before recombining them into new and improved species [*]Consider a staircase module that allows going up or down a level without being akwardly tucked in some corner. [*]Add a power display that's readable in world. Right now if you want to figure out if you have power to run another machine you need to open the power console. But you can somehow display global terraforming values on a big TV [*]Adjust the size of the outdoor platform to be in line with the hab modules and allow them to snap to each other. Allow the launch pad to snap to existing structures as well. [*]Allow hab modules to intersect the terrain to a small degree (you would absolutely do some landscaping before going "can't possibly fit this building here because of a bucket worth of sand") or require outdoor platforms as foundations.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: EDIT: I played quite a bit more of this than I did for my initial review to see if my opinion would change. I have one neutral thing and positive thing to start with: I can see why a lot of people rate this game highly: the devs very effectively trigger the "number go up!" endorphin rush by showing you five different point scales that you can make rapidly change to bigger numbers. This is definitely crack for gamers, and quite satisfying, but also super grindy. In addition, to add the positive comment, it *is* very satisfying in the early game to see the lakes and rivers fill up and the terrain start to change color. That's some clever coding and makes for a very engaging early game. See the bottom for the rest of my updated opinion after ~16 more hours. Reviews on Steam aren't about whether a game is *good*. They're about whether you would *recommend* a game. And while it's a relaxing little time-waster for a lot of people, for anyone looking for a real open world survival game, this one has potential but you'll be happier if you pass. This is an early access review, and maybe things about the game will change but for now, let's look at what's here. What initially breaks the game is a sense of inevitability of everything: the map is fixed, your initial location is fixed, and you're very definitely on rails. The first two are right out of the Subnautica playbook. The last one definitely is *not*. The blueprint system is built around how you meet goals given to you by previous blueprints. In short, your build order has been set for you by the developers and you will only be allowed to build what the devs will allow you to build, and in exactly the order they allow you to build them. And this is true even if you are experienced with the map and you know where everything is. This is not at all like Subnautica, where an experienced player can rush to the exact blueprints they want and start building specific items right away. Nope. Even if you find uranium early (for example), you will be sitting on it until the game *allows* you to use it. Until that moment, it's a rock that is useless to you and will clog your storage. In addition, most of the tension of a good survival game is drained out of the proceedings right away. There's an exploration element, and you initially need oxygen to survive. Great, that's right out of every survival game handbook. The problem is that oxygen generation in this one is completely trivial: if you build a one room hut with basic materials you can find anywhere, then build a door for it, you have instant oxygen recharge anywhere you want it. I worried about oxygen until I realized this, then I would just build a hut next to each of the game's wrecks, loot them from top to bottom in one trip, just building more storage cabinets in the hut to hold it all, then ferried it all back to base. There's also an absurd unreality layered over everything. In addition to the instant/unlimited oxygen huts, let's look at power. The first power generation blueprint you get is for a wind turbine. Did I mention that you've been stranded on a planet initially with no atmosphere? Yet somehow, the wind turbine still works. A bit later, you get solar panels. These work fine at night. Frequently, the planet is blasted by meteor swarms. Don't worry about repairing your buildings: they can take as many direct meteor hits as needed and indeed you'll *want* the meteors to hit your buildings so you don't have to walk far to collect their contents. (Tip: build two doors to your main base. I had a meteor hit the door of my base scattering debris that I couldn't move through for a few minutes, keeping me from entering.) Resources are unlimited but scattered VERY widely, so you'll spend your time going back and forth, back and forth, back and forth, ferrying the more key items for advancement in an ever-larger backpack. But since basic resources are unlimited, you can just sit back, fire this "game" up, and watch a "Terraforming Index" and a few other metrics climb and climb and climb, occasionally dumping a new blueprint on you. After a certain point, you'll get the distinct impression that eventually the numbers will climb (if slowly) high enough to make you successful without you having to do anything. There are blueprint boxes you can find in the game, but these drop non-required QOL sort of items, again in exactly the order the devs want you to have access to them. Sooooo... yeah. It's a "dad game" version of an open world survival game. Maybe some of this will get toned down over the course of development (for example, right now, plant seeds will sprout an unlimited number of times, giving you unlimited food -- the devs have said that this might not be the case in the final game), but the sense of inevitable progression on rails is baked right into the core concept here. So if you're looking for real open world survival game creativity, I'd point you to either Astroneer or the newly available early access game Occupy Mars, or of course either or both Subnautica games if you haven't played those. The Planet Crafter isn't *bad*. There are some good ideas here! But it's very much "dad's survival game". EDIT: Okay, +16 hours or so and I still stand by most everything above. If anything, the "you can only build in X order" only gets worse in the mid to late game (I progressed well into the insect stage and the gaps between new build items gets wider and wider). That said, you know the bit where I say the blueprints you find in boxes are non-required QOL items? NOPE! One of them is critical to advance the story of the game... and it's FAARRRRR down the "optional" blueprint order. So in addition to my notes above, the game also has a very grindy RNG-fest as you have to cast far and wide to find those little blueprint boxes, which just adds *another* layer of frustration to the proceedings. So yeah. Still not recommended. There's some clever ideas here, but watch a couple of play-through videos and that'll give you the gist and you can keep your money. 6/10

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: Playing the 1.0 update of Planet Crafter has been fun so far— now that I'm approaching the end and progression feels fairly repetitive and drawn out, I feel like I've formulated my thoughts enough to share them in a review. Planet Crafter is a game with big ideas! You're taking an entire map that's so barren and orange/red it hurt my eyes at times, and turning it into something lush and honestly pretty striking at times! It's very fun and rewarding to watch the map transform. The gameplay(and indeed, much of the game design itself) borrows from Subnautica; you explore, you gather resources, you build your base, you make the world your own. Instead of finding the unique flora and fauna like in Subnautica, you get to put it there yourself! Many of my issues with this game, and why I will not be finishing it despite being a stone's throw away from the finish line and ending, stem from technical issues and an apparent lack of polish that I originally thought was attributed to the early-access state of the game. Now that we're at a full release, I feel that the game is far too unstable. Hitches, freezes, and an apparent memory leak that caused my entire computer to lock up on multiple occasions made playing the game more stressful than rewarding or fun, because I was always worried about saving as early and often as possible to protect my progress(which is largely just based on waiting real-world time for your terrformation values to tick up) from the inevitable crashes. The map is full of holes. I found a gap in the geometry within a 15-second walk from the spawn point that allowed me to clip under the rocks. The game evidently makes a lot of concessions to maintain performance; one of these concessions is very aggressive LOD and occlusion culling of basically everything. Map geometry, player-placed buildings, even the plants that you grow will very obviously pop in and out of existence as you are moving to and fro. The lay of the land is hard to get a grasp on because of how drastically the environment changes as you travel; something I thought was just a bare hill that would allow me to access another part of the map is actually blocked by a huge cliff that simply popped into existence when I got close enough. It's jarring, confusing, and immersion-breaking. Another comparison to Subnautica is hardly fair here; those guys had the advantage of an ever-present underwater fog to hide what they were doing in the distance, but they also had the environments and objects fade in and out rather than simply appearing and disappearing. I don't want to make assumptions, but it feels very much like higher-quality assets and systems were added onto the very shaky foundation built by the team working on this game when they were much more amateur as developers. One example of this I feel is the lack of a proper day-night cycle. The skybox is eternally static, and "night" is signified by the game cranking down the exposure without changing how anything is lit. It's strange and doesn't feel like something that should have passed any kind of a quality check for the 1.0 release, which is a statement that I unfortunately feels like applies to many things about this game. I hope that some day I can return to this game and properly finish it without the pains of the current version. If you love survival-craft games, this is probably still worth a try. If you love having a smooth and well-polished experience, this game is not for you.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: Overall: Has promise, but needs a lot of work to resemble a quality game. Pro: * Solid survival-crafting basics. * Terraforming progress is reflected in the world. Easily the best feature. * Large map filled with lots interesting set pieces. For an early-access game there is a surprising amount of terrain to explore. * By default (see below) there is a very natural progression curve. Tech is tied to your terraforming progress, so you have to start small and work your way up. You also have to explore to access higher tech because the default start location has only basic resources nearby. Con: * Base-building is very constrained. Clipping restrictions are much too harsh; you're basically forced to build a base that floats at least a few inches off the ground, because the smallest intersection with the ground blocks construction. And don't even try to build near interesting terrain: every rock formation or wreckage has a gigantic exclusion box. * Alternate start locations are highly unbalanced. The alternate start positions drop you right next to advanced resources and let you blaze through the tech tree. * The lighting system is just bad. Different biomes have unique shaders, which is fine. The problem is that they apply based on player position - so if you cross the boundary into purple-land, and look backwards, suddenly everything behind you is purple! This is particularly bad inside crashed spaceships when everything suddenly turns pitch black because you stepped over the "inside" line. * Generally poor UI/UX. It's better than it was in the demo, but the menu still looks like it was created in 20 minutes for a game jam, and the inventory and crafting screens aren't much better. * The story... doesn't exist yet, and the placeholders are laughably bad writing. I would honestly rather see "Captain's log: BAD THING HAPPENED" than what's currently there.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: I bought this game enticed by "Overwhelmingly positive" reviews and frankly... I don't get the appeal. I'm no stranger to repetitive gameplay, that some people may find boring, but this game completely failed to draw me in. Gathering resources quickly becomes tedious and achieving next upgrade levels doesn't feel rewarding. It seems like it's just another "idling" game, where you grow your numbers for the sake of it, just so you can buy upgrades to make your numbers go up faster. If that's your type of fun, go right ahead. I have however refunded my copy.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: Just because a game is addictive doesn't mean you're having fun. This is a prime example of that. At the present time, Planet Crafter is not fun. It's addictive, and you end up mindlessly gathering resources and building the stuff you need, but there isn't really any fun or artistic value to be had here. Play subnautica instead.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: Played for about 24 hours. The first 10 or so were fantastic. The late-game was one of the worst grinds I've had in a game. So much "build tech 1 five times to unlock tech 2 of the same item so you can build 5 of those to get to tech 3 of the same item!" It got to the point where when I wanted my very last achievement, I actually just parked at the progress screen, calculated that I'd need to idle 45 minutes, and then played games on my phone while periodically drinking water and eating food. The game has potential and at some point I might recommend it, but not right now.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: A lot of reviews seem to be comparing this to Subnautica. Nah. First of all, there's no friction here. In Subnautica, one was forced to go further out beyond the reef and deeper into the abyss to find crafting materials and blueprints, which meant facing your fears, girding your loins, having your wits about you. In this game, not only do the blueprints come to you via your research module, the materials come to you too, via meteor storms (with incredibly weak-sauce impacts). Even when you do explore, there's so little to see; this game lacks all the visual and stylistic richness of Subnautica. The sound design is absolutely dead. The things you're collecting are just chunks of varying shades of grey. Nothing feels like anything.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: I do not recommend the game at this time. It has the bones for a great, unique survival crafter - but the actual experience of play is not engaging enough in early access to warrant a purchase. Maybe given future updates where there is a more dynamic state of play. POSITIVES: The hand-crafted environment changes procedurally as you make progress, creating a unique sense of earned progression - I think the developers should expand on this dynamic phase-based sense of play, where you feel incentivized to restructure your base at every phase of the planet, or at least add more exploration options as the environment changes (like new resources that appear at every phase in places like underwater caverns, etc). The crafting and tech progression are intermingled in a way that both feels natural and plays well, requiring you to diversify your play and base-building. The game incentivizes exploration, as searching nooks and crannies will reveal valuable rewards that increase quality of play - movement options, extra resources, special items, etc. NEGATIVES: The game feels rather empty, with no living creatures and exactly one type of dynamic event (meteor storms). Otherwise, it's you and the vastness of a lifeless, static environment. The lack of dynamic events removes a lot of survival pressure. Your #1 enemy is your Oxygen meter, which is a basic timer requiring you to either visit a base or have Oxygen tanks. Very little in this game will actually pose a survival threat to you, and in early phases it's simply inconvenient as you have about 60 seconds to mine materials & base-build before dipping into an interior space for air. I've died a handful of times and it has literally always been to running out of oxygen because I mistimed how long it would take me to walk back from an expedition. The game systems are not that deep. You place structures that contribute to the environment in different ways, then at certain ecological milestones, more structures will unlock. Sometimes the structures will add complexity to the system, but more often than not, they just require more advanced materials, take more energy, and contribute more to the environment. While you do automate some aspects, it's limited - you will be in endgame mining "advanced" materials the way you were mining starter materials at the very beginning. The story is bare-bones and simply not compelling. Comparable games like Satisfactory have a similarly bare-bones story, but the depth of systems in those games adds value to the point where the story is not necessary to enjoy the game.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: This is a very relaxing game to play, especially if you are stoned or had a few beers. It's so simple to play and there really is no threat to the player except for the first 30 minutes or so. But this game does not even hold a candle to Subnautica, not even close. Resource gathering is essential to the game but it feels so cheap because you are not breaking down rocks or digging to get to the materials but just picking them up off the ground. The material recipes for many things don't make any sense. Want to build a nuclear reactor? Well that will be 2 water bottles and a uranium rod. There is also a large unsightly seam in the map where you can see through the ground. The map is small. Exploration is boring, there is not much to see or do. There are so many better alternatives to this game at the moment. But i'm interested to see where it goes!

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: It's an OK time waster, but is basically like any other Unity Asset game. It looks and feels very similar to SubNautica, but without any of the polish... or story... or optimization. It's early access, so the hope is that the developers (there's only two of them, and apparently this is their second game ever) will get around to implementing more things to do. As it stands, though... you're basically playing in a clunky, ad hoc, half-built sandbox. Maybe in a year's time (or two, or three) this will be worth buying.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: If you are thinking about buying this game because you have watched the streams from Raptor, i don't think that will be a wise decision. The core gameloop is watching counters. Oxygen, Heat, Pressure and Biomass. With a Global terraforming index of Terraformation called GTi for keeping the overall process. Until it reaches a certain value terraforming complete and end of the game. The core gameloop is running arround the map gathering resources. And build a infrastructure wich let's the counters run faster. The more you wan't the counters to tick faster the more you run arround. To create some difficulty. You have 3 slow your progress down counters. Oxygen, water and food, these counter's decrease that quick that you are almost non stop busy get food get water, Furthermore is the map small(although Raptor stated it's HUGHE). And the map is in a highly unfinished state and is poorly modeled. People compare it to Subnautica .... yes but no. The concept of the game is really great, and for a couple wich develops this game , they get my fullest sympathy. But the current state is not worth the 16+ euro's. Stardew valley took 5 years of development by oe person. And we are talking about a 2d game with way more simple game mechanics. To finish this game it will take at least 6 years. And I don't see that happening for various reasons. One of the most important things this game lack's. Is what made Firewatch and Subnautica a success. Narration integrated with the gameplay. Furthermore gamemechanics that let you work together with a real person or NPC wich is terraforming another planet and helping each other out. The map needs overall remodeling. And the the lifesupport mechanics rebalancing. Building a base in mid air? More can be said you get the point and i am not going to do there work. GAMEPLAY PRO-TIP Don't plays Tree and Flower seeders arround your base. There are regularly meteor showers and Uranium and Indium are easy to find. But when you have the much needed Super Alloy meteor showers. They despawn after a short period of time and you can't find them between the tree's and flowers. Keep base as clean as you can for easy harvesting.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: I'm not sure why, but it feels so unsatisfying. It feels like it's missing anything exciting about it. So vanilla, but I think that's my fault for thinking it'd be similar to Subnautica. Nothing has matched the joy from Subnautica, so that's on me. It also feels incomplete and buggy, with items you build not snapping into landscape like it should or poor image quality/design overall. And the story drags, doesn't motivate me at all to push forward. I really tried to stay into this game, but I gave up. Maybe after some updates, I'd try again.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: So I know this is an “early access” game, but I’ve got to be honest, this is another game that I just don’t understand why it has so many positive reviews. It’s ok, I enjoyed playing it for the most part, but it is seriously lacking in a lot of key areas for a survival game. Pros: • Overall the game was engaging for a survival type game. • Concept is great. • Stages of terraforming felt well thought out. Cons: • It either needs to be a “Story line” survival game (i.e. Subnautica) or a “builder” survival game (i.e. Seven Days to Die). This is neither. • Lacks any real story. There’s a very vague story line, but it feels tacked on and more of an afterthought. • The progression is off. Some things come quickly some take hours if in game grinding to make any real progression on. • World is really small. If I had to guess, it’s probably about 1/8 the size of what the Subnautica map was. • Graphics are outdated, about 10 years older than current generations. • No real environmental threats. No hostile enemies or hazardous zones. With a proper eye on the bars, you will never die. Hopefully the full release will change a few things. It would be nice to have some sort of procedurally generated world, or new worlds to terraform or something to keep you engaged. Some sort of threat from fauna or the environment.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: TL;DR: Game is about 10 hours of good paced content, then grinding. I hope the game developers use the cash injection to really work on this product to flesh it out further which could make this game really good. As others have said, try the demo, the demo is representative of the first 10 hours of play. It is similar in flavour of sub nautica. Do the calculation of 10 hours of good game for the price tag of your country and see if that is of good value, the demo is maybe the first 3-4 hours(the save carries over from demo to full game) EARLY GAME Pacing is good, feels good to travel around and explore, you only need a few of the machines and you just upgrade them as you unlock newer versions, which keeps progress going. Since its minimal management on that end, you can explore while the number ticks up. Exploration is alright, I will say some places can be very hard to find, as they can be just a tiny ladder in a corner, but all the main monuments are...pretty basic, go in, break barrier, take loot, go home. you go in and out maybe 3 times to collect all the loot. LATE GAME When you get to around the 10 hour mark, you have unlocked all the terraforming equipment, at least most of it. at that point in the game you just unlocked something for like lets say 10,000 points, that means in 10 hours you generated 10,000 points, the next unlock is like 10,000,000 points, so it goes from a game of unlocking stuff and exploring into a game of 'okay time to get to work' and you just have to start crafting a bunch of the drills and heaters and such to start bumping all your numbers up. The problem with this is getting materials, right now to obtain the mid/late game materials, you have two options after draining the map of them, you 'summon' them from rockets, which you don't get a ton of the resources and its a manual process of going to go collect all the resources, it just isn't really 'fun' its just a chore, collect materials to build rocket, send rocket,wait for rocks, keep rough track of where they all land, go mine the rocks, repeat process. It also doesn't help that the rockets require the same resources that they are dropping, so if you collect 20 red ore, you have to use 6 to get another rocket, so you only really got 14, while spending maybe 30 minutes doing so. The alternative is ore drills, these would be great, if not for one flaw, you place this in specific areas to get specific materials, sounds great, put the ore drill in the red cave to get red ore, sounds easy enough. The problem is these ore miners have limited space, lets say like 15, now 15 of red ore would be great, the problem is the miners don't collect JUST the red ore, they collect maybe 1 red ore for every 4 'junk' ore and you are left with 3 red ore after it has mined for 10-20 minutes. These ore miners are not super easy to make, they take a long time to fill up, and they get filled with junk, but they are the only way to get some materials like aluminium, so you are forced to act like an errand boy, going from drill to drill, collecting resources, and dumping the junk ore into storage(or on the floor in a giant pile) This is a pretty annoying part of the game, but the good thing is, it is an easy fix from the developers. I want the drill to just drill what I need, If I want junk ore, I can put the drill in a 'common' area and get it that way, I don't want this mix of ores. To add onto this, because the drills have to be in specific areas, those areas are pretty far apart, even with max level jets and such, just going back and forward so many damn times, I've spent most my time doing just that. If the devs take the early access money, build up both the story more, the unlocks more and expand the exploration a bit more and maybe add a bit of teleporting so you aren't traveling so damn far to do things, this teleportation would also be good BEFORE the grind wall, so you can get to and from the drills and such easier. overall, try the demo, it made me want to buy the game, but if you are tight for money, maybe hold off another year.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: I'm a huge sucker for survival and base building games, and the idea of throwing terraforming into the mix really appealed to me. When faced with the brain-dead simplicity of the early game, however, I just couldn't bring myself to continue and see whether the changes to the planet were sweet enough to make up for my utter boredom and disappointment. Resource gathering amounted to "pick up minerals that are scattered around in a roughly even distribution." No deposits or concentrations, just walking around learning to identify which small rock (that sticks out from the environment like a sore thumb) corresponds to which of the 5 or so minerals you actually need, because you sure aren't going to be able to collect everything - inventory space is extremely limited early on. So you go out and hope that you randomly find the one you're looking for before you run out of oxygen. The sole exception was a particular one that I had to hunt around for, which was probably the most interesting thing I did during my playtime, punctuated by frustration when I realized that I needed a flashlight that I didn't have, so I had to make another tedious trip back to base, burning through my oxygen tanks the whole time. Base building, normally my favorite part of these games, was even more lackluster. I had hoped for a feeling of setting up a complex logistics system on an alien world: laying power cables, fiddling with buttons and wires on panels, managing pressure and atmospheric gases, performing critical maintenance, growing food while on the verge of starving, sweating at the possibility of making a fatal mistake. Instead it's just a matter of unceremoniously plopping down devices that magically provide power, magically dig through rock with no byproducts, magically provide oxygen to your suit, and magically correct the mix of atmospheric gases to something breathable. Oh, and they all magically work forever, unless perhaps one happened to get hit with an odd meteorite - wouldn't know. One you've plopped your first set of magical devices, what do you have to look forward to? Gathering more minerals to plop another set of them, until you unlock the T2 version, and then plopping those down instead. And the scale of my operation barely felt like it would be enough to support myself, let alone make any changes whatsoever to the ecosystem of an entire planet. "Planet Wizard" might have been a more apt description here. Graphically I didn't find the game to be up to modern standards. Textures are very flat and frequently don't blend well with whatever they're sitting near. The devices you put down lack a sense of character - that is, being a working machine. Wind turbines simply run at a constant speed forever. Solar panels are static and always clean. Drills barely move. Your own character only interacts with the environment via a tool that does everything. If the gameplay were more interesting it could easily make up for this, but such as it is, it's just another reason to be unenthused about the complete package. Overall, I'd say that if you don't much care about the things I listed above and just think the idea of watching the planet turn from red to green and having life show up (again, magically) is cool, then by all means you may enjoy Planet Wizard- I mean Crafter. If you just like great survival/crafting games, though, the market is flooded with other titles that will respect your time and provide a more rewarding experience

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: Sad to leave a thumbs down as I have enjoyed my 13 hours so far. The start feels like a good survival game, then this gradually gets easier, surviving becomes very easy/not a part of the game at about 7 hours in, then you start automating the mining process, all of this was great. Now though, I look at what is in front of me. Jet-packing between my multiple miners to grab resources (which frustratingly produce multiple other junk resources making this a longer process), to produce things while there is no threat to me/no survival aspect. Satisfactory overcame this by making logistic systems, whereas in this game the next bit will just involve myself moving back and forth a few dozen times. So I'm staring into the last 5 hours of this game finding little enjoyment at this last leg of the journey. What worries me too is that the developers are planning on extending this portion of the game (making amphibians, insects, etc.) but there is no puzzle, no chance of failure, just plug in hours and get said answer. The initial thrill of the game came from the challenging survival, short lengths of time you can survive outside, prioritising the way through the puzzle with the interesting story. But more needs to be done to make the second phase more interesting because sadly it is slightly boring due to the repetitiveness.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: The only reason it's a "no" is that I don't feel it's worth it *yet*. After being burned by Early Access games never completing, I can only judge games by how they are at the moment, rather than what they promise to be in the future. The short and sweet is that there isn't really much to do. You can go explore to search for materials to bring back to base, set up terraforming stuff, repeat. Add in a basic food and water need system and that's most of what you're dealing with. Graphics work well enough but there's a lot of pop-in and terrain that isn't properly set up so you can see through the world, audio is okay, etc. It's just in a really early stage right now. The devs' way of getting you to explore often comes down to resource scarcity, but the main issue I have with that method is that I end up never wanting to engage with the exploration except for small, targeted excursions to grab exactly the materials I need and come back. There's also no easy way to send materials back to base for long expeditions, so once you're full on materials, you might as well stop exploring then and there. The feature I want most is some basic automation. Nothing insane like Factorio inserters and autocrafters or whatever, just the ability to move items from one inventory (like the water collectors) into another (like a shared closet in a more convenient space). Mining drills just aren't all that good when I have to manually collect the materials from every individual one every few minutes, food growers aren't that good when I have to manually harvest the food even though I need a stockpile of some foods for crafting, etc. The game has promise, don't get me wrong. It's just not yet ready to ask for $20. Keyword being "yet". So long as the devs don't disappear, I'm sure I'll have to update this review at some point.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: So, I'm going to start with a mega positive here. I love this game, and will probably continue to play it for a while. It triggers the happy chemicals in my brain that only filling up bars and gauges can. I liken it to Space Survival Melvor Idle. And that's a huge compliment. For Early Access, it's brilliant. But... there's a few - meh notes. The graphics/sound/gameplay loops are decent. Nothing amazing, but solid. Quite enjoyable. I can't fault them for an indy game. So, if I'm going to keep playing, and the game isn't bad - why am I not recommending it? Simply, the game doesn't respect your time. And that dear reader - is my most precious commodity of late. Initially - I was happy to recommend this, but as I wrote that review I realised that fundamental problem, and I'm writing this, hoping that the developers will see it and change stuff (even just options to allow for, or to fix this problem). Now, as is the wont with survival games, you can't go AFK for long periods of time. You die. This is not a problem on it's own. I am quite happy playing survival games, however - as the canny reader may have noted, I likened this game to something else... Melvor Idle. Resource acquisition is gated by tech progression in the game, and not a little either. You need a LOT of resources to make things work - and again - I am totally OK with that style of gameplay in a bubble. As I am okay with things like Dyson Sphere/Factorio or Satisfactory. I have sunk many hours into those. But, your progression is gated by limited resources, so you can't build to your hearts content. Now this would be fine, if I could idle for 20 minutes, have a blast on Speedrunners or Mario Kart or the like with the twins while we play together while waiting on miners to extract their quotas... this would be fine, except it's a survival game. If I idle for twenty minutes, odds are I'm coming back to having died, even if I'm in base. I get that the devs don't want all the resources spammed for everyone all the time and content just zipped through, but there's so many mid game things that are limited in availability that at the end of the day, I can't just spend my day making a base that tickles my fancy up the side of a cliff while spreading my fields of spreaders or collectors, because it's survival, and the two genres in this fashion don't work well together. Individually, they are brilliant, but as it stands currently - there's not enough automation to allow for idle play (as in I have water collectors that can keep me from getting parched, and enough food growing to keep me from dying, but I have to be at the keyboard for this process), but there aren't the resources to allow me to go wild with base building (even incrementally as the fundamental bits are gated hard), so I find myself twiddling my thumbs far too much with this game. Without trying to spoil things, you can't make miners without a certain ore, but even when you get access to that ore initially, there is only such a small quantity available that you can make 1 miner and a bio lab, or two miners. Now you need 2 miners for the resources aluminium and iridium, but you're gated by power concerns as tier 1 miners can't get uranium (and I know there are chests with, but they don't always have enough early on). Now, if I could just wait it out while these resources gathered slowly to build up a stock pile, that'd be fine if I could idle it out, but being made to sit there shows that the developers haven't considered my time as a currency. If they sort this out, I'll gladly change this to a positive review, as overall it's a bloody brilliant game, but I'm struggling the justification of my time for eating/drinking while waiting.

description: A space survival open world terraforming crafting game, designed for 1 to 10 players. Alter the ecosystem of an inhospitable planet to render it habitable for humanity. Survive, gather resources, and build you base. Then, generate oxygen, warmth, and pressure to create a brand new biosphere.
name: The Planet Crafter
review: The early game is a decent enough open-world exploration game, and seeing the skybox slowly go dusty red --> blue sky --> clouds --> rain is well done, but by mid-game when you're dealing with plant seeding it crosses the blurry line from "exploration game" to "walking simulator" for me. The problem is that you need to have a specific "main base" where your bio-lab and rocket setup is because them and the support food growers are too damn expensive to move or build multiples of easily. This is Point A. You will probably use up all the aluminum anywhere near Point A in reasonably short order since solar panels need it, and you will need a lot of those to go along with your terraforming buildings, most of which also need aluminum. Thus, you will need ore extractors for aluminum before too long. Extractors only have a chance of finding aluminum in very specific places. The nearest of these places is Point B. Iridium also can only be found or mined in very specific places, and you also need a lot of it for anything to do with heat or rocketry, which is often. The iridium mine is point C. It will not be terribly close to point B. Sulfur is needed for a lot of biolab stuff, and only comes from Point D. Algae and water from Point E are also needed for most of the biolab stuff. Point E can't be anywhere near points C or D. Trying to build anything new by the "Moss" level takes 15 minutes of walking from Point A to Points B, C, D, and E and back to get the raw materials for a single building. And you can't readily replace this with exploration because shipwrecks don't reliably give you things like bio-nuggets, fertilizer, or bacteria samples. It's also complicated by what is the smallest but most damning flaw for me: inventory. The max-level backpack has 35 slots, which isn't even enough to hold all the raw ores/bio-components for one mid-game terraforming building, never mind the solar panels to run it. It's small enough that most shipwrecks or caves will take multiple trips just to bring back the good loot, which can mean spending half an hour just walking back and forth between two already thoroughly-explored locations. Just changing the inventory to have Factorio-style stacks so I don't have to make repeat trips or can leave the miners running for an hour or two instead of needing to empty their stockpile every 15 minutes would probably change my vote to positive.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: The game its self, for the most part, is great. Some of the best 3rd-person gunplay since MGSV; fun, challenging gameplay and mechanics. It's lacking much in terms of features and content compared to the first game - time will tell if that's addressed, but for the moment it's still very enjoyable. The main reason for the negative review is that Helldivers 2 uses nProtect GameGuard - a kernel-level anti-cheat software, aka a rootkit - and widely regarded as amongst the worst of its kind. It runs at the highest possible level of privilege in your PC's system - enabling it to monitor files and control hardware. It acts as a keylogger, monitors which programs you have running, and still lingers after uninstallation.. Presenting a gaping security vulnerability, a huge invasion of privacy, degrading the performance of the game and having the potential to brick peoples' PCs - and not even preventing hackers from creating cheats for the effort - it's already a bit of a stretch for games that take themselves seriously as competitive arenas. Why the fuck does a co-op game of all things need one?

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: As many others have stated: this game requires nProtect Gameguard, which requires root level access. The company, nProtect, has several scandals in its history, including having its user data exploited, as well as not uninstalling when the game it was installed with was installed. If you google "nProtect uninstaill" or "nProtect issues" you will find forum posts discussing the vulnerabilities and difficulties associated with this product as far back as 2008. Even ignoring the issues with potential privacy, nProtect is the main reason for all the crashes in this game. If you trust this company with access to everything on your computer, disregard this. But I view this as functionally malware. This is a PVE exclusive game that for some reason needs an anticheat with stronger access to your system than PVP games I've played.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: A summarized log of the issues some of us are having trying to update Gameguard so we can actually launch the game, and a few notes about other GG issues, posted on this review to hopefully make players and potential buyers aware of what sort of problems gameguard can cause, and get the devs' attention to fix this problem: 4th (and possibly final) update: So, look, I've spent 3 days trying to figure this out with the help of others who are having the same issue, or are just kind and want to contribute. I think we finally found out what the problem is, and unfortunately if we're right, then it's something that most people who have the issue won't be able to fix. Still, I'm going to explain what I think is causing it and a few things that might help a few people get it to work, and call it quits there. I'll keep an eye on discussions around this issue, and keep trying to get the devs' attention on it, but ultimately, I don't think they'll be able to fix it if they stay with Gameguard. Regardless, if I find a common fix or the devs add it to their list of known issues, I'll probably update this review one last time. Otherwise, I don't plan to. There's a non-exhaustive list of 'fixes' we've already tried that haven't worked for us in the first update down below (if one more person tells me to whitelist it on my antivirus, I'm going to have an aneurysm). NOTE: This pertains to Gameguard failing to update while launching the game. There are two other issues with Gameguard that I've heard people have while looking into this: If you struggle with error 114/Gameguard has a critical error, afaik the devs are aware of it and the only thing you can do is wait for the devs to fix it. Keep an eye on the patch notes. If Gameguard simply won't install for you at all, I haven't heard of any possible fixes and I don't *think* the devs have mentioned anything either. You have my condolences. If you're having this problem (or any problem with Gameguard/the game in general), you can open a support ticket at https://arrowhead.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/requests/new, or send an email to their support team at support@arrowheadgs.com. I don't think we'll hear back from them, which is understandable since I bet they're swamped, but if enough people report the issue, they might notice it. I'm only one player out of a few hundred thousand. SO: Gameguard failing to update *seems* to be caused by either a network/service provider or their firewall blocking Gameguard. One reason why we think that, is there are posts on GG's forums dating back to 2005 acknowledging it. If it's your home firewall, that's an easy fix. Unfortunately for most people with this problem, it isn't their firewall specifically. It's people living on campuses or renting that can't actually turn off the firewall for their network, because they don't have access to it. One person said they were able to get in using a VPN, but that didn't work for most of us. Another used the mobile hotspot on their phone, but for the few it worked for, it also requires playing the game on your hotspot, which wasn't exactly feasible for us. That said, those are the only things I've heard that have had any success at all. You can try any or all of the steps that failed for the rest of us that are listed below, but I wouldn't put much hope in those. But there's also a much bigger problem with this: IT CAN HAPPEN AT ANY TIME. It DOESN'T happen immediately upon launching Helldivers for the first time. I played from thurs-sat without issue. Since the issue first occured on Sunday, it hasn't gone away. Not only that, I did contact my network provider and got them to shut off the firewall for a second, and the game actually booted! (which is one of the main reasons why we think most people having this issue are having it). So you may think 'okay, Gameguard updated, so you can play again until the next update'. But that's not actually correct. They turned the firewall back on, I closed the game and reopened it, and you guessed it, no launch, and haven't been able to since. Someone replied to one of my forum posts an hour or two ago that they'd been playing for a few days, and this just happened to them today and they're still locked out too. So that means IF THIS PROBLEM ARISES AFTER YOU PLAY FOR 2 HOURS, which is has for most of us, you are SoL. - 3rd update: Unfortunately, simply updating via the mobile hotspot then returning to the network doesn't actually work. You need to remain on the hotspot the entire time you're playing the game. So, back to square one once again. Thank you, devs. I'm having *so* much fun right now trying to fix an issue that hundreds if not thousands of people are having that *you* could fix by simply switching anticheats. What a strange hill to die on. - 2nd update: A kind heroic random suggested this to me on discord: "my firend lives in a studen area where his network provider blocks alot of stuff like nsfw websites for example, i read on gameguard website that if your network provider blocks alot of stuff its becasue of it you get the error code. conact your network provider it said, so i said to my friend conect to your phone hotspot and try to launch the game and it worked. spread this messege pls its on of the big reasons. this anticheat are ♥♥♥♥ and i dont know why they use it." It worked for me, so anyone else having this issue, give it a shot and let me know if it works for you too. I'll revert the review to positive again if i find out this is a widespread fix. Until then, I'll continue to fight for my brothers that have lost their Helldivers to this anticheat until something more comes of it. Sidenote: This isn't a fix for GG error 114. Afaik, it's a similar but different problem that the devs are aware of and looking into. The only advice i've heard for that so far has been to wait until they fix it. So, yeah, even if my particular problem with GG has been solved, it's far from the only problem this anticheat has been causing people. - Update: I reviewed the game positively originally because it was working fine for the most part and the fun was worth the bugs. But since Sunday, I haven't been able to launch the game because Gameguard refuses to update for no discernible reason. I and a growing number of others plagued with this problem have been trying everything to get it to work over the past 3 whole days or at least get the devs to acknowledge it as a problem that they'll look into, but so far it's been radio silence and no one has found a fix yet. Some examples of things that we've tried so far that have been unsuccessful: Uninstalling and reinstalling both GG and HD2 Whitelisting in our AVs Reinstalling with both antivirus and firewall turned off Reinstalling/running as an administrator Using a different network to install Turning off all other programs that might be interfering Verifying the integrity of the game files Doing a system restore Opening an official support ticket So far, none of those have worked. I just want the devs to acknowledge this problem that a growing number of people are having (that is in no way related to the one GG problem they already did acknowledge) so i know this is getting looked into, and that we arent just SoL. ------------- You can actually catalog my descent into madness trying to fix GG from me being all happy and nice and perky about it in my first post on sunday to all the other posts and replies and updates I've made through the past 3 days getting gradually more and more worn down and pissy turning into incoherent ramblings from scouring the internet for youtube guides and forum posts and nigh-20yo outdated official faqs and messing around with stuff on my computer i didn't even know existed until now I have no memory of the sun and don't know if i'll ever see my family again unless gameguard decides to fix itself and update so i can return to enjoying the crashes with the rest of you

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: BUY THIS GAME Only if you do not care about personal and System security for your PC. That is a BIG NO for me! This game is VERY difficult squad based game. I can live with that. There is no offline play and solo play is stupidly hard. Duh! Its a squad game. Graphics are decent as are the game premise and functionality. The problem I have is that the game installs a ROOTKIT on your PC without them informing you. This ROOTKIT installs at the kernel level on Windows. That was bad enough, but when my AV caught the ROOTKIT trying to access files outside the program file directory that had nothing to do with the game that I considered this an insider threat and major security issue. I immediately removed the game and requested a refund. I cannot have some random company accessing files on my PC that do not belong to them. No telling if they are collecting personal data, or up to other nefarious things. If you read the forums, the anti-cheat ROOTKIT is only designed to protect their micro transaction system but will randomly delete any files it considers a threat without notification or permission. I cannot have some random company accessing files on my PC that do not belong to them. No telling if they are collecting personal data, or up to other nefarious things.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: with any negative review, this one in particular, please grok that this is at launch and while a launch state does reflect on the developer issues mentioned may be fixed by the time you see this. i love the mission to mission gameplay a lot in this, i wasnt someone who played helldivers 1 so i can't talk too much about some of the finer details but i do sincerely think they translated this game 1:1 from 2d to 3d and thats an impressive feat. but due to the nature of the game crashing, being always online, and the upgrade/monetization system ill talk about soon have me not wanting to give it a total thumbs up. i am going to 'hypocritically' continue playing the game despite this edit 2/9/24: a later in the evening day one patch has improved this significantly, theres still been some crashing followed by lobby privacy issues but its infrequent now. there are three progression systems in the game, utilizing four currencies one of which has three tiers. the currencies are "Requisitions" which are used to unlock new stratagems. samples, returning from 1, which come in three tiers and are used to unlock multi-tiered permanent upgrades to your stratagems. medals, your method of progressing the battle pass (we'll get there.) to unlock new gear. and super credits, your standardized buy in bundle predatory MTX (Microtransaction) currency. focusing on the super credits, you are capable of finding them ingame. presently across the 9 or so hours i spent in the game ive managed to find around 50 credits. for a sense of scale it requires around 250-300 to buy something from the rotating superstore, and 1000 to buy the premium battle pass. for the sake of context, please understand that i have been playing on difficulty 3-4 of a 9 tier difficulty system, rewards likely (i hope) scale with challenge. so, gear progression right? everytime you clear a mission you get Medals, which can also be acquired from exploring in missions. think of this like EXP and levels but instead of getting something set per level you can choose what you get, this is handled by the battle pass which offers tiers in pages that unlock with a certain amount of medals spent in the pass. now the average person read 'gear is in the battle pass' and primed to explode, lets be entirely clear: **THESE BATTLE PASSES DO NOT EXPIRE**, they are more or less dlc. does this make them cool? in my honest opinion no not at all, people hate the vermintide 2 class dlcs for having separate purchases for cosmetics that you then have to clear challenges to unlock. similarly here, the battle passes that helldivers 2 offers are just DLC but you have to farm and grind to actually get the content you paid for. assuming of course that you did pay for it instead of farming to get the pass to farm. like any good drug dealer you can get some cheaper samples by using your medals to acquire bundles of 100 super credits from passes. the free pass has quite a few of these so that it feels good but the premium pass offers 3 opportunities for this. this translates to recovering 300 of the 1000 super credits spent. this is monetization that ive seen time and time again with the average gacha game, premium currencies that steadily dwindle to enable you to want to spend real money. this is typical f2p behavior... wait how much did this game cost again? edit 2/11/24: it seems to be super credits spawn relatively reliably, and thorough farming seems decently viable. around 20/hour on average. further testing is needed but i felt like this was important to add to this section for folks personal judgements again, ontop of this, i must clarify that the game is fun and that i do genuinely enjoy it, i look greatly forward to playing it with my friends. but in terms of my overall statement on it and how i would like my opinion to be contributed to a ratings factor i would not recommend it, and i genuinely think the studio, or sony, whoever is actually responsible, should reconsider how this is handled. it really stinks. especially because to my understanding in helldivers 1 weapons could be customized or augmented but now the augmented variations are only within a 10 dollar dlc pass. the other thing about this that grates me is the announcement for said battle pass & store systems. remember the super store i mentioned earlier? it rotates in and out cosmetics* that can be purchased using super credits, the MTX currency. (*armor carries perks, theres only so many armor perks in the game and all of them can be acquired for free. thus while you can use MTX to acquire perks 'early' they are not exactly stat items.) the reason this pisses me off is that in the post where this was announced, a line i have come to mockingly quote regularly is posted: "Do you hate FOMO? We do!" yes, you sure do, you hate fomo so much you had fomo preorder bonuses, you hate fomo so much you have a rotating storefront encouraging people to keep eyes on unless they miss out on something. you hate fomo so much that your special edition has a arcade cabinet that is in your ship nomatter what and only works if you fork the 20 dollars over for it to work. this particular point has been sticking with me for a while, the direct "look at how cool and generous we are uwu" bragging followed within seconds by more predatory bullshit makes me genuinely nervous, and is the primary factor as to why i give this a thumbs down. if you've read all this, firstly thank you for taking the time to hear my rambling out and consider my opinion. secondly, if you've read what im upset about and you do not feel that it would bother you, you think that this would be a particularly fantastic co-op game with your friends, etc. do not let me hold you back, please. i really do enjoy this game, and the reason im making this negative review is to express what can be improved for the sake of this being an even better game.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: Don't let the thumbs down give you the wrong idea, this game is FUN, it's entertaining, I put in lots and lots and lots of hours in Helldivers 1. BUT none of my friends want to touch a game with a Kernel Mode Anti-cheat because it's a dangerously invasive and unsafe anti-cheat on a PVE game. And frankly after learning about this myself I'm half tempted to uninstall this game. Please consider some other kind of anti-cheat or something. I want to be able to play this game with my friends but none of them trust this Kernel anti-cheat. I'll change my review if this ever changes because again, its FUN, but the Kernel Mode Anti-cheat kills it for a lot of people because they aren't as dumb and trusting as me.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: NProtect Gameguard, the anticheat they use is straight up malware. Didn't know the extent of the problem until after I installed and played for awhile, only to have tons of other programs crash while I'm NOT playing helldivers that event viewer tells me was cut by gameguard. From what I've seen on forums in the past, uninstalling the game and even using the uninstaller they provide doesn't fully scrub gameguard from your system as a kernel level rootkit. How bad is that? That means it has more access to and control over your computer than you do as a "user/admin" that owns your computer. This game is fun, but it's actively damaging my computer and installing malware on it that as far as I've been able to tell, can't even be formatted out of the computer with a factory reset because of how it's implemented as a kernel-access rootkit. The best advice I've been given on the ONLY way to be sure to not have it on your computer anymore is either to hope you had a backup from before then of the drive you have windows on or just straight up getting a new computer because the hidden files and background processes and being above the owner of the computer in rights as an admin/user makes it just impossible to uninstall, let alone be completely sure. The korean company that makes the anti cheat made an uninstaller after all these years (used to be you couldnt ever even if you uninstalled the game. It had security flaws that never got fixed and remained on your computer) and you can actually find and use it in your game files and it runs automatically when uninstalling helldivers, however multiple people have screenshotted and proven that it doesnt get rid of everything as background processes are still going even after restarts after using this uninstaller. This is such a fun game, but if the torrent of actual security professionals who work in IT screaming that this is malware you cant even remove from your pc isn't enough to dissuade you, I just have to add my voice to the chorus of warnings that you shouldnt EVER install this game until that's been removed. It's already fucking over my pc and force stopping programs left and right.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: Genuinely really fun and amazing game... BUT: The anticheat the game uses is borderline malware, which doesn't fully uninstall even if you uninstall the game. It's so powerful it has more access to your pc than you do as a User/Administrator. But beyond that, it can trigger your firewall/virus protection so much, that you just can't run the game anymore, which was happened to me, blackscreening on startup before crashing. That led me to look into this, discovering that the anticheat they use is practically a virus. https://www.alteredgamer.com/pc-gaming-tech/1709-how-do-i-uninstall-nprotect-game-guard/ This article is really useful in guiding you on how to uninstall the malware as best as you can if you already have the game. Extremely upsetting that the developers would do everything right, except for the pile of shit anticheat that ruins the whole game and your computer. Fix your shit Arrowhead.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: Avoid Because of Kernel Level Anti-Cheat (nProtect Gameguard) The truth is, this game's anti-cheat, Nprotect Gameguard, is the cheapest and most unsafe rootkit anti-cheat on the market. Since it's kernel level the anti-cheat has kernel access to your PC, meaning it can go through all your files and control hardware. Some reported that even after uninstalling their games, people still can't get rid of the anti-cheat as it lurks in your PC. Here's a list of awful Free 2 Play games that Helldivers 2 has the honor of sharing an anti-cheat with: Games List The decision behind using this anti-cheat is because, the developers don't want cheaters to steal microtransactions like they did in the first game. Which is absolutely fair, but they have chosen the wrong anti-cheat. It doesn't even make sense for a PVE Game to have such a strong rootkit anti-cheat that gives it access to your entire PC. To protect their profits, the developers have chosen an anti-cheat that put players at risk. Many people have been turned away from this game, due to their decision. I hope the developers read this and consider using one of the popular anti-cheats like EAC, at least that anti-cheat has a good reputation unlike nProtect Gameguard. Edit: Thank you everyone for all the awards and kind messages. I hope the developers take the feedback of this review seriously and change their anti-cheat to a less intrusive one. 🎅Would Appreciate If You Follow My Curator Page🎅 Would mean a lot if you supported me there, would help me create more quality reviews.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
