description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: -This is a day 1 review- Big fan of Helldivers 1. I played it for about 100 hrs on steam, and another 100 back on PS4 Let me run down what I dislike about this game. Strategem and weapon upgrades are gone. All weapons are as good as they'll ever be. Samples are instead used for permanent ship upgrades, however, it takes a long time. I'm very mixed on permanent, global upgrades in Helldivers, as the "You are as good as your gear" mechanics does feel really nice. Weapons take forever to unlock. We're stuck in solo while the game launched broken, so we have to unlock weapons this way too. Each mission is 15-20 minutes, after 4 hrs I unlocked 1 pistol and 2 primaries. They're going to get exponentially harder to unlock from here. Weapons are less special, more shooty, however, they "made up for it" In Helldivers 1, lots of weapons got their own elemental upgrades. The Double Barrel had dragonbreath, the Paragon had toxic, and lots of low-cal weapons like the Knight got a bit of AP, or stun. In Helldivers 2, there is a paid battle pass for a flame version of a different gun. It sucks, bad. Vehicles are gone too. No more APC, Tank, Mecha or Bike. It's a shame. The matchmaking is broken. I'm not one to really use SOS instant matchmaking but I tried to today many times, on full game servers, to no avail. It's broken. Edit; matchmaking is no longer broken. The Illuminate are gone. There's now only two factions, Bugs and cyborgs. This sucks because the illuminate had a harsher stealth and shield based gameplay that led to interesting fights. Microtransactions are here. Which sucks. They have paid and free battle pass sections. The paid one has unique elemental guns, as said above. Edit: they're not THAT bad. still not great. Finally, the anticheat is very aggressive. What's here is fun. The shooting feels nice. But there's just too many issues to deal with right now. Edit: I want to make it clear that all the in mission gameplay is good. It's VERY good. The problem is everything else around that in-mission gameplay. Further Edits: The game is buggy. Very buggy. Connection problems, my shops broke, both the premium one, the battle pass, and strategem shops. I have a 1 in like 5 chance for the game to work. I now have a small chance to be unable to use terminals. I also sometimes get teleported to the sky unable to do anything.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: Gameguard has been causing hard crashes (it locks up my computer so hard even the power button stops working and I have to unplug the PC to restart it). It has even started causing crashes in my other games, confirmed when I uninstalled Helldivers 2 and the hard crashes in those other games stopped happening. I might pick this up in the future but for now I cannot risk the chance of permanent damage to my hardware due to constant power cycling (almost one crash every 3-4 hours). Edit: I've seen some other reviews describing crashing on AMD 7xxx-series GPUs, for reference I have a 7900XT. Until I uninstalled Helldivers 2 every other game I played would hard crash so it does seem like an interaction between this game and the video drivers (drivers updated to latest as of time of the review).

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: Fun game, but this DRM is computer cancer. Never had one games DRM actually give me stutters in other games, until now. I also experienced crashes in random programs, including Steam itself, and slow loading times on trivial tasks on my beast of a machine. Deleted this game and the problems magically went away. This game should be removed from Steam until the anti-cheat is taken down. It is a direct liability to your computer, you've been warned.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: Gameplay is fun as fuck. Planetside is great, progression is pretty good if not grindy but a little bit of grind doesn't spoil the bunch for me. What DOES spoil the bunch for me is locking elemental weapons behind a premium pass after i just paid $40 for a game. That is unfathomably cringe, and there is a special place in hell for whoever came up with the idea, peer reviewed it, coded it, and then put it in an otherwise great game. This blew up! So i'm gonna specify some things. The premium pass is locked behind a premium currency. You can claim this premium currency through a free pass that holds normal armor, weapons, perks, and equipment. You can also find this premium currency rarely in missions. The biggest issue I have with this, is the slogging grind you'll have to do to unlock the pass, many people wont have the time to unlock the premium pass and miss out. It encourages you to spend money on the pass to skip out on the grind. An ugly "P2W" mechanic in a great game. Who knows how long the pass will even be here for, and if the weapons will be forever available elsewhere after the pass expires for the next one.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: Game appears to be pretty damn fun and the graphics are beautiful. That being said, the anti-cheat software they decided to use in this game is probably one the worst. I've known about it for a long time as it was used in a popular Asian MMO I used to play for years. Even in under an hour, the anti-cheat software managed to close two programs I really need to use on my PC, and they don't interact with the game at all yet this software decided to control my PC and close them. The fact that they decided to go with this specific one is really bizarre to me, but oh well. Though... I don't think the software is as dangerous as people claim it to be, however it does like to control specific things on your PC without your immediate, direct consent. As is pretty commonly talked about when you look this anti-cheat software up, it does indeed not fully uninstall I've found. It will remain and do things. There is legitimately zero good reason for this. If it were about whether or not the user is going to re-install a game that utilizes that same anti-cheat, then the files should remain dormant, not running, until that condition is met. But that is not the case here for who knows what reason. If you don't particularly care about a game's anti-cheat potentially going behind your back and closing things just because it wants to, then by all means get the game and enjoy it, because it's a great game. Otherwise, don't even try it because the software will hook itself in and you'll have to research the potentially long process of scrubbing it from your OS. Only real way I'm going to pick this game back up is if a friend really wanted to play it together because we'd have fun, I'd just have to deal with the anti-cheat closing things randomly.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: Man, I've never had such mixed feelings about a game before. The core gameplay loop is phenomenal, but not being able to even log in means I can't even play the game most of the time. The sheer amount of polish and care poured into this game shows, from the animation work to the superb gunplay. But then they implement a shady (almost 20 year old!) root-level anticheat that makes me not even want to have it installed.

description: The Galaxy’s Last Line of Offence. Enlist in the Helldivers and join the fight for freedom across a hostile galaxy in a fast, frantic, and ferocious third-person shooter.
name: HELLDIVERS™ 2
review: I was very much excited about the idea of playing this game, I adored the original. Sadly after consistent crashes to desktop and even a few BSODs thrown in for good measure, the only thing I can recommend is STAY AWAY until you hear about patches fixing these issues.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: TL;DR Cannot recommend game in its current state. Game has potential and an interesting premise but balancing issues and tedious objectives leave much to be desired. The premise for this game is an interesting idea (in theory): take a wave-based shooter and explicitly make the game about completing objectives instead of only killing enemies like say in Killing Floor (KF had some objective-based maps but they were never the focus nor that popular). The single biggest problem with this game right now is the balancing and scaling. You start with a pistol and can buy from a limited selection of weapons at trader(s) at fixed points on each map. Each weapon can be upgraded, and potentially infinitely except the cost of upgrades scales very fast. The first upgrade for a weapon costs 5k, the second 15k, the third 30k, the fourth 50k, and the fifth 100k. You earn a fixed amount of money for killing an enemy, with headshot kills earning slightly more. Each wave also scales enemy health and quantity at a considerable rate. A single headshot from the pistol on the first wave is enough to kill an enemy, but 3 headshots will be required by wave 3-4. In order to not get overwhelmed by enemies, you probably want to upgrade your primary weapon every ~5-6 waves, which quickly becomes unrealistic after the first 1-2 upgrades as enemies will become very bullet spongey and deplete your ammo reserves much faster, often requiring you to pay for a refill of ammo every wave, and the refill cost also scales as you upgrade your weapon (1.7k for a t3 weapon vs ~250 for a t1 weapon). The game also has a respawn mechanic in the form of life tokens, which allow you to revive yourself or a teammate. You start with one life token (can only ever have 1) and it costs 5k base to buy another one, and each subsequent token costs 2.5k more so 7.5k, 10k, etc. This means if you start getting overwhelmed by the enemies, you will start spending a considerable amount of money on life tokens and that makes getting your weapon upgraded so you can try to catch up even harder, and often impossible. On the whole, I've often found that in order to complete a level, it's often necessary to play the level several times to figure out what you actually need to do on that level and then try to speedrun it to complete it as fast as possible before the scaling gets to a point that you get overwhelmed. This brings me to my next biggest gripe which are the objectives. One of the biggest problems with this game are that objectives vary wildly in both difficulty to complete and also just figuring out how you're even supposed to accomplish the objective at all. Some objectives will give you nice clear objective markers at least of where to go on the map while other objectives will require you to explore and run around the map frantically while trying to figure out what the text is actually trying to get you to do. On the most recent map, Sewers of the Dead, for example, there was an objective where three moving targets needed to be shot in a sequence that was indicated by a prop in the environment. We shot the targets over and over in the correct sequence, making attempts that spanned at least 20 minutes, before we finally must've done something somehow different (even though we just shot the targets in sequence yet again) that caused the objective to actually be completed. This particular objective was also incredibly annoying as the targets were on a tower that goes high up in the air and if you get hit, your aim is going to be knocked about by aim punch, so we ended up in a familiar song and dance we often find ourselves doing on these levels which is killing every enemy except for 1 and having one player kite that enemy while the other tries to figure out the objective. The game eventually despawns the enemy after a certain amount of time (probably 3-5 minutes?) but it's the only strategy we've really found for trying to figure out objectives that are unclear like this. Some of the objectives are just plain tedious. An objective that appears in some form on every map is to kill x number of enemies while you stand in a (small) circle on the map, which will require killing something like 80-100 enemies. As the waves increase, the number of enemies per wave increases and so you often end up stuck in this loop where you kite enemies around, stop momentarily in the circle, killing some enemies, and then run away and kite before you get overwhelmed. There's just no reason the objective needs to require killing as many enemies as it does - halving the number of kills required would be a very welcome change. Another tedious objective that was specific to this map was to escort an npc from one side of the map to the other. The NPC didn't actually follow the players however - you had to pay it a small sum ($500?ish) and then it would activate for either a short amount of time (~5 seconds) or a fixed, small distance it would traverse before it would shut down and you'd have to activate it again. This probably took around 5-10 minutes to complete and cost a non-trivial amount of money. Sometimes we'd activate the npc only to have it basically not move at all or literally take 1-2 steps and it wasn't clear why that was - a best guess was maybe if enemies were nearby it would move a much shorter distance? The last level released before Sewers of the Dead, The Ashes of Sker Hotel, also had an objective that required escorting multiple npcs but in that objective at least, the npcs would simply follow the player so it didn't take overly long to complete and there was a nice push and pull between trying to keep the npcs in line of sight so they would follow you and not getting overwhelmed; that same push and pull just felt frustrating in comparison with the npc on Sewers of the Dead as how far it went was completely out of your control. This game definitely has potential to be a game I'd highly recommend but until the balance, scaling, and objective clarity/tedium is fixed, I cannot recommend picking this game up. That's unfortunate as the setting is very dark and unique with some interesting enemy designs (and some incredibly annoying enemy designs like enemies that instantly teleport behind you every time you shoot them, seemingly with no cooldown). Follow it to see what updates are made if you're interested and hopefully the developer can make some positive changes in this regard.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Once you die in game, you are perma fucked. Playing with a full squad turns into a single player game cause your friends will die, and never be able to contribute again. Since the respawn tokens scale in price with how often you die, and since there is no picking up of downed players, there is no coming back from a single death. Do you use your 5k for a gun upgrade or re spawn token? if you get a better gun you can do more damage, but the second you get pinned in place by the zombies youre dead and have to rely on a teammate to buy you back. If you buy the token instead you wont be able to do any damage, ensuring you never make money to buy a gun upgrade, leading to your inevitable death again. Throw in undersized hitboxes on zombies for when you shoot them (some dont seem to even have a hitbox from the side) but oversized hitboxes for when youre trying to run past, points only being awarded for kills and assist, with some mini bosses not even rewarding you for beating them, and terrible dsync, this game could certainly be good at some point and i understand this is early access, but ive played better early access free games, and i payed 10 dollars for this

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Game is super fun and has lots of potential but needs a bit more time to cook. Point system is bad, once you get to round 20+ it feels impossible to get to tier 4 without hitting the box to get lucky. No reg in co-op every 2-3 bullets, feels impossible to come back after dying on at high rounds as zombie HP gets so high your guns begin to do very little damage which means no points. Love this game and what it has to offer but feels very jagged around the edges,

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Game has promise but; the point system is shocking late game due to earning nothing for damage only for kills, the invisibility skill doesn't work for any quest objectives or boss fights and there isn't enough variety in terms of weapons

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: I like that its an indie cod zombies but its extremely clunky and the performance is all over the place. Also if the frame rate dips the sensitivity starts going frantic, its like mouse acceleration but if it started freaking out. If they work towards it being more optimized and add more content I could easily recommend this.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Not quite ready, put this back in the oven for a month or two I reckon. Excited to see if this game gets big future updates to help polish it up a little more. Some quick things to note: - Footsteps? Why does it sound like I have 8 feet all walking simultaneously - UI imperfections and sounds overplaying - I hover over menu items and they make their sound without visually showing me they're selected - Some game tweaks? - Not sure if I'm missing something but it feels almost impossible to come back after dying on round 25+ I get given no money and I forgot to buy my life token, if my mates win the round I'm pretty much a dead weight - Guns feel a bit underwhelming at times? Pack 2 what looks like an AK-47 feels like I'm shooting BB-bullets at rounds 20+ I truly wanna see this game succeed, I love what they've got so far, but I don't want to taint my experience in the mess that this game currently has, so I'd rather wait for it to be the perfection I know it can be.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Although this is a negative review, I believe this game has a lot of potential. Sker Ritual is a game that takes the Call of Duty Zombies formula from multiple entries and remakes it into a game with a different engine. And this is all this game is, in addition to some pretty standard horror shooter options. The reason I think this has potential is in optimization, performance and quality. The current game is almost unplayable in lower-end systems and the poor performance is even viable on high end system.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: I understand that Early access is a great way for developers to get additional funding and have players test their game... But there should be a standard, Sker ritual has a concept but that's about it, the idea is there but what's implemented so far feels super rushed and hollow. Visuals look low res yet somehow the game struggles to keep a solid 60 somehow Mouse sensitivity feels terrible (which I reported during the demo, worrying they didn't acknowledge this) it feels like mouse acceleration turns on and off randomly throughout the game Sound is dead quiet, no ambiance, no background music or at least from what I can notice and the lack of vocals from yourself or even the enemies makes the game feel more empty. The weapons not only look and feel bad but sound bad too with some very rough animations to complement the lack of polish Guns have no recoil, reload animation sounds are completely out of sync and the variety feels very weird and underwhelming would be great to have a cod zombies competitor especially after vanguard managed to ruin things But this isn't it

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: This isn't a game a game that you jump in for a couple of rounds of "zombies". Every map is heavily objective based. Imagine playing COD zombies but having waypoints on your screen the whole time to complete complete the easter egg you dont wanna do. It also adds "elite enemies" early that have a stupid amount of health that follow you around till you upgrade your weapons multiple times. Everymap is essentially "call of the dead" except done worse. Movement and gunplay is "floaty" and makes shots seem inaccurate. Pros: Miracle system could potentially be good. Cons: animations Objective based no progression (weapon unlocks, camos ect. I know its early access but this is currently 3 out of 4 maps completed) This game needs rewarding progression and the ability to just have no bullet sponge "elites". Needs a wave based game mode or custom mode to adjust settings. People just wanna come home after work and shoot waves of "zombies", not have an easter egg forced down our throat everytime we open the map. Development should be put into the fundamentals of the game, not throwing maps out that no one wants to play because the general game is bad.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Great concept just not ready yet. - Running sound out of sync with players footsteps. - Game liked to crash randomly. - XP and points system needs to be adjusted. - Objective system needs to be more clear. PC specs CPU: i9-10850k GPU: Rtx 3080 10GB version RAM: 64GB SSD: Samsung 1TB 970 Evo

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: As it is, right now I honestly don't recommend this game. Don't misunderstand me, the concept and idea is great and I love the fact that this is sort of a L4D/Killing floor type of game, but if any of you were to buy this game as it is I'm pretty sure that the boredom will come crawling pretty quickly. It's fine for a couple of games, or you can even test your patience and reach ten matches but at the eleventh one you'll probably start searching for another game to kill some time while this gets updated with any new content. If you also count that there are two achievements in which you have to stay alive for 35 rounds and 50 rounds, I even wonder who actually did these two (surely friends because solo's I doubt). I honestly tried it, so hard, but after reaching the 21 round every time I just simply quit because I get bored. Just sitting there, waiting, killing, repeating.. you know by now that yes, after a while it gets boring (after repeating this so many times). The problem lies also in the fact that the grind is real, the normal difficulty for this game it's not rewarding at all because for doing at least one level of the "sker pass" you have to play at least two times or if things gets worse, even three times, doing the same and only available map, same objectives and so on. The only thing that can make a difference and maybe make everything more interesting, is the fact that right at the start of the match you can choose to increase the difficulty of the level and raise the bar really high. There's also another level, expert I assume but I didn't try it because the hard mode indeed was already challenging for me. Still, it's not enough and I doubt you want to start already at hard mode (but if you're a masochist go ahead, it's great). I just hope that they will bring new content soon and rework the overall grind because it's not really great.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: This game needs a lot of work done to polish it. The foundation is there but it feel so bad currently.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Yes, the game has very good bones and is one of the few "CoD: Zombies"-like games out there, but there are still many, many issues with it. Everything feels way too meat-baggy, but yet not threatening. I beat the first level on my first try and hardly even took any damage. Even and especially the final boss was a joke. The zombies (or quiet ones) need to be way more of a threat while also being easier to kill for me to want to play the game. Also there is very very little audio, to the point that it is just the big bad enemy stomping around and the banshees that yell at you.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: the game has no middle eastern servers, private match does not work, and if you press on quick play there is no matchmaking, the game is dead and doesn't work. Once this is fixed i will change my review

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Honestly, just feels like a worse version of old CoD Zombies. You have to lead your shots by a large amount in co-op due to latency/desync. Melee feels bad. Trials bug out. Overall, needs more work.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Solo is kinda fun. Coop is UNPLAYABLE. No-reg, glitching zombies/teammates and microstutters. Very limited gun selection.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: This game is pretty well developed as an early access game that competes with call of duty's zombie mode. My only problem with this is that no one is online to play the game with you because there isn't much stuff to entice you in the REPLAYABILITY aspect of the game. I solo completed a match by myself and later wanted to do it with others but I've been matchmaking for nearly 5 minutes and decided that no one's probably going to play after. I also asked people on reddit if this game has an active online playerbase and I don't think anyone has really answered so far. I would definitely recommend this game but it doesn't seem like there's just anyone online to play with...

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: Really hard to recommend something that every time I've tried to find a group, literally no one is playing this game. It's super rare that a game is dead on arrival, but.... When you do get a game, it's basically the same Zombie Survival game that CoD has established, except this time there are little quests in between. After trying games for days and using the developers discord, no one is playing this game. The discord is dead, the game is dead on arrival. The developers responded below and while I respect their opinion, imagine believing that a healthy game means you have to trawl Discord groups to find people that actually want to play this game, and that ALL of those people in this discord are playing other games. So to answer you devs, this IS the Sker Ritual Experience, which is, a game that absolutely no one wants to play.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: so, this has a very nice foundation, just feel like there isnt nearly enough gun variety,the online matchmaking is near dead and the miracle perk system could also be expanded alot. another thing is the enemy variety is extremely low and the screamer mobs are very annoying coz of the sound and frequency of it happening. i dont wanna sound like im blasting the game too much coz it can be fun but there wasnt enough variety of anything to keep me invested. i think the devs could keep adding stuff and this will rightly be popular but as of now its a bit meh.

description: An intense round-based zombie survival FPS, play solo or co-op. Shoot your way through relentless waves of vicious horrors with high-octane objectives, upgrading steampunk weapons, collecting Celtic God powers, and surviving the onslaught of the Quiet Ones.
name: Sker Ritual
review: The only ritual that occurred was me kicking my router hoping that the message "waiting for other players" would go away. Does not seem to function multiplayer.

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: Not currently worth it, ignore reviews comparing it to mount and blade as it's nothing like it bar the directional combat. Personally found it ran really poor on a 3060, High on 40fps, low on 30fps. Building and crafting systems feel very unfun and tedious. NPC movements feel really janky, they just pace around for no good reason.

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: Steam, we need a "in the middle thumb". i coud use it for this one. (for now) hmmm they copied 1:1 some charakters and Quest idears from "medieval dynasty" its like you feed an AI with "medieval dynasty" and say "create me a game like that". You need to find a Hunter in the Forest ... his name is "Lubomir" pretty close.... You need to go to "Sambor"? yeah right... The AI voice lines in the quest are pretty monotone and annoying, after 2 minutes of listening to that you start skipping because it ruins the flare of the village listening to amazon alexa read out a quest to you :D The crafting itselfe is okish, you can stack in storage containers but not in your inventory, i guess thats a design choice whats fine, but you cant acces containers next to the crafting station automatic, you need to check what you need, go to the chest, take it out and go back in the crafting station to repair your axe for example. Thats not that big of a deal, but some QOL woud be nice there. The gameplay itselfe looks like what "The Epic" Update for OKAM had shoud been years ago. Its not bad, but nothing fresh aswell, its some lube warm copy pasta that they had under the desk since then. woud have been a new level of gameplay back then, but now its just a MD copy. Same as the old OKAM directional combat, its fine, nothing bad, but its nothing crazy. You can have fun with it for sure. for this price, if its your type of game and you dont expect mutch from the future of the game just go for it and have some solid hours of fun. if you are unsure to start with, i woud just wait, maybe they drop the game like the other 3 they started and never finished. iam pretty sure if you play it with friends in coop, a lot of the things i mention are minor and you dont even think about it while your mate try to hump some women in the npc village. but i coudnt get a single one of my guys to play it. Dev´s hurt them to mutch in the past, so i played solo. **Edit: played 20 more hours, and its not to bad at all, i had my moneys worth of fun for sure. shoud i excuse okam & LO now? their alergic against transparancy? absolutly not. but still its a fun game to play for that little buck. i will for sure check in again and see whats up with the donkey crew, but for now i stay on the positive side of a mid review. if you really like that kind of stuff, play it. if you are unsure about the past just move on for now. you can always come back.**

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: Oh boy. Last oasis developers back at it again. Same combat mechanics from last oasis. Same drop loot on death mechanics with a sh*tter bag and line beacon. All the dialog is AI voiced, but it's not that bad actually. The game runs like total dogsh*t. Probably wont be too long before they throw this one away too for their 'next' 'next' project.

review: Lots of facial choices if you like people who've been hit with the ugly stick. Animals react with lackluster. Fighting is clunky. The one saving grace is being able to see how things are built as you put them together. Maybe in a year I will come back and try it again.

name: Bellwright
review: Wow, nothing stacks in inventory. I wish i was kidding but each flower, berry, and seed take up a spot in a very limited player inventory. No Stamina and you run everywhere. Theres slow paced gaming, then theres Bellwright on a whole new level. Wait until they finish the game or until they let modders at it.

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: I wish it wasn't almost entirely AI. Kind of ridiculous to work on a game for so long just to not hire voice actors or any real artists to work on this. It has so much potential. Here's to hoping my $26 goes to the devs actually finding people to put in the real work. I was looking forward to this game so much, I love the vibe and wanted to be a knight. Now I feel I am no knight supporting those who steal from others. :/ Wait till they actually put in effort before buying the game.

Pros: Actually runs pretty well on 4090 (144 frames no problem) Building System seems fine, reminds me of the first Forest game where you put a blueprint down and then fill it in. Cons: Looks pretty bad ultra looks dated 10 years, animations feel bad and just walking around feels like a chore. The directional combat is worse than mount and blade from 15 years ago and i'm not going to play long enough to try bow combat

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: I understand its day 1 Early access, but this is rough. They delayed releasing to Early Access for quite a while because they wanted to avoid bugs and glitches and deliver a solid experience... which they just didn't. It feels clunky. Inventory stacks in storage, which would be great if you could build from storage, but you can't. Had they not delayed because they wanted to be further along from day 1, I would've had some mercy. The concept seems great, it just has a LONG way to go. Expected more, especially with a $27 early access price tag.

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: Yet another unfinished game. I understand that this is early access, but it's way too early. It feels very bulky and rigid; every action has a predefined path. Crafting is almost terrible; you have to add every item step by step, which is not that big of a deal, but you must be in a very specific point to be able to add said item. The combat hitbox is not great either; wrong angle => miss, wrong elevation => miss, same applies for gathering. The amount of necessary resources to run this game doesn't match the terrible graphic quality you are forced to endure. No matter what settings you choose, the environment feels fake, and the foliage is borderline terrible, if you look at a branch you can see how square it is. If the game feels bulky because of the mechanics, at least try to optimize it before adding further content, because what we have now here is a bulky game with bad optimization. This game needs to be more fluid, speaking of fluid you can't even swim, it will just teleport you back to land. Other annoying things: - You can't deconstruct buildings. - You can't cancel construction. - You can't research by yourself; you need to have a villager conduct the research, and you can't queue multiple researches. - Changing the research will destroy all the resources you've invested in that research up to that point. - Half of the map is basically barren land, with not even vegetation, just plain green grass pretending to be ground. The mountain biome is nothing but grass. - Hunting animals is a pain in the ass; there are no stealth mechanics. You can't crouch; you can only walk slower, but that does nothing to increase your stealthiness. - Most of the buildings are just a small rework of the same building (a wooden tent). - It's painfully slow to walk anywhere, and God forbid you're out at night outside your village, and the innkeeper is no longer there to pass the night. - The most annoying thing is that when you're deeply developing your settlement and finally unlock the Village Hall, you need to be far away from any village to be able to build the Village Hall. So now all your work is useless because you have to relocate to another spot to be able. So be sure to be far away from any village. - Clearing bandit camps is not even worth the effort; the reward is minimal, with the only useful item being the strap. - Sitting on top of a rock renders you invincible; the NPCs won't be able to attack you unless there is an archer. - Dying while reading a book destroys all the progress in learning that skill as well as the book, so you are pretty much forced to avoid any kind of combat during that time. - The quests are as boring as finding me X item and going to talk with Y person. - The mechanics of the inventory are trash; each item takes up one spot. Say you have 2 rocks; they're going to use up 2 spots. 2 mushrooms will use up 2 spots, and so on. - Fighting a shield man with a bow is impossible; it doesn't matter if he is in a block stance, he will ignore the damage from every arrow, even if you hit him in exposed areas. - Wolves will literally follow you half a map before giving up; it's plain stupid. - Your villagers are very easy to kill no matter the equipment, so think twice before throwin them to battle, especially if you have high skill ones. At this point for this price I can not recommend this game despite its potential. Is like the down version of Kingdom Come Deliverance with with Silkroad Online graphics and terrible optimization.

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: Graphics seem really grainy and twitchy and dated. AI voices are annoying. you just walk slowly when in water. Construction seemed all over the place, clicking on little white dots. I know its Early access, however i don't really trust the devs to fix these issues.

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: It's meh. It's incredibly half baked. Janky animations: clipping everywhere, lots of teleporting (i.e. teleport mid jump to begin the cimbing animation) Janky voicelines: Sounds like they just used a text-to-speech program for 90% of it. Robotic, lifeless, monotone, and they get used way to frequently. Lack of control customization, poor optimization. Not a big surprise for EA but noteworthy. Combat is simplified KC:D style with mouse movements for directional attacks and blocks. I believe it's actually copied from their abandonware Last Oasis, but I can't be 100% sure because I noped out of that garbage game pretty quickly. It's also incredibly clunky due to the shit animations, and honestly feels much closer to an asset flip game than anything produced by a reputable developer. Unfortunately, it's also not something that can be improved upon without starting over from scratch so don't expect it to become better down the road. Other then that, it seems like a fairly standard, somewhat grindy, open world survival crafting game. It has a companion and city management system as well but it's not even worth mentioning. I would have considered giving a more neutral review but I realized after starting that I had played the demo quite a while ago. At least 6 months ago. Nothing has changed and I didn't notice a single improvement from then. Taking that into account, as well as their tendency to abandon games and the fact that only two of their games managed to get positive reviews... I give an exaggerated eyeroll and a lol no thx/10

description: Establish and expand your own settlements, liberate the land and assist its villagers, and recruit others to your cause while learning more about a life you had to leave behind. Command your forces, prove your valor through combat, and cement yourself as the hero of your people.
name: Bellwright
review: Can't stack stuff and it felt slow as hell.. that wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't so clunky. I've also read that this studio gives up on games after a short bit... so.. not going to invest.

description: Sea of Thieves is a smash-hit pirate adventure game, offering the quintessential pirate experience of plundering lost treasures, intense battles, vanquishing sea monsters and more. Dive in with this revised edition of the game, which includes access to digital bonus media.
name: Sea of Thieves: 2024 Edition
review: I love this game, and have fond memories of playing with my friends. If you have no problems with losing hours of progress to unfair PvP with your pals, you will likely get a great degree of fun and memories from this game. When I heard the news regarding PvE servers, I was ecstatic. Sure, the promised nerfs to gameplay were appallingly foolish, but I figured there would be some kind of 'come-to-jesus' moment where the devs realized what was obvious to the rest of the world; that people are significantly more interested in having pirate adventures with their friends than dealing with sweaty PvP. Fast forward to today, and I am disappointed. Rare, please, for the love of all that is holy, wake the hell up. Instead of punishing PvE players for wanting to enjoy a game, you should instead perhaps give additional rewards to those who still want to PvP, if that. I can't even take my captained ship with my friends that I slaved over? To hell with that. To newcomers who are attracted by the PvE; you should wait. As it stands, the game will treat you as a second-class citizen, and you will be disappointed by all the things you can't enjoy. I have full confidence that, with time, Rare will eventually make the right decision. As a message to the PvPers out there; I am in no way indicting you for your fun. It's cool that you guys enjoy the game the way you do, but I do hope you understand that there is a significant majority of people who just want to have fun with their friends. I'd like it if y'all PvPers were given *additional* rewards for your gaming, instead of PvE'ers being punished for theirs. Best of plunders! Edit: On request, here are some of the punitive measures against Safer Seas; 70% Less Gold and Reputation Earned (Entirely) Many Reputations are inaccessible, and the ones that are cap at level 40 No Live Events No Emissary Action No Captained Ships No Guild Support There are others, but they are more reasonable as they specifically pertain to PvP. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Edit 2: I want to express my gratitude to all those who connected with this review, and posted your own thoughts. I am glad to see so many people agree with me that this is an issue requiring attention! Sadly, I had to turn off comments, as a subsection of the community could not set aside their toxic behavior. I simply do not have the time necessary to moderate it. I would like to remind everyone that a conversation requires a degree of mutual respect, and simply insulting other people - or arguing in poor faith - not only fails to move the conversation forward, but simply weakens any arguments you may have. You may as well admit that the other side is right. Who exactly do you think, working at Rare for instance, is going to see that behavior and think, "Yes, that is the player culture we want to foster! Toxicity that pushes all potential customers away"? We can do better.

description: Sea of Thieves is a smash-hit pirate adventure game, offering the quintessential pirate experience of plundering lost treasures, intense battles, vanquishing sea monsters and more. Dive in with this revised edition of the game, which includes access to digital bonus media.
name: Sea of Thieves: 2024 Edition
review: This game is actually very fun. It's got a huge open world to explore and sail through, and if you can get in with some friends it can be a great time. Mechanically, the game is phenomenal and I'd love to sink hundreds of hours into it. But the community is the worst I've seen since League of Legends. I imagine there has to be a tremendous overlap in the player base between them, because it's too depressing to consider that there are THIS many people who are THAT terrible to each other. I haven't been able to sail a single voyage in ages without having someone chase my ship for hours while screaming every slur they know into their awful $10 microphones. I tried to love this game, I really did. Those few times I got to just play with my friends I had a great time. But there is no matchmaking - when you set out, you're up against anyone who might be playing. You can have 10 hours of player time to their thousand. It doesn't matter. And if you're not interested in the PVP aspect? Tough luck, there's no opting out. Most players don't bother with the world events or the voyages, it seems. They just sail around looking for someone who already gathered up their treasure and then chase them for hours. And that's not hyperbole - I've seen players get chased (and have frequently BEEN chased) from one side of the map all the way to the other. It shocks me that someone is still having fun with that, that someone is just THAT dedicated to ruining someone else's time that this is how they spend hours. There's no downside to this style of play, either. I imagine the game encourages it. The sea monsters and AI ships are a lot of fun to fight, but they actually make the toxic community WORSE. If the kraken decides to wrap itself around your ship while someone's attacking you, you're just doomed. The AI will lock onto one target and utterly ignore anything else in the vicinity, usually leaving them free to, once again, scream all the naughty no-no words that their parents don't let them say when they're at home while you slowly die from the combined onslaught of a literal kraken and another player ship. There's no way to coordinate joining a server with your friends' ships already on them to form an alliance together if you wanted to try to just play with friends, either. Rare seemingly attempted to fix this by coming up with community days and community weekends, where rewards were massively increased. This encourages teaming up with others on the server to maximize benefits across the board. This somehow seems to only make the toxic community WORSE. In the entirely of the last community day weekend, I was unable to speak with a single player. Most of them were just screaming - not even words, just screaming incoherently - into their mics while chasing/attacking any ship they could find. The game also has a serious problem with hackers. I can't count the number of times I've seen someone board my ship and stand around getting blasted by shotguns and facetank all of it without moving. Supposedly the game has a report system, but it relies on an Xbox account and requires you to know the person's name. Most hackers I've seen have had incomprehensible names or are just literally nameless, not that it matters because I'M PLAYING ON STEAM AND DON'T USE AN XBOX ACCOUNT. Maybe I just have the worst luck in the world. Maybe there are some decent people to play with out there. But I haven't found them, and I can no longer convince my friends this game is worth playing, so why would I bother playing it without them? This is a great game utterly ruined by a terribly toxic community.

description: Sea of Thieves is a smash-hit pirate adventure game, offering the quintessential pirate experience of plundering lost treasures, intense battles, vanquishing sea monsters and more. Dive in with this revised edition of the game, which includes access to digital bonus media.
name: Sea of Thieves: 2024 Edition
review: Look, I love this game. I really do. But there are serious, fundamental issues with the current implementation of multiplayer. First off- PvP is profoundly unfun for and unfair to small crews and people not dedicated to the PvP grind. Ganking is astoundingly easy, and 100% the meta strategy- all players have the same amount of health and do the same amount of damage, so large crews just fill your boat with more players than you can reasonably fight and spawnkill you until you sink. Overall, the skill floor for this game is way too high, and players self select into groups that make it worse- players who play the game for PvP will naturally become more skilled at PvP than players who play the game for PvE. As such, PvE players are sitting ducks, easy prey. And, even worse- with captaincy, a ship can be ready for a fight in less than a minute. It takes hours to build up a PvE loot stash of any meaningful value. So PvP ships can just throw themselves at PvE ships until they eventually lose- and, let's be real, when you lose you're screwed. They'll cash out immediately. It's way too easy to get Level 5 Reaper. So, as a small-crew PvE player, the game becomes heart-stoppingly stressful. And the devs don't seem to get this- they continue to make running away even harder. Which would be fine in a game where the stakes were lower, but is total crap in a game with enormous stakes and an even enormous-er aggressor advantage. You want to talk about realism? It's realistic that a tiny merchant ship would see a big hulking pirate galleon trudge up from under the horizon and be able to get the hell out of dodge. Second, the ability for anyone- even allies- to backstab you is exciting and interesting on paper, but in practice is just an enormous impediment to camaraderie and community building. If I'm allied with a crew that I can't keep tabs on at all times, and I have any real amount of loot, I just plain can't leave my ship. We can't hang out, can't go on island voyages together- I can't spend time with other players without the risk of being betrayed and sunk. Without any form of loyalty assurance, this game is a profoundly lonely experience- compounded by the astoundingly sparse servers, at least partly limited in density because of the serious threat each new ship represents to your hoard. Is all of this a skill issue? Yes, 100%. I'll be the first to admit that I'm garbage at PvP. But, frankly, PvP matches as a solo are just so slow, complicated, expensive, and frustrating that I don't have enough IRL time and motivation to commit to the grind. The constant threat of attack is exciting, and vital to the gameplay loop's challenge and significance, but the odds are so far skewed in the aggressor's favor that it's just not fun. Edit: I'm really disappointed by the announcement of Safer Seas. I guarantee that if the fundamental issues with balancing and the gameplay loop were addressed, people wouldn't be clamoring for a PvE mode. Rather than take a good hard look at why people want PvE, they've decided to throw it in there and call it a day. It doesn't solve anything. It just splits the playerbase into the camps of Willing and Not Willing to deal with the existing bad design. And the ability to earn commendations in Safer Seas seriously cheapens them. Why should you be able to earn the Gold Curse or Legendary Hunter of the Sea of Thieves in the "introductory mode"? Edit 2: They're adding an "industry leading" third-party anticheat. Every "industry leading" anti-cheat is kernel level, which is beyond invasive and an unacceptable security risk. I really, really hope they reconsider, because otherwise I'm out for good. I'd rather deal with a few snot-nosed script kiddies than sell my digital soul to some company I've never seen. This is genuinely heartbreaking.

description: Sea of Thieves is a smash-hit pirate adventure game, offering the quintessential pirate experience of plundering lost treasures, intense battles, vanquishing sea monsters and more. Dive in with this revised edition of the game, which includes access to digital bonus media.
name: Sea of Thieves: 2024 Edition
review: This game is fun! You probably shouldn't buy it. I know that sounds a bit confusing, so I'll try to clarify. Sea of Thieves has a niche loop: you sail around for a long time, grab some items, put them on your boat, sail some more, and then sell your items. You can buy cosmetic items with the gold you get from selling items, but, surprisingly, the main draw of the game is the loop rather than the reward. I don't think any of this should be fun, but for me, it was - there's an odd, primal satisfaction that comes from grabbing a thing, physically putting it on your boat, and saying this is mine now, and I like to have it. There are a few PvE threats which can get in your way, but they're laughably easy and quite a bore to fight. Nobody plays this game for the PvE; if they're not playing it to fight other players, they're doing to for the weird satisfaction of item collection (or they just really like sailing the boats). The main threat comes from that other group I just mentioned: people who play the game to fight other players. If you're playing the peaceful part of this game (i.e. item collection), you've got to be constantly on your toes and looking out for other players. In fact, the presence of other, frequently hostile players turns this game from a docile sailing game to a really quite intense game of cat-and-mouse. Rocks and trees in the distance begin to look like other ships. You slam against a reef, spring a leak, and swear that you just got shot by a cannon. You see lights in the distance and panic. It's great! And then the inevitable happens: another ship locks onto yours like a heat-seeking missile, and the chase begins. You try to run, but they're in a Brigantine and you're in a Sloop; neither of you really know how sails work, so you both sort of fumble around until they end up in the wind and suddenly you're getting broadsided. Both you and your crewmate abandon the wheel and run below deck to start repairing - where's the wood?! How do we get all this water out of here?! You're scrambling, panicking. You think you've got it all patched up until there's a massive thud, and even more leaks have sprung at the front of the ship. Your crewmate rushes to get the new leaks patched up, while you head to the deck to see what happened. That's when you see it - the Brigantine! You've accidentally rammed it, and you see two of the Brig's crew furiously swimming around the boat, looking for the ladder and trying to get back aboard. You see there are sharks in the water. The Brig's captain lets go of the helm and drops the anchor, locking the boat in place. You see your chance and take it. You get on the helm of the Sloop, spin the wheel around, and scream at your crewmate to get on the cannons. He does. You start hammering the Brig with everything you've got - cannonballs, firebombs, blunderbombs, something called a chainshot. The Brig springs leaks; there are explosions on the helm, and the deck is on fire; finally, as if in resignation, the masts fall. You sail away. Behind you, against the backdrop of a slowly rising moon, the Brig sinks. It was a great fight, but, sadly, it was also a hypothetical one. Fights like this do happen in Sea of Thieves, but what I've described above is a fight between players who are new and have no idea what they're doing. This is when the PvP in Sea of Thieves is at its absolute best: it's frantic, crazy, and spectacular. More frequently, however, the players deliberately seeking out PvP (and new players) are the people who have already sunk hundreds or thousands of hours into the game, know every modicum of the meta, and who do nothing but fight other players. If, in the above situation, we were talking about a Brig crew who were good at the game and knew the meta, it would have gone more like this: Another ship locks onto yours like a heat-seeking missile, and the chase begins. You try to run, but they're in a Brigantine and you're in a Sloop; they know exactly how sails work and before you know it they're ahead of you. You try to turn away, but your hull explodes, your mast falls, and your crewmate dies. You drop down to the lower deck, confused, and spot another player on your ship. You're not sure how he got there. You pull out your pistol, having never used it before, and fire; by some act of divine providence, you manage to hit the intruder. He jumps off the boat with something that looks a piece of fish in his hand, disappears into the water, and soon he's back on board. You didn't realize until now that someone had dropped your anchor. You attack him with your sword, but it seems like he has fully recovered from your pistol shot. He pulls out a blunderbuss and kills you with a single blast. As your soul leaves your body, you hear the other crew in voice chat, yelling at you. "Sit down," they say. "Too easy." After sitting in a green, flaming ship that appears to be sailing through hell for what seems like an eternity, you spawn back on your ship - a new ship, on a different island. The old ship is already sunk. They got your treasure, and your adventure was for nothing. Here's the problem: the latter situation sucks. It's not fun, and, in my experience, it's far more common than the situation I described earlier. This game has an incredibly toxic community which is also very good at the game, and you will run into players who will stop at nothing to not only steal your treasure but also make you feel bad and want to stop playing. The consensus, as far as I can tell, among the more vocal members of the community, is that the game's title contains the word "Thieves," which, upon a quick reference to your favorite dictionary, is evidently defined as "people who put hundreds of hours into cartoon pirate games for the explicit purpose of trying to make it so other people can't play cartoon pirate games." The body of water in-game is also called the Sea of Thieves, which must be telling. After all, every body of water inherits properties from its name. Pacific means "peaceful in character," and we all know that no wars have ever been fought in the Pacific Ocean. These experiences will occur, and they may end up being your first encounter with other players. Unlike Rust or ARK, there is no server list in Sea of Thieves; you must play with other, random members of the community (toxic players included), or not play at all. The value proposition, then, is wrong. This is a $40 game with a niche gameplay loop and the express guarantee that you will have many negative experiences with other players. Like I said, I had fun with it; I learned how to avoid other players, and, when combat was inevitable, I learned some of the sneakier tricks. Some people will be so drawn to this game that they'll be willing to do that, but I reckon most people won't. I think that's perfectly reasonable. Buyer beware.

review: Look I love the game, but your screwed if you dont have any friends. To many people target small ships and you cant get anything done. You need friends. Sadly I dont have any and I cant enjoy the game.

description: Sea of Thieves is a smash-hit pirate adventure game, offering the quintessential pirate experience of plundering lost treasures, intense battles, vanquishing sea monsters and more. Dive in with this revised edition of the game, which includes access to digital bonus media.
name: Sea of Thieves: 2024 Edition
review: Dear Rare, I am writing to express my disappointment with the rampant cheating problem that seems to be present in your online platform. As a player, it is disheartening to encounter cheating players who are using unfair means to gain an advantage. It undermines the integrity of the game and ruins the experience for legitimate players. I would like to recommend that your company implements a report feature that would allow players to report suspicious behavior or cheating. This feature would allow you to take appropriate action against cheating players and help to ensure a fair and enjoyable experience for all players. I hope that you will take this feedback into consideration and work towards creating a fair and enjoyable experience for all players. Sincerely, A mad player

description: Sea of Thieves is a smash-hit pirate adventure game, offering the quintessential pirate experience of plundering lost treasures, intense battles, vanquishing sea monsters and more. Dive in with this revised edition of the game, which includes access to digital bonus media.
name: Sea of Thieves: 2024 Edition
review: Disclaimer: This is a review aimed at players who think they can find some casual fun in this game. No, I cannot recommend this game if you, like me are a casual player. I get that it is called Sea of Thieves and is a game that heavily pushes PvP. That in itself is not an issue and is a feature of the game - The problem arises, now that most of the casual and friendly player base that used to be in the game has left for greener pastures. I originally played this game when it came out, when it was new and fresh, and everyone was still learning. There were of course people yearning for PvP, it is nothing new, they have always been there. Now, however, they are the only ones left truly playing this game. In practice, this means that now, every time you log in and attempt to get a bit of progress in, running into another ship is an instant death sentence, unless you are incredibly good at the game already. This game does not and will not respect your time. The only way you can enjoy this game, is if you are okay with hours of hard work disappearing in the blink of an eye, because that will happen to you, especially if you are new to the game and still learning. I came back because I heard they had finally caved and made a safer seas mode, only to learn that this mode was completely and utterly useless for me. I don't mind that you only get 30% rewards in safer seas, it makes sense that you get much less reward when there is little to no risk - However, gating reputation levels past level 40 and making you unable to use the ships you have purchased in this game mode is what kills it completely for me. I would have been fine just spending a few hours of my time here and there, slowly chipping away at the reputations with the reduced rewards while sailing on my own ship - But no, I am not allowed to do that, because in order to enjoy this game casually, you are forced to deal with the worst this game has to offer as well. TL:DR: This game is not for people like me, who likes to play the game for a casual adventure with friends. This is a game for hardcore players, ready and willing to dedicate hours of their lives to become true pirate legends and reap the rewards of dunking on much less experienced players. Edit: Hey folks. I've read through your comments and I have a few notes. Yes, I did go back and play a little more after this, pretty much only to do some tall-tales with my friends to at least get a little out of my purchase. I get it, some of you really like this game for what it is, and that's fine. This game is not for me and it's my right not to play it. I wrote this merely to warn other people that this game might not be for them.

description: Sea of Thieves is a smash-hit pirate adventure game, offering the quintessential pirate experience of plundering lost treasures, intense battles, vanquishing sea monsters and more. Dive in with this revised edition of the game, which includes access to digital bonus media.
