description: Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer (4vs1) horror game where one player takes on the role of the savage Killer, and the other four players play as Survivors, trying to escape the Killer and avoid being caught and killed.
name: Dead by Daylight
review: Playing DBD is like being in an abusive relationship. There are genuinely good times. You can remember them. They were great fun. But as time continues to tick on, you realize how unhappy playing this game makes not only you, but everyone else around you. It's some sort of weird purgatory where people knowingly hate the game, yet still play it. As if they can't shake DBD out of their system or something. These are people firmly in the loop that DBD provides. It gives you just enough to keep you in, but you're firmly aware of how much you hate it the entire time. Will that stop you? Probably not. Welcome to the abuse. Reconsider your time before playing this, I promise you there's better expenditures of your time

description: Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer (4vs1) horror game where one player takes on the role of the savage Killer, and the other four players play as Survivors, trying to escape the Killer and avoid being caught and killed.
name: Dead by Daylight
review: To start this off, I have over 1500 hours on DBD on Xbox, before I made the move over to Steam, starting from scratch. I also play both killer and survivor. So where do I even begin with this? I think we did a pretty good job so far For me, the game in it's objective is the exact same as it was years ago when the game launched. The script has never been deviated from. What even is a win? Is getting hatch a win? Did you win if you ran the killer for 5 gens and your 3 teammates got out but you died? On the killer side is 3k a win if the 4th survivor gets hatch? No one knows and everyone interprets it differently. Even the devs can't give an answer and it's THEIR game. When streamers do escape streaks or kill streaks, they have to outline what the rules are because the game doesn't differentiate. Notable updates and changes take so long to be implemented. This makes the game feel stale. How long did it take to fix keys? Moris? Both sides were given such powerful tools that they could use to make the other side's experience miserable and it took years for changes to be implemented. New maps have been so few and far between over the past couple of years. The graphical reworks are stunning, and the devs deserve tremendous credit for that, but ultimately the maps are the same with a new lick of paint, the novelty wears off after just a few games. Speaking of things that never seem to change, the survivor meta has been the same for three, four years? Dead hard, Borrowed Time and Decisive Strike are your staples with the only new introduction being Circle of Healing. A perk so strong that the devs are now struggling to balance it. The killer meta has changed, but the strongest perks have always been the ones that slow down gen progression. Unfortunately, as effective as these are, they make for an incredibly boring experience when playing survivor. Remember Forever Freddie? Yeah I try to forget too. MMR No one wants to play a game and get stomped on so playing with and against players at your skill level, particularly for newer players is great; in theory. The reality has been completely different, does anyone have a good word to say about MMR? The old ranking system was far from perfect but it felt more natural, and you could see ranks. The current visible ranking system is pretty much correlated with your playtime and doesn't mean anything; it only impacts on the number of bloodpoints you'll get at rank reset. The determining factor on who you are matched with comes from the SBMMR which is invisible to all players, so you never actually know what level you're at. Luckily there a few clear giveaways that you're at high MMR. If you're playing as survivor then you will most likely be playing against Nurses and Blights, with the odd Leatherface and Huntress thrown in. You will very rarely see any other killers. Why? Because the difference in power level with those listed above, particularly Nurse and Blight are far superior to every other killer who will get stomped at the highest level. A top level Nurse can probably down an entire team in around the same time it takes Trapper to gather and place his traps. Y'all remember when Nurse could Blink five times consecutively? Fun memories. As well as playing against the same killers every single game, you'll see a lot of sweaty strats. Everyone can play the game however they like, this isn't a criticism just an observation. At high MMR you will be camped, you will be tunnelled and yes, they most definitely have NOED. The main issue with NOED is that it contributes so heavily to kill rates which the devs are then seemingly use to make decisions on balancing. From the killer's perspective, what are they supposed to do? In my opinion, the survivor is the power role, not as a solo, but if the killer is facing a 4 man SWF at the highest level? You've probably already lost multiple gens in your first chase. At high MMR this will be your experience every other game. There is an absolute irony that you try so hard to "win" to increase a rank you can't even see, to make your in game experience more and more miserable with every success. Doing gens, you? The survivor experience. You'll be camped. You'll be tunnelled. If you do your objective too quickly then you'll be called a gen rusher which then means you're fair game, apparently. In solo, salty survivors will kill themselves on hook or dc on first down. Play for hatch. GGEZ The killer experience. There is a lot of hypocrisy on the topic of toxicity, as the killer you drew the short end of the stick, congrats. You've probably heard of the survivor rulebook. You probably thought it was a joke; no it is very real but there is one fundamental flaw, it changes from person to person. There are a couple of key ones though. First, don't camp. Yes that includes if the survivor on hook's teammates have just bombed the hook, you gotta take a stroll to the other side of the map and let them heal. That's survivor rulebook 101 my friend. Don't tunnel. This one is tricky because some people genuinely don't understand what tunnelling is and have their own interpretation. Oh and no Lightborn. All the sick survivor plays involve flashlights, so you're practically hacking if you run Lightborn. Having a flashlight on macro isn't annoying you're just tilted. Booping the Snoot = free escape. Teabagging isn't toxic. If you run NOED then you're a little bitc...well you know. Now here's the best part, most important rule of them all actually so listen up, it doesn't matter if you followed every single rule, it doesn't matter which killer you played, which perks or add ons you used, it doesn't matter how the survivors played, good or bad, if you "won" the game, you played incorrectly. Confusing right? Survivors hate losing and they'll have no problem telling you everything you did to seemingly ruin their experience. But if the survivors "win"? You're going straight to teabag central at those exit gates and you'll probably get hit with the GGEZ in the post game. The classic. And this brings me to probably the single biggest issue with DBD. The Community The DBD community is one of the most toxic I have ever had the displeasure to be a part of. Not the entire community, I have had many positive memorable interactions, but for every one of those, I can recount at least ten bad ones. The way the DBD community treats each other is, at times, horrific. My Xbox inbox is filled with hundreds of messages from players I met on DBD, salty that they lost. It was only when I started watching DBD content on YouTube and Twitch that I realised I wasn't the only one getting messages like these, particularly when playing killer. Within the space of an hour on Steam, I was called a re***d by one SWF and then told to kill myself by another. What had I done to get that reaction? I killed them and "won" the game. I've seen countless interactions like this on YouTube, many far worse and there are absolutely zero consequences. The devs stick their fingers in their ears and refuse to acknowledge this kind of thing goes on. Using the in game report feature is the equivalent to writing something on a piece of paper, scrunching it up and then lobbing it in the bin. Whilst whatever happens in game, should stay in game, there has to be accountability for those who use racist, homophobic or otherwise serious abusive behaviour towards other players. How could I possibly recommend DBD to anyone? Game communities should be a safe space for its members, DBD is not it. Anyway I've rambled on for far too long so I'm going to take some advice and I'm going to play something else. Maybe I'll try Civilisation or something.

description: Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer (4vs1) horror game where one player takes on the role of the savage Killer, and the other four players play as Survivors, trying to escape the Killer and avoid being caught and killed.
name: Dead by Daylight
review: This game is absolutely RUINED by the newest patch: 2.6.0. I've completely quit the game as a result. The recent patch strongly encourages toxicity and screwing your teammates over. - Rage quitting is no longer punished with a de-ranking penalty - To de-rank, survivors must sacrifice themselves at the start of the game, rather than help teammates and then disconnect at the end of the game. This also de-ranks the killer too! - Matchmaking is totally and utterly broken now: 9/10 lobbies are 300+ ping and totally unplayable - Lobbies are worse than ever with 3-man bugged ques; the game won't start - New system saves data on DBD servers, meaning data often saves incorrectly and you sometimes lose your points - The devs are completely incapable of fixing bugs that have been in the game for years; but they will gladly release unwanted and unnecessary patches that make the game worse. - The rank system is now ruined in every aspect - Audio changes are terrible, chase music is deafening loud & some noises are quiet as a mouse *BEWARE new players, you will be bullied to the extreme by high rank survivors/killers, with thousands of hours of game time, due to the new rank matchmaking imbalance changes. **TLDR: Great concept and fun gameplay epically ruined by an utterly incompetent dev team who refuse to listen to the player-base.

description: Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer (4vs1) horror game where one player takes on the role of the savage Killer, and the other four players play as Survivors, trying to escape the Killer and avoid being caught and killed.
name: Dead by Daylight
review: I've been playing this game since Huntress and David came out and it has changed a lot over the years. The bugs are inconvenient but funny, the licences are great, the player base is what makes the game miserable.

description: Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer (4vs1) horror game where one player takes on the role of the savage Killer, and the other four players play as Survivors, trying to escape the Killer and avoid being caught and killed.
name: Dead by Daylight
review: Let me make this clear, I love Dead By Daylight, which probably confuses you as I have stated that I wouldn't recommend this to other players, and there is a very good reason for this. Firstly, certain elements of this game are incredibly unbalanced. The map system in this game is complete garbage, and even though I am a survivor main with 75% of my hours across all platforms being that of a survivor, most of the maps in this game are ruthless for killers. I wouldn't say this game is survivor sided, as realistically a "scummy" killer can hold all the power in a game by simply going against the "survivor rulebook for killers", but it is still brutal. Multiple videos providing evidence for this can be found online, including videos from Demi, Tru3Talent, etc. From broken loops to sweat squads with locker flashlighting on dead dawg saloon, the potential to destroy a killer's motivation to play this game is definitely there. Secondly, after 1000 hours in this game, you would expect to be able to have all perks for all characters on at least half of the cast for one of the sides. I am sure if you were ridiculously efficient with how you spend your bloodpoints form the VERY beginning of the game, then it just might be barely possible. Tier systems for perks in this game are outdated and needs to be completely removed for both sides. This would avoid needed thousands of hours to be able to play any killer however you want, and play any survivor how you want as well. I'm aware changing survivors doesn't really matter too much, but for killers this is a really big deal. Lastly, mmr is complete trash. The "ranking" system in dbd has never been accurate and probably never will be. Ironically the current "grade" system is better at ranking than the mmr "ranking" system. I'm aware in a game like this it is hard to create a sustainable ranking system, but just slapping a bad system onto it and calling it a day is not a solution. Every new patch in dbd seems to make the game slightly more unplayable for both sides, but mostly for killers. Everyone runs the same 4 perks out of a pool of 6 or 7 on both sides, and it's ridiculous how little variety there is in this game. Half of the excellent perks are locked behind paywalls (which whilst not an issue for myself personally, is a giant issue for a 5 year old game). This is no longer a game that I have an infinite amount of passion for like I used to. I have played this game (on console) from just after it's launch, but repeatedly came back as I found the concept to be original and enticing. Back in late 2018 I switched to the PC version, stopped playing yet again but in 2019 was drawn back into it again. This was probably the peak of dbd for myself and a lot of others, as whilst it was unbalanced it was nowhere near as hellish as it currently is. I met some lifelong friends through this game so will always be grateful to it, and it will always hold a special place to me as far as a game can. If you are thinking of getting this game, be prepared to sink thousands of hours into it before being able to play at an optimal level. I wish you luck, and hope you grow to love this game as much as I did.

description: Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer (4vs1) horror game where one player takes on the role of the savage Killer, and the other four players play as Survivors, trying to escape the Killer and avoid being caught and killed.
name: Dead by Daylight
review: I can't say it's a good game, mostly due to the vast majority of its player base, survivors and killers alike, trying to get under your skin to make you as angry as they are. I don't blame them. This game is so flawed in many aspects, and no amount of perks will ever fix that. Take it from someone who 100% DbD twice. You could spend your time doing much better things, like learning to cook Bucatini with mushrooms & sausage. Hell, let me teach you how: You'll need: -1 lb Bucatini pasta -1/2 lb Italian sausage, casings removed -8 oz sliced mushrooms -1/2 onion, chopped -2 cloves garlic, minced -1/2 cup dry white wine -1 cup chicken or vegetable broth -1/2 cup heavy cream -1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese -2 tbsp chopped fresh parsley -2 tbsp olive oil -Salt and pepper, to taste 1. Cook the Bucatini pasta in a large pot of salted boiling water until it's al dente. Drain and set aside. 2. Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the Italian sausage and cook for 8–10 minutes, breaking it up into small pieces with a wooden spoon, until it's browned and fully cooked. Remove the sausage from the skillet and set it aside. 3. In the same skillet, sauté sliced mushrooms, chopped onions, and minced garlic for 3–4 minutes, until the mushrooms are tender. 3. Pour dry white wine into the skillet and cook for 1–2 minutes, until the liquid has reduced by half. 4. Add chicken or vegetable broth to the skillet and bring it to a simmer. Let the mixture cook for 5–7 minutes, or until the sauce has thickened slightly. 5. Stir in the cooked sausage, heavy cream, and grated Parmesan cheese until the cheese has melted, and the sauce is creamy. 6. Season the sauce with salt and pepper to taste. 7. Divide the cooked Bucatini pasta onto serving plates and spoon the mushroom and sausage sauce over the top. Garnish with chopped parsley and additional Parmesan cheese, if desired. You're done! Go prepare some nice pasta and impress your friends.

description: Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer (4vs1) horror game where one player takes on the role of the savage Killer, and the other four players play as Survivors, trying to escape the Killer and avoid being caught and killed.

description: Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer (4vs1) horror game where one player takes on the role of the savage Killer, and the other four players play as Survivors, trying to escape the Killer and avoid being caught and killed.
name: Dead by Daylight
review: At its core, Dead By Daylight is a game that oozes potential and replayability. However as someone who has been playing the game for several years, I cannot in all good conscience recommend the game to anybody in its current state. Behaviour Interactive is the least passionate, least engaged, and most lazy game developer I've ever come across. Never before have I had so little confidence in a studio's ability to perform basic tasks until I played Dead By Daylight. Bugs that would take a normal developer hours to fix would take BHVR weeks. In-game concepts that are common knowledge to the community are often lost on, or completely ignored by BHVR. You can expect balance changes that will leave you baffled and scratching your head because on a fundamental level, Behaviour Interactive does not understand their own game, nor do they intend to. Devs past and present exude elitism out of every pore as though they know what's best for the game, and the community knows nothing. Several glaring issues such as a heavy grind, a lack of diversity in recent characters, and power creep are sure to go unaddressed because BHVR both don't know or care about their game. At the end of the day, Dead By Daylight is a fun horror/party game that is currently being run into the ground by its unenthused leadership. A game with a solid foundation whose cries for competence and care are likely to go unheard for the remainder of its life.

description: A co-op horror about scavenging at abandoned moons to sell scrap to the Company.
name: Lethal Company
review: Fun Game, needs greater goal. I hit "not recommended" because most of the recommended reviews do not mention any problems. I did enjoy this game, but I feel it has a flaw that seriously mitigates it in the long term. This game is a great time with friends and it is fun to progress, get loot, and furnish your ship. However, the game is set up where there is no ending, however the quota will keep rising until it is unachievable and you will die as a result. You can't even make save files, so once you are "fired" your whole campaign is gone. By the time the quota got too high to meet, my friends and I all agreed we wished we could continue buying new gadgets and progressing. So I'd say it either needs an ending other than death, or the quota should rise slower, and eventually plateau. (the plateau could be higher depending on a difficulty setting.) You should also be able to load back to previous saves. Edit: I hit not recommended because I wanted my criticisms to stand out, and I feared hitting "recommended" would bury it in the echo chamber of reviews saying the game is perfect. I wish Steam had a middle option... I see why people are upset I would do that when I have all these hours in the game, but when I look for criticisms in games I often filter by not recommended to find them. I do recommend this game, but unlike 99% of the positive reviews I have some suggestions. Also, you don't have to agree with my suggestions and it shouldn't offend you if don't. I'm tired of people saying that because the game is in early access, criticism is invalid. A game being in early access is not a magic shield that makes it immune to criticism. In fact, criticism is helpful to devs because it tells them what people do not enjoy or what they wish was added.

I absolutely love the mansion level, and I think the game would have so much more replay-ability if there was more variety to the indoor parts of each moon. I know the dev is capable of this because The Upturned was a banger with its locations, just hope that more variety can be added here

description: A co-op horror about scavenging at abandoned moons to sell scrap to the Company.
name: Lethal Company
review: While I'd really like to see the progression loop of this game torn out and replaced with something more interesting, the actual gameplay loop is extremely good. Going in, getting stuff, and getting out in the worst places ever is fantastic. But I still would love to see some sort of permanent progression. Starting from 0 just kinda sucks and there's not really anything to work for that's meaningful once you can reach Titan. So there's not really anything beyond "going in, getting stuff, getting out." Nothing to unlock, nothing really to reach. But that being said - the moment to moment gameplay is fantastic. I've never laughed so hard at a horror game. I just hope there's a reason to keep coming back or something to work for in the future because at this point I feel like I've seen everything this game has to offer. Edit: I keep going back and forth if I should leave this as "recommended" vs "not recommended" and I think i'm going to leave it at Not Recommended. I wish there was a midpoint between the two because that's more realistic towards how I feel.

description: A co-op horror about scavenging at abandoned moons to sell scrap to the Company.
name: Lethal Company
review: Overall, its a great game. The reason I wouldnt recommend it is because, you cant ever find a lobby. Here i'll give a few situations: 1.) People only want experienced players in all the lobbies. 2.) all lobbies are either "Girls only" or "" 3.) You finally get into a lobby thats 2/4, youre the third person to join, a fourth person joins and the host ends up kicking you both. 4.) You find a 3/4 lobby and join when the host forgot to invite their friend. 5.) You create a lobby since you couldnt find one and noone joins. -- By no means is this a terrible game, its great fun genuinely, but most of your time playing youll be wanting to find a lobby only to get into like 10% of all the lobbies you join, unless you have friends who also have lethal I'd probably wait a while before getting it right now.

description: A co-op horror about scavenging at abandoned moons to sell scrap to the Company.
name: Lethal Company
review: I do like the concept, but I just do not get anything from the game that keeps me wanting to continue playing passed the first quota or two. If the jump scares get you and you enjoy searching for items while wandering through procedurally generated hallways running away from monsters, then knock yourself out. To me, Lethal Company seems like a game that's better watched than played at it's current state of development. It's all about the reactions of your friends, or otherwise just streamer bait. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ With that said I do wish all the best for this game and it's dev. Hopefully we get some more interesting elements introduced in future updates to draw in boring old people like me. :)

review: So I have worked for this company for a little while I will list the pros and cons. Pros: Company supplied space ship. Cons: Company does not supply any equipment so that comes out of your own pocket. No 401K or Paid Time Off Company does not recognize sick days No health, dental, or vision insurance Failure to meet company quotas results in your untimely demise TL;DR This game is basically like working at Walmart.

description: A co-op horror about scavenging at abandoned moons to sell scrap to the Company.
name: Lethal Company
review: This review is for anyone looking for actual criticism of the game. I do recommend the game. The game quickly becomes a snooze fest after the 15 hour mark. The "terror" highs you experience during the first five hours are one of, if not the best I've experienced in this type of game. The next five hours is you being scared but breaking down and understanding the creatures one by one whilst getting scrap and learning each items mechanics. The last five I had were mastering each creature/item/map. After that, I felt my first case of boredom. Now at 20 hours I feel burnt out. I am happily awaiting more content for this early access game.

Difficult to get a consistent full lobby to last. Has its moments, but over-hyped.

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: I wish there was a "It really is great, but not for me" button. Being a fan of the Souls games as well as Bloodborne, I found myself in familiar territory with Sekiro, but something just wasn't quite clicking. All the new systems function well, and the setting is expertly crafted, but it's the stripped away RPG elements that leave me feeling empty with Sekiro. For me, so much of the enjoyment of the Soulsborne games came from exploring the intricately designed areas and finding strange little nooks and crannies containing unique weapons and/or armor. It felt like an interesting and satisfying reward for exploration. In Sekiro, every item you find in the world is more or less a consumable (with few exceptions), and that sense of wonderment feels lost. I feel no desire to explore secondary paths knowing that they all end in yet another pocketful of confetti. That sense that each pathway could potentially result in a weapon that changes your whole playstyle (if you want it to) is no longer present. This drawback also bleeds into my second issue with Sekiro: Being locked into a singular playstyle. Again, to reference the Soulsborne franchise, FromSoft games have always come with a variety of ways to build your character. Do you want to be a heavily armored brute with a two handed axe? Have at it. Want to be a robe-wearing mage? Go nuts. How about a holy Paladin type that hurls lightning-spears from behind a shield? Whatever floats your boat. On the flip side, Sekiro takes the approach of "learn the new parry/block system or die." Without having the previous FromSoft titles as reference, this isn't a bad thing in and of itself. The system works well and has a good deal of polish; it's the fact that it represents yet another facet of RPG-oriented gameplay that has been stripped away from FromSoft's design philosophy. The world itself also feels much more linear than that of the Soulsborne titles. To compare Sekiro to Bloodborne or Dark Souls, it's clear that FromSoft was less interested in the intricate world building they're so well known for. The levels are gorgeous and well crafted, but are much simpler and straight forward. The lore is not nearly as cryptic and expansive, and the host of characters are far less enigmatic. Again, not an objectively negative trait, just... Not what I admire about FromSoft titles. In a vacuum, this game is fantastic on a technical level. In the scope of FromSoft's catalogue, it's a shift away from what I love most in their games.

publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: Game seems excellent, but there is no easy mode I can find in settings, and certainly no easy mode for seniors. I have been pc gaming since the 80's and indeed played some early arcade games on lab computers when in college 50 yrs ago. I buy top of the line gaming computers, but now that I am 73 rapid reflexes are a thing of the past. Don't get old!

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: 2023 EDIT EDIT: Having played a different game by the name of Lies of P, and having experienced far far worse difficulty woes, I am resolving to rethink this review. I will replay this game sometime soon and see if my feelings have changed on it. Until then, I encourage any readers to look at positive reviews. If you're on the fence, you'll probably at least somewhat enjoy it. --------------------------------------------------- Original Review Below: Cdr. William T. Riker's review said it best: There needs to be a middle option. A "Great Game, but Not for Me" Button. Pros: + Yet another title by Hidetaka Miyazaki with some of the most fantastic visual presentation out there. The care that goes into the environments in his games is not to be ignored, with certain areas looking fucking beautiful. + Mobility and verticality are two areas Sekiro improves upon, with every area feeling fully accessible, and exploration constantly rewarding you with interesting diverging paths and optional encounters. + Storytelling has had its ups and downs in the Souls series, with your character essentially being a blank slate that pieces things together from interactions and lore. Sekiro's story, however, feels somewhat more fleshed out, and the area of Ashina (and its surrounding locations) tends to show more of the downfall of the city, even going so far as to humanize the enemy more than most others game have so far. This seems to be a common trend for Miyazaki's "Souls-But-Not-Souls" games, as Bloodborne did very well in this aspect as well. + Captures the feeling of "being a Shinobi" pretty well, with a mixture of gadgets and special techniques in your arsenal, and a focus on stealth that has never quite been realized in the series before outside of backstabs. Even bosses can be hit with this to guarantee a cheap free shot, with speedrunners finding ways to abuse the system to make some bosses laughable. And the tools are enjoyable to use, with some upgrades and skill unlocks feeling particularly badass. + The music is fantastic and boss fights are very memorable despite mostly being humanoid. Some bosses, in particular, are a little TOO memorable (looking at you, Headless). Cons: - Difficulty (1): There is a huge discussion piece for this game right now. I do not think the game needs an easy mode, but I do think that the game is far less satisfying than any given Dark Souls game. There are a lot of flaws that make the game frustrating to anyone who aren't at "git gud" levels: the need to farm to use tools if you're not good at conserving them, the severe punishments for dying frequently (arguably far worse than the rest of the games in some ways), the absurd staggering that can occur if you take a hit that leads to you taking MORE hits, the lack of animation canceling, the absurd boss tracking (in particular a certain boss in the fucking beginning who manages to grab you when you're miles away behind him)... it's engineered to punish more than any other game has so far. - Difficulty (2): Boss difficulty is an oddity in this game as well. Some are frustrating but enjoyable to study and deal with, such as your fight against Genichiro (and a certain returning enemy in the same place you fight Genichiro). Others, like the final boss, enjoy constant move spam, staggering attacks, and the ridiculous "RED MOVE" where you have to make a split second realization as to whether you should dodge, jump, or parry/interrupt. The red move is the most annoying of the mix, as the game encourages you to discern what you should do based on the posture or movement of the boss. However, this felt incredibly inconsistent and frustrating to attempt to do in battle unless the enemy was pushing forward and you have the ability to counter it by stepping on their weapon. What ended up happening was that for these bosses I'd simply die again, and again, and again until, eventually, by way of throwing my face at a problem enough, I'd eventually win through luck and anger. - Difficulty (3): I feel like there has to be a discussion on what value we gain from a game being "difficult", and where we draw the line. This goes beyond some stupid argument about 'accessibility' (I'm sure there are people with disabilities or a lack of interest in games who can whip my ass at this game), instead focusing on the concept of enjoyment. I beat Sekiro, I sat down and fought every boss and lost, and tried again and lost, and studied, and looked up strategies, and examined speedrunners, and "got good". I even did it, more or less, like the game wanted: in their face, parrying moves, making judgements and dashing at the right times. It took me 33 hours, which is a far shot from other people's playthroughs. But for once in the series, I absolutely hated the experience. It's not the first time the game has had cheap moments, but it is the first time I've left the game's ending feeling zero enthusiasm for repeating the experience or any sense of satisfaction. It's the difference between the uphill climb of a Dark Souls game and Sekiro cunt-punting you off a cliff and throwing you a dagger to climb back up with. Yeah, given enough time and unlimited retries, I could maybe pull it off - but why would I want to? - Items have never felt more useless in the series. A lack of meaningful weapons or armors seriously downgrades the experience, where the only items you'll find that are genuinely great to find are gourd seeds, a tool (most of which are purchased anyway), or Divine Confetti, which is basically essential in some fights. Most of the other items, while having various uses, barely ever feel necessary or a boon to help you, either offering too little to be worth casting or requiring too much to be worth using. This ties into an overwhelming sense of "why" when it comes to exploration. You do meet new people and find optional encounters, and they're certainly INTERESTING to move around in with the aforementioned verticality of your grapple hook -- but at the end of it all, your rewards for doing so are usually nothing. - A lack of playstyle variety is a significant issue as well, and a complete departure from one of the fundamental enjoyable aspects of Miyazaki's games: choice. You learn the Parry System and you use your katana as your main damaging weapon, and that's it. The minimal ammo system for the tools means it is virtually impossible to only use them, and even if you could their uses are meant to compliment your sword, not replace it. - Majority of the unlocked skills, while badass to look at, do very little in terms of damage and often leave you vulnerable. - A lack of multiplayer, while understandable, is a significant blow to any sort of community being built around the game. Overall: After 33 hours, I can safely say I beat the game. And... I cannot say that Sekiro is a bad game. Time and money and care went into this experience. It is a whole package, completely free from the usual overtly-predatory bullshit we see in games a lot these days. It played smoothly, it ran well on my system. And, ultimately, not all of it was awful - there were some fights that were genuinely fun to experience, and glimpses of the original intensity and enjoyment the souls games bring. But as an individual, I just did not like this game overall. Dark Souls games have always had a bit of difficulty and frustration to them, but this one was so overt while lacking a lot of the things that brought about my personal enjoyment in the series. At the end of the day, the button asks if I recommend this game. And I do not. BUT, look at other people's opinions about it. Maybe it's more suited to you.

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: DISCLAIMER Personally, I do enjoy Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice. However, unlike with From Software’s previous titles, I would not recommend this to the average gamer looking for a tough-but-fair experience, which is why I opted to give it a “would not recommend” label instead. I wish there was a “mixed” option, or a way to simply write a review without being forced to labelling a game as positive or negative, but there isn’t. That said, I would thoroughly recommend Sekiro to you if you enjoy sitting down and intently studying move sets of enemies and bosses, not minding repeated re-tries until you eventually figure out how to react to each of their attacks on an order of magnitude way above the Souls series; and if you liked the parry system in the Dark Souls series, because, at its core, Sekiro is largely a parry game. These are my thoughts on the game so far, roughly 20 hours in. It is possible that some of the observations and assumptions in the following write-up will change, however, it is unlikely. I have meanwhile beaten the game (~30 hours) and my opinions remain largely unchanged! If anything, my issues with the game got exacerbated by the design of the last few areas and bosses. Combat & Combat-related Combat feels overly punishing at times, and requires persistent mastery over the game magnitudes higher than any previous From Software games did. Minibosses, bosses and even most regular enemies push out intense damage, commonly being able to kill Wolf with 2-3 attacks. Most* bosses and minibosses can only feasibly be killed by building up their posture gauge, which is mostly done by deflecting their attacks; requiring near perfect moveset knowledge from the player before they have any real chance of defeating them. Bosses tend to have checkpoints close to their boss arenas, however, minibosses do not. Additionally, miniboss arenas tend to have other enemies placed in them. Whenever you die to a miniboss, you are forced to clear out the entire arena of regular enemies before you can engage the miniboss again. In arenas with 7-10 other creatures on patrol paths that require you to sneak around and wait for them to patrol past you, this gets tedious quick. Certain types of enemies can only be properly damaged by using certain items. Those items do not replenish upon resting at a shrine, and so, if you die a lot to bosses that require the use of said items, you will be forced to regularly leave the area and either farm up sen to buy more supplies, or to farm enemies and hope for the right items to drop. *Certain enemies and bosses take little posture damage, forcing a type of fight more similar to From Software’s previous titles. However, the vast majority of boss fights are designed for deflection style of combat. Death Death seems to be the most punishing out of all of From Software’s previous titles. You lose 50% of your carried sen and 50% of your progress towards your next skill point whenever you die. This is mostly par for the course considering their previous games. However, dying has consequences to the NPCs around you. More and more NPCs will eventually become sick as you die more often, halting their questline progressions until you cure them. Curing an NPC can be done, however, the cure is only temporary (if you continue dying, NPCs will get sick again), and the items required to create the cure are extremely limited (the wiki currently lists their total number at 8, but as the game is new still, there might be undiscovered merchants). If you mismanage your cure timings, cure too liberally, or simply die too much, you will lock yourself out of NPC questlines. Exploration Moving through the world feels great, with many hidden nooks and crannies, side paths and optional areas. The grappling hook adds fantastic verticality to nearly every place you visit, often allowing you to avoid a frontal approach and instead come in from behind or above and take out a bunch of enemies. The level design is top-notch. However, the joy of exploration is greatly stifled by the absence of real new weapons and armour pieces. 95% of all the loot you will ever find are coin pouches and consumables, the other 5% are new prosthetic tools and the rare item that upgrades your stats. Finding yet another ceramic shard that you can throw at enemies doesn’t feel exciting. Finding the latter feels rewarding, since those types of items tend to be guarded by tough opponents. The worst part is that, sometimes, tough enemies and even mini-bosses guard dead-ends with no interesting loot whatsoever. All in all, not being able to find new weapons or armour pieces puts a big damper on the joy of exploration. Skill System The game features a skill tree to upgrade Wolf with. With only two types of skill upgrades available, passives and special moves (of which you can only have 1 active), the skill system feels rather bare-bones. The prosthetic upgrading system has a lot of options, adding roughly 3 variations to each of Wolf’s prosthetic tools (of which you can only have 1 slotted per tool). It is unlikely that you will be able to fully unlock all skills nor all prosthetics unless you intend to do a heavy amount of grinding, and some materials needed to upgrade the prosthetic might be limited per playthrough. There is no real way to change up your playstyle. None of the passive or active skills or prosthetic upgrades alter the core playstyle in any meaningful way. Unlike their Demons’s/Dark Souls series, you won’t be able to customise your character to fit a certain playstyle. Bugs & Glitches I’ve run into these only rarely, but they do exist and most of them lead to the death of Wolf, resulting in you losing half of your sen and skill experience to no fault of your own. The jumping system is a bit of a mess and finicky to control. At times, Wolf will slide off of platforms, that, moments earlier you were able to jump on perfectly fine. When fighting enemies with big weapons on slopes, Wolf has been literally hammered “into the ground”, rendering him uncontrollable, stuck inside the level geometry and forcing a death or ALT+F4. Occasionally, the grappling system (especially the grapple-from-point-to-point version) flings you into directions that get you killed: like literally away from the next grapple point. Trying to jump onto certain objects can leave Wolf in an endless falling animation loop, with the only means of escape being ALT+F4, which could potentially lead to your save file becoming corrupted (the chance of actual save corruption should be highly unlikely, however). Like I wrote above, overall I do enjoy Sekiro but many of the design decisions have moved the game into a spot where I don’t feel I can rightly recommend the title to the “average” gamer, unlike their Souls series. This is mainly due to the intense damage you take from nearly everything in the game, and the requirement to sit down and absolutely learn attack patterns. In Dark Souls you had a good chance of beating a boss, even if it was your first encounter with it. With Sekiro, for every boss and miniboss I have fought, I needed a couple attempts to study and learn how to react to their move sets. At times I walked away and came back later, due to how tedious it is to repeatedly and slowly clear out miniboss arenas. This requirement to borderline perfectly learn a move set for every miniboss and boss you encounter and the requirement of mastery over so many enemies, I feel, is something that might turn average, less dedicated, gamers away from the title.

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: I'm going to start out by saying that I am a huge fan of the Soulsborne series of games, and that has heavily colored both my expectations and judgements of Sekiro. Sekiro is a different beast, and while the Soulsborne DNA is quite evident, it remixes the elements it takes from the past games and uses them to create something that's innately distinct. My personal feeling is that Sekiro is worse for this, but many disagree, and they're not exactly wrong. It's different. That said, Sekiro is simply much less fun for me than any of the Soulsborne games. I've unlocked every ending, collected every item, completed all the questlines and bosses. I wanted to love Sekiro, as I love Dark Souls and Bloodborne, but after I'd checked everything off the list of things to do, I felt relieved and happy that I had no reason to play it any more, something that's never happened with any of the Soulsborne games. There is very little replayability in Sekiro, and once you've done everything... you've really done everything. In Dark Souls, you can play again with an entirely different style; the first time I played, I used a spear and shield almost exclusively, using armor that made rolls useless. Then I discarded the shield and armor, and grabbed a halberd for my next run, rolling as my only defense. Later I realized that the Great Scythe has an entirely different playstyle to most weapons, that certain weapons could be very useful in the offhand, that ultra greatswords were an enjoyable power trip, that rapiers were amazing counter tools... I've played Dark souls through many times over the years, always coming back and trying something new. In Sekiro, you get a katana. This katana has a light attack, a charged heavy stab, and a single combat art that can be equipped from a large variety. I've unlocked every combat art in the game, and despite there being about twenty of them, there's only three that are particularly good, and of those three, one of them is the best tool 70% of the time. You can change your combat art, but in general they're only useful for trivializing certain mooks, or countering certain boss attacks. With one arguable exception if spammed, they don't change how you play, they just make one or two moves easy to deal with. Prosthetics are a big deal whenever you hear about Sekiro, and you can equip three of them at once, which is nice, but broadly they have the same problem. The majority of the prosthetics that are available act as simple direct counters to enemies, a few of which are extremely difficult to fight unless you use the specific counter prosthetic. Many of them deal damage, but they're not fast or strong enough to be useful against bosses, and they're too expensive to use often against normal mooks. Two of them are extremely useful against bosses (with a few others occasionally being useful as specific counters), but both are barely more complex than "Press button to get a couple free hits in." There is just no depth to customization. Everything you fight, you will fight with a katana, and you will fight it in the one way that thing is fought. I find Sekiro deeply disappointing in terms of variety and lore. Almost all environments--except for one clearly inspired by a specific Lovecraft story--are deliberately mundane. The vast majority of enemies are some variation on a human with a normal weapon. There are very big humans with clubs, very small humans with knives, and hunched-over humans with large shuriken axe things, who are all about as visually nonhuman as an orc or gnome. They're all pretty similar to fight; be aggressive, constantly attack, stop only to block or parry their attacks when necessary. The bosses and minibosses also all largely follow this pattern of being human with a normal weapon. There are precisely three bosses which break the pattern as much as, say, Taurus Demon, the Bell Gargoyles, Capra Demon, Quelaag, Ceaseless Discharge, or the Iron Golem, and that's, uh, all the bosses in the first half of Dark Souls. Few of Sekiro's bosses feel like rehashes of a prior boss, but not many of them really feel original or exciting, either. You're just stabbing some uninteresting dude for no real reason beyond him being in your way, if even that. That leads into my last complaint. Sekiro is a story driven game, but its story just sucks. The protagonist is largely devoid of personality, the classic scowling stoic. There are four endings, only one of which has him taking an action without any prompting from somebody else, and despite that action breaking completely from the path of the story... it doesn't feel at all unbelievable for the protagonist to take it, because he's so flat. There are some interesting characters, but they're mundane, and with only hints of their greater stories being told. The game successfully made me curious about many things, and I did want to know more about the stories of several villains, but I was rarely rewarded with anything more than a couple sentences before they were forgotten about, a minor distraction on the endless path of aimless murder. There are major twists in the plot, but they feel senseless and random, without much more than the minimum foreshadowing, and even that only if you looked for it. Events broadly feel like they happen because the author felt like they were the best way to have some particular boss battle or encounter, not because it's what the depicted characters and world would result in. If Wolf is Sekiro's point of view character, Wolf is blind, or Sekiro is dumb. Personally, I think both are true. There is much more to say. The game is not small, and I could quibble about its elements and design choices for hours. It's not exactly a bad game--the posture system is excellent, for one, and I hope that it's somehow integrated into the next Soulsborne game. These, however, are my main problems, and they keep me from considering Sekiro to be a great game. It's just... decent, and that's disappointing.

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: I enjoy the Soulsborne franchise but for some reason I don't feel like I enjoy this game. I think my biggest reason is the fact that when it came to Dark Souls, I always wanted to beat a very hard boss. Sometimes it would take a lot of time, but I always wanted to keep going and going for hours on end sometimes. When I did beat a boss, I felt accomplished and somewhat proud. I don't know why but I do not feel the same way in Sekiro, for some reason it just is not rewarding to me. I don't feel accomplished after beating a boss( or mini boss ) in Sekiro. I don't know why that is. I don't find it fun at all. Some people like the rock, paper, scissors type combat however it isn't for me I don't think. I will most likely get comments saying 'git gud' which is fair. I did find the game hard in some parts, as I did with Dark Souls but in this case, I had no motivation to overcome it like I did in Dark Souls. I don't think the difficulty drove me away from the game, more so the combat mechanics as a whole which sucks because the game looks great. If the mechanics were different and if I felt a sense of accomplishment after beating a boss, I honestly think I'd enjoy it. However if the mechanics were different it wouldn't be Sekiro then would it. The game seems to be fun to a lot of other people though and that is more important. You can't please everyone sadly. I do hope the best though for FromSoftware and hopefully maybe their next game will be the one for me, who knows.

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: Sekiro gets rid of build variety, item variety, customization, and creative gameplay in favor of a very stripped down, very focused experience. It's tightly-designed and extremely thoughtful in its implementation with a high gameplay skill ceiling. The game is punishingly difficult with very little in the way of shortcuts. The only way to progress is to learn the game and increase your skills. Your character doesn't get much stronger, you have to. Some people really enjoy that! I wasn't one of them and found Sekiro tedious after the midgame. Another tough miniboss, another back-and-forth samurai duel on the rooftop, another guy with a spear,.. You fought this boss, now fight it again with triple the health. There's no reason to replay the game because there's no different way to play, you'd just be doing the exact same thing again. If you like the gameplay, then this is a plus but for me it lacks the endless replayability of other FromSoft titles, plus you have to be Boring Gruffdude the whole time. It's an extremely well-designed, well-polished game that (for me) got boring and which I have no desire to play again, and certainly no desire to buy DLC for. But that's because it wasn't designed for me. If you like fast-paced, technical gameplay that rewards persistence and practice, you'll find many of the boss fights cathartic. After four or five catharses, I was over it.

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: Objectively, despite the fact that From Software never learned how to make an honest death-action hit, they haven’t forgotten how to make beautiful worlds that are interesting to explore. If you want challenges and tests of your reflexes - the game is for you. Subjectively, the most important difference from the Souls series, and the most important disadvantage of the game for me is that it does not give any opportunity to play the way you like. Only parries, only monotonous setting of timings. If you, like me, like to go through the Souls series, constantly experimenting with sets of equipment, choosing a style for yourself, then you will not like this game.

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: I wish I could have loved Sekiro. So much about it is perfect, including the handling of the character, the stealth mechanics, the new grapple system (which adds a whole new dimension of verticality to FromSoft's formula), the world and enemy design, and so many other things. But I think FromSoft took the difficulty too far with this one. Before you dismiss me as a casual and tell me to Git Gud, let me just say that I beat the game four days ago. Yes I finished the whole thing. And I enjoyed a lot of it, especially the stealth sections, which were implemented extremely well. But if I'm being honest, it feels like the balance between TOUGH and FAIR was completely thrown off this time. I'm an avid Souls fan; been playing those games since 2011 and I've loved every single one. They are tough as nails, but they always feel fair. Death is treated as a learning experience rather than a punishment, and if you're careful, you can almost always get your XP back after you die. If a boss is kicking your trash, you can grind smaller enemies for a while to level up. You can switch out armor, weapons, rings, buffs, and other stuff to see which strategy works best. Some bosses are easier to tank, some bosses require speed and precise dodging. But there's always a way to work around the problem. It's like a puzzle. If you try enough strategies, you'll eventually be victorious. And if worst comes to worst, you can always summon a friend to help. It's a tough series, but there's always a way to win, and that's what I love about Souls. Tough but fair, always. With Sekiro, every single benefit I just mentioned is gone. Every single one. If you die (and you will), you lose half your money immediately, along with your XP. There's a small, random chance that Unseen Aid will kick in and save your currency, but that chance starts at 30% and gets lower whenever you die. I was at 4% by the end of the game, and literally saw Unseen Aid twice in my last ten hours. There are no alternate weapons, there is no armor customization whatsoever, there's no grinding to level up, there's no summoning at all. There are no alternate strategies to beat a boss. You either deflect or you die. I got really good at deflecting, and sometimes it's incredibly fun and satisfying, and I would have happily played the game if that was the focus. But it isn't. Sekiro focuses on making the boss encounters as difficult as possible, in the most spammy, annoying way. The game teaches you deflecting and forces you to master it, but even if you do, the bosses are still almost impossible. They have ENORMOUS health pools, multiple phases, and most of them can one-shot you with no problem at all. Bosses can take upwards of 20 minutes, during which your gameplay has to be literally perfect, or you're dead. It never feels fun, it feels like a grind. I was so frustrated because my deflecting was so good, I mean I pretty much mastered it, but if I made one mistake 12 minutes into a fight, it was all over. Yes, you can resurrect. Yes, the bosses can hit you during your resurrect animation. Yes, the bosses can also resurrect, again and again. There was never a sense of accomplishment or elation after a tough boss fight. I just felt glad to be done and angry that it had wasted so much of my time. In particular, the last boss has four phases, all of them gruelingly difficult, and took me over a hundred tries to kill. It stopped being fun so long ago, and I just wanted to uninstall the game at that point. Rant over. The game isn't for me. There's so much about it that is amazing, but prepare for some serious roadblocks.

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.

review: i hate blazing bull stupid dog

description: Game of the Year - The Game Awards 2019 Best Action Game of 2019 - IGN Carve your own clever path to vengeance in the award winning adventure from developer FromSoftware, creators of Bloodborne and the Dark Souls series. Take Revenge. Restore Your Honor. Kill Ingeniously.
name: Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice - GOTY Edition
publishers: Activision (Excluding Japan and Asia), FromSoftware (Japan), 方块游戏 (Asia)
review: I really don't dislike this game per se but I find the From Software formula to be self indulgent at best. I find myself just not able to justify the amount of time I'm spending on just learning the attack patterns of what amount to be trash mobs and the whole routine just disappoints me as a lifelong gamer. The highs from conquering a challenging boss can no longer outweigh the frustration of struggling more with adds from random roaming enemies. I find myself cursing out my game and acting in a way that generally makes the people around me tense and uncomfortable. I'm just trying to focus on the game but that's just it, it's just a game. From Software isn't challenging me more than I can give, it's challenging me in a way that's demonstrably unhealthy for me and the people around me. So I've decided to step back from this game that has become a source of toxic energy for me and play something else instead. Genuinely, this game is amazing if you're into From Software's back library. Give it a try, see if you like it, but I'm over it. Edit: As of 10/24/2020 I have officially beat the game. It really wasn't worth it. I genuinely feel like I wasted the time I put into playing this game and should have been playing something fun instead.
