review: After spending a fair bit of time, money and being quite committed to the game for a solid year, it was time to stop. The first several hours are shallow. The next 40 are thrilling. The next 400 are fulfilling. The next 1000 are wasted. Fun. A late-game power fantasy. A second job. A game with enchanting potential, but not enough direction to fulfill it. The development team is under shareholder pressure to pump out 'content' frequently, but the capacity to keep up with expectations isn't there. The fun is lost in attempts to pad-out content. If you go ahead with the game, be conscious of feeling exhausted or losing sight of what you're doing at the computer. It's easy to fall into a mindset where being efficient means pushing yourself forward unreasonably. I fear that mindset of tolerating the game is what kept me on the hook for so long.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: Unfortunately, and I say this with a heavy heart, I cannot, in good conscience, recommend Warframe in its current state. I've stuck with Warframe for far longer than any player should. I've been around since the Founder era. I've experienced both the highs and the lows. I've shaken hands with the devs. No, this review is not a gut reaction to the AOE nerf that seems to be in the spotlight. But rather, exists because of the progressive condition infecting Warframe that I personally refer to as "Toxic MMOsis." Symptoms include pus-like RNG discharge, feverish FOMO, and an unwitting addiction to boring, monotonous chores. -- The Heart of Warframe -- To sum it up, Warframe's core is an exciting F2P robot ninja shooter. But, these days, there's a lot of not-Warframe in Warframe. From hunting, to fishing, to mining, to... whatever Lunaro was supposed to be - I'd say DE was trying to be adventurous but in reality, they're simply relegating to tried-and-true MMO gameplay loops to pad out with a dull, lifeless grind. Even so, I stand by the premise that I don't mind grind as long as the grind involves exciting gameplay and WF's movement and shooting mechanics are nearly unparalleled. But when a grind takes me away from the core content I love, that's when I call foul. Warframe's core is sound but you now have to work to get to it. And who plays games to work? ..but that's enough about that. -- What the Heck is Toxic MMOsis, Anyways? -- I've defined Toxic MMOsis as the sacrifice of gameplay and player experience to cater to the company's greed by artificially boosting sales & play time. Toxic MMOsis is a disease not exclusively present in MMOs, but most commonly found festering there. Toxic MMOsis often comes in the form of rampant RNG, randomized, cycle-able equipment, loot boxes and other risk/reward upgrade systems that are borderline gambling. These aren't so much gameplay loops that people want as much as gameplay loops players learn to need. These strategies exploit human behavior, especially in the big spenders game companies lovingly refer to as "whales." Some of those behaviors include, decision paralysis, sunk cost fallacy, FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out), and the same endorphin release experienced when winning big at a slot machine. Early Warframe opposed and abhorred Toxic MMOsis. It was, first and foremost, a passion project to be experienced. It relied on its mod system to provide build flexibility in spades. Once you earned a thing, whether it be a frame, mod, or weapon, it is yours. Paint it pink, have it spew fire and ice, make it unload 500 little BBs in 5 seconds; whatever man, you do you! DE even regularly provided exciting new content, whether it be a progression in the story, a revamped system to toy with, or new weapons & frames to engage with. Warframe was, in my eyes, revolutionary in the MMO world. Most MMOs up to that point implemented respecs, character/tree resets, RNG upgrade systems where you could lose all your progress in a weapon, and frustrating, time-gated grinds. Each of these systems could be (and often are) integrated into a devious monetization scheme to entice those "whales" to turn their pockets inside out to compensate for the time sink. Not early Warframe. That was beyond them. -- Honest Feature Trailers -- Enough preamble - here's a quick (non-comprehensive) timeline of DE's roadtrip to hell. I've even formulated my artist's rendition of DE's thought process akin to one of those brutally honest game/movie trailers. Keep in mind, most of these new systems took the form of a new content lake, distinct from everything else, further muddling the experience for old and new players alike. * Events - occasional events that offered timed exclusive content FOMO - Don't play those other games releasing this weekend! Come back to play Warframe! We have weapons only available here this week... But don't worry - if you miss out, we'll offer them again! We just won't tell you when. Maybe next week. Maybe next year! But most likely when that shiny, new game you've been eyeing releases. * Focus System - introduced grindy skill trees that could not be respecced Sunk cost/Decision Paralysis - Ooooo, choose your school wisely because if you don't like your build, you'll have to spend tons more time to fix it! But hey, you can always buy these handy lenses to hasten your journey to the top with real money! Don't worry - we're not exploiting you since you can't just buy focus outright! That'd be awful. Gosh, who would do such a thing? * Sorties - introduced a weekly challenge FOMO - We've noticed you don't play Warframe every week! Did you forget we own a percentage of your life and a chunk of your soul? Let's remind you with these glorious new Rivens to amplify that one weapon you probably don't even use! Keep getting those useless Endo statues? Better try next week! And the next week! And the next week... * Riven System - introduced an RNG-based mod cycling mechanic Gambling - Finally got that Riven for the weapon you like but don't like the 500% aim zoom it so generously provides your Lato? Spend Kuva to cycle it to your heart's content! We dare you to TRY and roll the same stats you saw on our contracted Youtube partner's video you saw yesterday! But hey, it's totally not gambling because you can't buy Kuva! All it asks from you is your hard earned time & resources. Who needs a social life, right? * Nightwave System - the almighty pinnacle of time gating: a battle pass FOMO - What? You say you need a break from Warframe? Nah, just come and stay with us. We'll give you free stuff for engaging with neglected old systems so we can show our share holders that people LOVE fishing and it totally wasn't a waste of company time! We'll even introduce some extremely rare upgrades towards the end of the pass... But it's free, so, fine!... right? * Archon System - time-gating + RNG = disappointment FOMO - Hmm... we have a power creep problem. But whales love being the BEST! Oh well! Let's introduce more power creep, gate it behind weekly events, and lock the best shards behind RNG! Whales will go NUTS! Didn't get that Tauforged shard you wanted? Of course you didn't! Give it a few weeks! You'll DEFINITELY get it next time! "So what?" You might be asking. "Lots of game companies use these tactics!" True, but they shouldn't be rewarded for it. Players are slowly beginning to understand how games manipulate them and, to no one's surprise, they don't appreciate it. Games from AAA studios have become less about fun and more about greed. Warframe showed us before that it can support itself with crispy content, and fair gameplay mechanics. They were able to demonstrate this throughout its early lifespan and beat the odds, generating a massive fanbase despite little in the way of corporate funding. But now, it's clear they've lost sight of their passion. They've steadily reset the bar with each new content drop and convinced people they're still the good guys even though they're just hiding in the shadow cast by sinister ringleaders in the corporate world. -- TLDR; -- * Warframe is a great 3rd person shooter held back by its systems * Warframe does not respect player time * Warframe is riddled with RNG and FOMO mechanics * Warframe is swarming with boring content that masks a truly fun gameplay core * Warframe's disparate content lakes are daunting for new players and don't reward returning ones And most importantly: * Warframe's developers at DE lost sight of their original passion; Warframe is no longer Warframe If you are playing this game and happen to read this, I encourage you to uninstall and support up-and-coming developers who still have that fire ignited in them. If you're looking for a great substitute to scratch that PVE itch, try Deep Rock Galactic!

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: Founder, have been playing since 2013, over 4k hours, MR31+. While the game is still a technical marvel, weighting barely 30GB and packed with free content, I decided to uninstall it today after months of not playing. There used to be a vision, a drive behind warframe. This vision changed over time, of course, but in my opinion for the worse. In the early days, Warframe felt dark and difficult. I remember my first time encountering infested and running for my life as a fresh newbie. But as time progressed, people got stronger, the balance flaws became easier to spot, and so warframe evolved into almost a hack'n'slash in 3rd person view. And I loved it! It's fun to grind enemies to get better gear, loot, and endurance runs became feasible. But over the past 2 years, the game has been slowly dying. I'm not gonna elaborate on the story (New War), DE basically took a 2 year hiatus. They forced Necramech gameplay on us, and now operator shenanigans. Nullifiers were bad, but new eximus are worse. Control-based warframes are useless in endgame settings. Single Target weapons and frames are even more useless than before. Focus rework was supposed to give us more options, but it failed. Nuke Meta using tank warframes is not cool, not fun, but has become the only viable way to play the game. At this point it feels like developers are actively trying to fight what is in essence Warframe's true nature : a cull the weak third person hack'n'slash. New content is poorly refined, poorly balanced. Anything fun or remotely advantaging players always gets nerfed asap. What's even more frustrating is there is potential in their updates, but it always fall short, unbalanced and mediocre. I'd like to say "they need to seriously think about where they want to go and what they must do to enable it", but I'm afraid the way they want to go is not what I personally want for the game. This gap is growing ever larger and it's time for me to abandon ship.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: Update 31.5, Angels of the Zariman, is the final straw for me. It makes me sad, because I did truly love Warframe. Look at my hours logged. I bought a Founder's pack way back in the day, one of the expensive ones, too. I've put probably a grand or so into this game. Nearly every hour spent in it, I loved. But quite frankly, U31.5 is just kind of representative of a downhill slope the game has been on for the last four years. 2018 was the last year that Warframe updates were good. In late 2018, DE added the second open world. Placed on Venus and centered around a hub social zone called Fortuna, this new open world zone would be the last update that Warframe received without a curling of the monkey's paw - though even Fortuna was not a completely safe release. Alongside the new zone, a new class of "modular" secondary weapons was also added that introduced significant power creep in a way the game had, until that point, largely avoided. But at the time, it seemed harmless. Each subsequent update saw an aggressive curling of the monkey's paw. The Lich update was supposed to add dynamic boss enemies a la Shadow of Mordor's nemesis system. Instead it added boss monsters that must be manually spawned by players, and which, for the first three months post-release, had phases in their fight with mandatory player deaths. Yes, you read that correctly - Digital Extremes added a boss fight phase that requires the player to die. The Railjack update was supposed to add complex ship-crewing mechanics for four players, with one at the helm, two on the guns, and one on engineering. This update was also supposed to include an in-depth system for power management within the ship, a la Elite Dangerous. Instead, it added an even clunkier grinding zone that required randos to figure out how to patch holes in the ship lest it explode. The power management system was never added at all. Later updates would add NPCs that can patch the ship's hull, completely eliminating the need for multiple players. The Scarlet Spear event was supposed to add a squad-link functionality that would allow players to send each other benefits across multiple squads - a sort of multi-server buff synchronicity. Instead, it quickly became obvious that the system was obfuscating and fabricating this synchronicity - generating buffs from nothing, and doing nothing with buffs generated by players. The Heart of Deimos update was supposed to add a new open world centered around the game's zombie faction, with a complex ecosystem and new mission sets involving pilotable mechs a la Titanfall. Instead, it added an even smaller open world than the previous two, with more frustrating ecological mechanics, and tiny mechs that are (a) a giant grind to obtain, and (b) literally only useful in content that is gated off until you obtain one. Do you see the pattern here? Digital Extremes comes up with an idea, they market and sell that idea, then they present "content" that is at best a baleful shadow of what was promised. Angels of the Zariman takes this issue to its logical conclusion. Core to Warframe's gameplay is a duality between the Warframe equipped, and the Operator character used to control it. The player is encouraged to regularly swap between them in-combat; this system is meant to be quick, fluid, and flashy. Angels of the Zariman was supposed to make this system more fluid, give the Operator character more abilities and use-cases, and generally allow quicker and more convenient swapping between the two. Instead, it completely gutted the Operator's skillset, added a (frankly, bizarre) cooldown on swapping between Operator and Warframe, deleted significant amounts of player progress with zero rebate, and added *nothing.* Angels of the Zariman is the culmination of Digital Extremes' boneheaded decision-making over the years. At this point all I can assume is that it is intentional sabotage. The people in charge of the title must, I can only assume, have grown bored of working on the game and are now trying to drive enough people out that they can shut it down without breaching their contract with Tencent. Oh yeah, did I mention Tencent bought DE? Because they very much did - right around 2018, actually. But don't think too hard about that, friend. That'd be Sinophobic. EDIT: My hours have changed since posting this review. It is not because I have changed my mind, it is because I have failed.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: This is a bittersweet review for me. I've been heavily invested in this game three separate times with years-long hiatus between each stint. I've accumulated 1460.9 hours, the most of any game in my library and to be clear, I don't regret any of that time spent. Just a few weeks ago, I abruptly quit playing for the third time and this time I'm fairly certain I'm never coming back. Over the past few weeks I've been racking my brain, trying to understand how a game I love so much can make me feel so bad. I believe I've nailed down a few key points. THEORY CRAFTING The one thing I love most about this game spits straight back in my eye. Warframe has the most intricate theory crafting system I've ever seen. The problem is no one cares, nor does the game require them to care, nor do I think it would be possible to require them to care. By design, Warframe is hyper-prone to having ALL creativity mathematically optimized out. With every shot you take, brightly colored damage numbers and will pour out of your enemies. While the big colorful damage numbers are an effective addiction algorithm for most players, myself included, they're also an invitation for math nerds to cull every piece of equipment that isn't the best from common usage in the game. A player might spend countless hours reading every mod card, delving into different stats, and pondering synergies. They might enjoy building, testing, and optimizing something uniquely suited to a certain task and take pride in the engineering that went into building that piece of equipment. They might even strike gold every once in a while, and through deep understanding of the modding system and a little bit of help from RNG, manage to build a truly exceptional assault rifle, but there's a problem. The meta is AoE right now, not assault rifle. Effort and creativity are worthless in Warframe. You'll load into a mission with three other Tenno and your rifle which is fully capable of murdering massive hordes of the enemy, but you'll never touch a single one. Those three other Tenno are carrying explosive arrows or launchers and at the start of the mission they took off like a pack of greyhounds, greedily racing to get that rabbit before you. You might catch on to the competitive nature of an extermination mission and make sure that you also move with purpose, but there's another problem. With your single-target weapon, you'll actually have to aim at enemies and even if you've prioritized movement speed, you will never out run those explosive arrows. The lazily-aimed arrows will whiz past you, land on the ground in the middle of a horde, and everything within a 20m radius will be dead before you ever had a chance to use your creation. Not the best feeling when you're playing a horde shooter and there are no hordes to kill. Some may disagree, but I don't believe there is single mission type in this game that requires communication, teamwork, or specialization of loadout/role in any significant way. What that breeds is an insidious, copy/paste meta that enables players to kill the most enemies in the shortest amount of time, all for the reward of seeing that they did 99% of the damage on the stat page at the end of any given mission. This leads into my next point. WARFRAME FAILS AS AN MMO Another aspect of Warframe that I really love is fashion. You'll hear people say that fashion frame is the true endgame and I don't disagree. The game offers a dizzying number of color palates, stylish accessories, and ornamentation, all of which can be mixed and matched to the heart's content. The type of player who woke up in Skyrim and proceeded to agonize over their Dragonborn's facial features for hours before ever starting the game will be right at home in Warframe. You'll spend hours getting every emissive color combination just right, trying on accessory after accessory, weapon after weapon, applying skins, and even adjusting holster positions to look just right. You might even purchase loadout slots specifically for those frames you styled or pick up some miniature "warframe articula" (ball joint dolls) of your favorite frames that you can place around your ship. All of this really tickles a creative center in my brain that drives me to produce beautiful things to share with the world. The issue is that no one in this world is encouraged to look beyond their nose. Despite having 20mil registered users and common areas in the game that are bustling with activity 24/7, Warframe still manages to isolate me from my fellow Tenno. There are a couple different reasons for this. For one, the game has limited options for relaxed social interaction with random players. Yes, there's text chat, but it's clunky. Sometimes in an easier mission, you might see the occasional casual banter, but for most part when you're in mission, everyone is focused on playing the game, not interacting. You might think the common spaces I mentioned, where you'll find hundreds of roaming Tenno would be a better place for that sort of interaction, but you'd be wrong. If I like a Tenno's aesthetic and I walk up to them in Cetus, there is no slick way of giving them a compliment or striking up a conversation. There's no prox chat, so I'll never have the strange and unique experience of another player hearing me through a wall, striking up a muffled conversation and offering me some chicken because I was starving like I had in DayZ the other day. Perhaps most importantly, there are objectives to pursue in every single space within the game. There is no dedicated social space. Clans in this game are not about people you enjoy. They're about trading and collecting clan research to build new weapons, warframes, etc. The aforementioned common spaces in the game are merely jumping off points for the game's "open world" areas as well as a place to engage in mini-quests by engaging with the town NPCs. The point I'm trying to make is everyone you come across in one of these places has somewhere better to be. They didn't come to the common space to pay attention to anything other than the addictive objectives the game laid out for them. Standing in the middle of one of these spaces feels like walking the streets of NYC on a weekday. No one is relaxed and no one cares you exist. Warframe may technically be massively multiplayer, but it leaves me feeling massively alone, on my ship, surrounded by my stylish dollies. WARFRAME IS AN EXCEPTIONALLY EASY GAME You can try to do all your own theory crafting and tune out noise about the current meta, but at some point even the most unplugged player will realize how mind-numbingly easy Warframe is. The game cleverly disguises this with excellent mechanics, time-locked progression, and extremely low drop chances for certain items. This makes the game seem more difficult than it is, and indeed there is skill involved in mastering the mechanics, but at core, all one NEEDS to do is click on (or for AoE, click near) hordes of squishy enemies and occasionally press the 1,2,3, and 4 keys. Yes, enemy HP scales, but with a well-built weapon, enemies at all levels die on command for as many hours as you want to sit there clicking on them. Enemy damage also scales, but current meta survivability techniques make it easy for even newer players to become perma-invincible vs level cap enemies. At some point over the years, DE actually did make the game's enemies substantially weaker while simultaneously introducing items and systems that have pushed power creep to insane levels. Why DE would want to make an already easy game even easier boggles my mind. Add on top of all of this that 99% of the player base are using the most mathematically optimized weapons, frames, and builds, mindlessly copied and pasted from their preferred Youtuber and you have a recipe for sheer boredom that no amount of good gameplay mechanics can redeem. The game isn't all bad, but its endless, addictive gameplay loops ultimately have little reward.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: On the cusp of having 1,300 hours into this game that I have played since 2014, I cannot in good conscience recommend it to anyone looking for long-term playing. I just recently uninstalled and quit playing. Again. For the third time. This game is an absolute grind-fest. It was fun the first few hundred hours or so but at a certain point, it stopped being fun and started to become incredibly tedious. Mats and blueprints, mats and blueprints, don't forget the random alerts (dead) and definitely do your dailies. Every game became a mad dash as you and your teammates rush to finish the objective, find the few worthy material drops, and run frantically to the exit (RIP Ember's WoF). All of my favorite gear and weapons have been buffed and nerfed to hell over the years, yet I can manage to dole out tens of thousands of damage per second because of multiple formas and crazy riven mod builds. I just think it's another inconsistent and roundabout way to force players to grind even more for what they want to achieve. Most of the updates now a days add these crazy hurdles in the form of materials needed. At first it was the Dojo. Man, the time I spent gathering mats and building trivial stupid things like drums and plants. And now archwings, K drives, warframes and weapons; crafting these things all required the same thing: Every single hour of your life that you can afford to give, maybe even more. If I could buy my time back I gladly would, but I can't. I can only buy Plat. There are a multitude of issues I have with this game, but every time I think about Warframe I get so mad at myself for wasting so much time with it, I can't clearly think about the problems that I truly have with it. It runs deeper than me not liking the grind; it's very problematic and the main fanbase seems to be completely okay with that, but I just think that the game has run it's course. The past few updates have admittedly enticed me into coming back to play them, but shortly, the initial optimism is quickly snubbed as I begin to get that familiar feeling: I've been here before, I've done this grind before. It's the same grind for a different reason, just some new "rare" materials for a shiny new item. And as always, the end result is anticlimactic. Cool archwing collection you got there, its a shame archwing missions kinda suck. Oh hey cool, a giant space frigate. Oh wait I have to build it all by myself? What's the point of building this in the Dojo? I... just honestly don't know what else to say. I'm constantly at a loss for words whenever I try describe how I feel about this game. I wanted to be the ideal fan, I wanted to support DE every step of the way but I can't anymore. Every single person I have played this game with has left me in the dust and moved onto bigger and better things, and here I am typing my solemn farewell. So goodbye DE, farewell my dearest Loki. I have nothing left to give, and I am growing tired. Let me know when Warframe 2 comes out.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: 755 hours in and I love this game. The gameplay is top tier and after you get through the difficulty of learning the in game systems, it has so much depth and allows for so much creativity. However, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to potential new players. The on-boarding experience, while improved over the years is still pretty bad. They teach you the gameplay well enough, but then throw you into a frankenstein's monster of systems that they did not put nearly enough effort into explaining. There are also so many vestigial systems. As a new player, you might find yourself pouring in time to understand one of these bastardized systems to only to find out that it's out-dated and been unsupported for years. (looking at you archwings among other things) They really could stand to invest some time and money into improving the onboarding experience for new players. Clean up/remove unused systems, optimize the current ones and create worthwhile tutorials for them. New content is great for us who have played for hundreds of hours, but I feel like they would do themselves more good if they spent some extra time and money on the early game. There is a reason only 40% of players have gotten to the 2 hour mark of this game and this is the biggest reason why. I wish this was a game I could recommend to not only others on steam, but to my friend group. As it stands now, I cannot.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: Hi hello, I will try to explain to you how to approach this game. 1 - How the game progresses and where the problems begin; First 200 hours : Pure bliss, amazing game, the movement, weapons, warframes, quests the community and oh all this and that. It is genuinely great, very addictive. Pretty much perfect in every way. The progression is gated in a nice way, microtransactions are not predatory, you can even earn the premium currency without spending money! 200-500 hours : You begin to understand the game more, enjoy it on a more technical and nuanced level, so many cool interactions, great depth to everything. Maybe you even dip your toes into some "competetive" aspects of the game. You manage to spot some of the mistakes the devs made, not too many, but they still are there. You begin to become a bit jaded. 500-1000 hours : Many of the more intricate interactions between weapons, warframes, mods and operator, back of your hand. Second nature. You begin to notice how little the developers play their own game, spot more of their mistakes, maybe even try to do something about it. You truly start to understand where the problems lie, what should be fixed, what needs to change, or at least you think so. You start getting annoyed with the developers incompetence. 1000-2000 hours : You just keep playing the game, hoping that some things change, get better. You see the game fall apart into pieces, at this point you have absolutely nothing positive to say about the game. Try as you might, you will change nothing, the game you loved is no longer what it used to be. You see the community you once treasured turn toxic, overconfident and egocentric. 2000-3000 hours : You very well might have a good grasp on how the game truly works, and how truly broken and half assed it is. You begin to understand that the previous "horrible errors" are incredibly minor in comparison to the underlying issues that the game has. You see that it is heading off of a cliff, and nobody will do anything about it. You see the true colors of developers, their lies, empty promises, laziness. It dawns on you how far gone the game you used to play is. 3000-5000 hours : You truly see how bad it is, you compare the game to what it was yesterday and it only gets worse. Content getting removed, watered down. Players getting abused for just playing the game, gamebreaking glitches not being fixed and swept under the rug. You see how little they care. For me it was the end, and it will stay that way for good. The first few hundred hours got me helplessly addicted, I still long for the game I used to play way back then. And before some dimwit comes out and says something about "nostalgia goggles", its not that, it is not even remotely close to that. It has gotten progressively worse and worse as the time went on. The game got very empty, all of the challenge left, every aspect of the game got watered down. Everyone is a winner taken to an extreme. 2 - Who am I and how I played the game; Started out just like everyone else, casually having fun, scrubbing around. Best days of my warframe life. Fully captivated by the movement, scenery, story, basically with everything the game had to offer. It was great, loved every bit of it. The first day I put on 14 hours, the game had me. After I got done with the starchart, fully kitted out my favorite weapons and waframes, I searched for something more. At first, I found it. Enjoyed the speedrunning, even had a few world records for all that's worth. Cracked down on endurance runs, I ran a solo survival for 5 days, played the game till it broke. Literally, the game engine started dying. And here laid the very first problem. During my endurance adventures, I caught a few trade restrictions. I got banned from trading because of "unusual mission results", two week ban after every "unusual" mission. And those were not hard to come by honestly. This is the first game I have ever played that chastised players for playing it. Scoffed it off at first, whatever, right? I kept playing, doing my thing, sometimes even dipping my toes into the forbidden lands of The Conclave, which I began to enjoy tremendously. Then the decline started, status changes, warframe reworks and rebalances, newer operations, enemy rebalancing. After a certain point every single update I played was either a letdown, recycled or a net loss for the game. Pieces of the game started disappearing, skill ceiling was getting lowered, the community started getting toxic. Past a certain point I could extract no more enjoyment from PvE, they took it ALL away. So I moved on, PvP. I loved it, played the fuck out of it. It had its problems, but hey, we made it work. WE. The community is truly great, knowledgeable, charitable and willful to help out. So I got hooked again, ground out the skills, got really good. At my peak I was one of the best in the period I was playing, and a very good player when it came to the overall gamemode. I helped others get their feet off the ground, made them enjoy the game with me. So many great people I met there, and a lot of them I will miss from this day onwards.To whom it may concern, if you are reading this, you know who you are. I want to thank you for every game we played together, and all the moments we spent in annihilation. You are a part of my life that I will never forget. Thank you so much.Even though the gamemode was not popular at all, we had around 100 people playing actively, some of them INCREDIBLY skilled, professional quake players, top 10 aimers on Kovaaks, insane players. If you could bear the bad balancing, incredibly high skill ceiling, you had an amazing experience that was never and will never be replicated anywhere else. A great arena shooter with amazing flow, movement, feel. It was by far my favorite game ever, and it will always be. But oh well, when it comes to warframe, all good things need to end at some point. Even though the gamemode at this point was not being actively worked on by any developer, not even the one or two that were assigned part time. PvE changes bled through and broke it, shield gate, melee block, falloff bugs, imbalanced EHP warframes, and oh so more. Some weapons went from fine, to dealing damage that could kill the tankiest warframe 5 times over. It was all in shambles now, everything. No game left undisturbed by the telos boltace ragdoll, wolf sledge instakill AoE, tigris prime crossmap oneshots. No game left untouched by the horrible melee 3.0 system that completely broke all melee weapons, shieldgating completely ruining the whole dynamic of the game. Piece by piece, yet again, the game I loved was being torn apart. But I did not want to let go, I continued. We would deal with it like we used to, right? We could manage the exploiters back in the day, shouldn't be much different now. But I saw faces fade, people leave, friends fall out. It was too much, even for them. But I continued, I wanted to uphold it. I wanted to show people that this gamemode is something worth playing, and fighting for. I took it upon myself, I even made accounts to fight off recruit conditioning bullies picking on MR0 firstcomers, goddamnit made a whole clan dedicated to it. Made communities around it, I really wanted to make it work. This was my last stand, the last thing that kept me playing this godforsaken game. Alas, after some time it was enough even for me. I took a break, and today I came back from it. To see Conclave in a state even worse than it was left at, the fps issues worsened, freezing grew more frequent. It was the final straw. They did it, for the second time now. Ruined it all. This time without even trying at all. Today is the last day. Keep in mind, there still are more problems, but sadly the character limit hit. So, should you play it? No. Not for long anyway, take the first 200 and run far away.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: As a player who has actually played for a long time (MR26, almost 27 before I quit, all frames, including Primes except Excal Prime), and who has spent money into the game for Tennogen, I have to say that at the end of the day, I really cannot recommend this game to anyone out there who seeks to play it. On the surface, the developers seem to be nice people who listen to the feedback of the players, and there seems to be a relatively welcoming community free of toxicity. But look past this gilded surface, and you start to see the problems that actually plague this game. Firstly, it is obvious enough that the developers are trying to market this game in a revolving door fashion. You go in, play, get everything, get bored and quit. The crap about "Fashionframe is end game" and "just play your 3 hour survival for challenge", it is really a terrible way to retain players as there's no tangible reward for attempting to perform above and beyond. You reach the end of the content soon and the game soon turns into nothing but endless grind to upgrade many weapons which are just slightly adjusted stat tweaks of each other in different skins. The Devs do not care about long time players who have put many hours of effort into the game, as an actual fact. They want these players out of the game and all the plat and other bought resources to rot away in their accounts, so plat and rivens are taken out of circulation, while hoping new players will come in and pay. Secondly, the way the devs devalue player efforts by making excuses that the game is always in Beta and the Riven System is subject to change. Rivens are as a whole an end game chase for the bored players who have nothing to do. It gives them something to farm for, in the form of Kuva, to always try and push the stats a bit higher. But when dispositions and adjusted, all the hard work put by veterans into the rivens vanish overnight. Weapons should never be balanced by popularity, but by actual power. Also, when frames or guns which are released strong to attract plat sales, but later nerfed to make way for the new release, it's no different from power creep, except disguised. You don't make the new deal stronger, you make everything weaker. The frame reworks as well, forcing players to keep up with forma use as a poor effort at player retention, it isn't something that should be welcome. Thirdly, much of the content turns out either to not cater to the player base, or ridiculously buggy and unplayable. The Story Quests turned out to be full of problems on release, while game modes like Arbitrations and Sanctuary Onslaught were plagued by similar problems. There is no pre-release testing by a proper team of testers, and instead they depend on players testing the game. Do you all see the logic in this? People are paid to test games in general as Quality Assurance, but why are we as players paying either with time or money to test the game for Digital Extremes? Rather than enjoy working content, why must we earn working content? The obsession with pumping out new content also leaves many old pieces of content unfixed and buggy, with the logic that they will eventually get around to it. It's been years, though, and the only things they fixed were "wonky calculations" that allowed weapons to do more damage than they were supposed to. Or rather, nerfs are hidden as bug fixes ... while some bugs are simply turned into features. Digital Extremes only fixes what is convenient to them to fix, not what needs fixing. Fourthly, the community of Warframe isn't as nice as its silvered surface would suggest. Many within blindly defend the choices of Digital Extremes, but constitute a minority who drown out the voices of the other players who may have suggestions to improve the game. They only believe that Digital Extremes can be right, and they decide that they may dictate how the game will be played. It doesn't require a visit to the Warframe Forums to know of this. You'll spot the white knights shouting down all other players wherever there is criticism of the game. You may just be saying I'm some player who is salty about my toys being taken away, but I counter this by saying that I paid for the toys with my time and money. You can as well if you were willing to put in effort, and I am sure many long time players have the same experience as me. As a long time player of the game, who has provided steadfast support over quite a long span of the game's existence, I believe I have at least the right to voice my opinion about what's going wrong with the game and why I left the game. Too long, didn't read? Basically the Devs give jack about their real supporters and don't care. Nobody listens to longtime players and we are treated as trash to be taken out. Don't fall into the same trap and waste the same time as I wasted on this atrocious game made by people who don't give a damned about you.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: Review from a veteran player. (6 years played so far) After playing for long I just can't recommend this game anymore mainly because of this reasons: They don't care about keeping players into their game, they just care about new players; evey patch note, every hotfix, every big mainline update is about new players. YES! I know its a business and they need to have people interested in their game but hey 6 years and every update is dedidacated to them for us vets what is there for us to do? NOTHING, there is no endgame, we used to have raids but hey they removed those so yeah... "O hey but fashionframe is endgame"... dude for real just stop saying that its not funny anymore. We were promised something close to and endgame and that was sanctuary onslaugh BUT HEY they made it so new players could play it as well and... yep in the end it turned out to become a place where you lvl up your stuff... DUDE WE ALREADY HAD THE METHODS FOR THAT!! Kuva lich system came out but NOP don't think that this system is endgame, you only get to either kill you lich to get a weapon with bonus elemental damage (the bonus % is rng...) or you convert your lich to help you in battle (if you do this you get an ephemera) and thats it... why would we grind hoping to get the weapon we want with that 60% elemental damage, just to grind AGAIN for the relics to grind AGAIN to get the mods for the parazon just to keep doing "tryal and error" again and again and again and again and again... Warframe nowadays just adds more grind and more rng on top of the OTHER layers of rng and grind that we already had to compensate for the lack of content. O whats that you are a new player and you just want to play the new railjack content? welp too bad for you you need to wait 12 hrs for each part to finish "o and how many parts?" 6. YEP! you have to grind for all of this NEW resources that they introduce every big update so yeah have fun in getting your own railjack after all of that. "o but that means you didn't farm for it and you are complaining about warframe just because of this" nop, I did grind for it, I experienced railjack and burning tides since day 1; one of the worst experience I've had in a video game so far... no joke trully atrocius. Railjack is a buggy mess its a rushed content that was only release because of the hype of game awards... I don't care that NOW they are adding hotfixes, they had the time to work for this and the fact that they released it this way... just no dude... its a joke even from the point of view of a business model its just dumb... no one would have take the decision that they took. Another reason why I don't recommend this game its mainly because of an epidemy... WHITE-KNIGHTS. DE tends to listen to this part of the community, and why? welp because they won't criticize the game they always say that "waframe is perfect, warframe has no flaws"... sure buddy just look at how warframe is not in the top 10 of steam anymore lul. And for those thinking "o you are just burned out" no... I'm not... I have been playing warframe constantly, the thing is Its hard for me to keep up with so much BS from the community and devs alike. Now its true, I should have more hours after 6 years of playing 4k+ at least but I started playing Warframe when I was about to enter college and yeah I have been very bussy since then. And lastly why I don't recommend this game? welp cause trade chat. (I won't put more arguments for this after all its not worth it anymore...) If you have a time machine, go back to 2015 and play the game after all, those were the glory days. Since plains of eidolon came out all went downhill in terms of content release, mayor bugs, unpolished updates, etc etc... So long story short, I can't recommend a looter shooter that has the "bad kind of grind" to keep itself releveant. The grind in this game its not rewarding at all, you just grind because its there and thats it... Now whats left for Warframe in 2020? idk and I don't care I just lost the small light of hope that I had for this game, the game has potential but thats it, till this day devs decide to leave it like that "its has potential" and then... that "potential" stays there... they just leave it there and add more stuff on top of it... yeah they add potential on top of more potential. Am I quitting warframe? Idk, but I'm sure that I won't be spending money even if I have a discount or the money to buy a tennogen item, I just don't feel like supporting this game anymore. I might play it or maybe I won't I just dont know anymore... remember when warframe used to laugh at destiny 2? yeah... me too kid... me too...

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: I've been playing this game on and off in the last decade ever since the game was available to public. Every once in a while, I'd hear about the game having a huge update and would come back, just to play for a few weeks and quit wondering why I even bothered at all. And that's the problem with this game which made me find it hard to recommend the game at all. Having the grind at its core, Warframe over its course has been updated with systems upon systems that require you to grind for the sake of the grind. There's not really any content challenging enough that you HAVE to bring that maxed out shiny frame with five-times-prestiged weapon to. It's a game about mindless slaughtering hordes of trash mobs and that's just all fine and dandy. But constantly adding content to a game bloated with 10 years worth of content is no small feat, much less tweaking older content to a good spot alongside that effort. And my heart goes to the developer, they've tried really hard, but the longer it goes, the more obvious that the developer got into way over their heads and are gradually utilizing more and more tricks to force people to play their game all the while buying time for their next update by making the grind as obnoxious as possible. Had I written this review before November, I probably would have left a Recommended review with some caveat, but the latest blunder that the developer committed has pushed me off the edge into the red territory: the Aya system. No amount of 75% off for next platinum purchase coupon can fix this. For those who aren't familiar with the game, Warframe has a plethora of weaponry in the form of titular warframes and weapons that you can use to commit war crime in space. There are regular weaponry, and then there are Prime weaponry. Prime warframes are just normal warframes but shinier and has a different look. Prime weapons are often straight up upgrades. These prime weaponry are available for a limited time before they are "vaulted" where they can no longer be organically obtained. When a prime item is not vaulted, you can do various ingame activities to obtain relics that contain those prime items, then you have to open relic in a lootbox manner to obtain those items. Each item has several parts, some are common, some are rare. When a prime item is vaulted, these relics no longer drop. A little bit of history, before this relic system was in the game, prime items could be obtained as reward from a specific series of maps called the Orokin Tower where you can use a key to get access to, there were 4 tiers and the higher the tier, the higher the part rarity. The reason why the relic system and the vaulting procedure was introduced was because the developer wanted to avoid a diluted drop pool, as they were introducing new prime items faster and faster, and you can understand why having 60 different items each with 3-6 parts dropping from 4 missions is a bad, bad idea. Cue the Aya system update, an event where instead of relic drop, the in-game activities will drop Aya which the players can use to exchange for the relics that contain the parts of a prime item the player want instead. That means that the entire vaulting system where they wanted to adopt to avoid diluting the drop table was completely fixed. One would think that that's a positive thing. And it is. Except the developer implemented it as a one off event and still designed it around a Fear Of Missing Out. In this event, all the relics that contain vaulted items can be obtained again, but only 2 weeks for each set of item, and only for a few weeks. This has been the developer's modus operandi for years. They introduce a system that's ridden with problem, people complain and put up with it, until they can't anymore and the developer finally caves and starts working on changes. Meanwhile they make use of FOMO to keep players playing, buying time for their next big thing and be showered in praise for doing one good thing after a series of barely comprehensible decisions. The latest changes regarding nerfing the massive material sink in the Helminth system, the frankly annoying releveling process while a player forma an item, the new player experience, etc... (which are all too long to explain) are all results of years of players and reviewers such as Josh Strife Hayes and Brozime complaining about how absolutely unfriendly to the player they are. I love the core game to death, it has just the right gunplay and the movement system. They have a wonderful foundation, but everything that they built around it is ugly, clunky and just minimally functional enough to keep the game together and for the players to play while they work on fixing it 5 years down the line. And that's not too mention the predatorial business practice which has never manifested itself as clearly as the latest Regal Aya controversy, which they so shamelessly lied through their teeth about before backpedaling and implemented the changes to appease the player base. Frankly at this point I don't recommend playing the game. People tell you this game will consume so much of your time as if it's a good thing. I'm here to tell you it's not. If you play this game, you'll be playing just to get mad at a system being completely backwards and inconvenient, yet keep playing anyway because "maybe they'll fix it soon, they just fix X system last update, give them some time" and/or "if I don't play right now and get these stuffs I'll have to pay an astronomical price for it later when it's not naturally obtainable anymore". If you really REALLY want to play the game, go ahead, but I wouldn't recommend investing too much of yourself into this game.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: I have a severe love hate relationship with warframe, it’s a long read tldr at the bottom I’m a “grandmaster founder”, I’ve been playing off and on since the beginning of 2013 and I’ve seen just how different the games changed for better and for worse. You play in third person, as a warframe a “space ninja” where you kill everything in your way with a ton of different weapons or abilities as you chase the green finish line mark on your map, this gives you loot, you use the loot to craft more toys and the process repeats; this can either be done solo or with up to three more people for a total of four. To keep this relatively simple here is what I like about warframe • Warframe’s art is unique and many people spend huge amounts of time coloring their gear, between picking a frame, what three weapons it’ll use and then what it’ll wear almost turns into a dress up game all on its own. The levels look great and get better each time the dev’s take a look at them usually adding new effects and rooms to fight in. The enemies you fight (while kinda stale) all look good and can be cut into pieces, burnt to ashes, melted, electrocuted, smashed into the distance or frozen which while not anything groundbreaking, does lead to some memorable moments. • Warframe’s combat is fast paced and varied in what you can use to fight your way through hordes of soldiers, robots, or space zombies. Jumping ahead at what feels like 60 mph to swing a great sword at the head of some poor sob never really seemed to lose its appeal. • Warframes payment scheme is mostly pretty forgiving, you can earn things in-game by working for them, if you want them quicker there’s always the option of tossing some money at the screen. Unfortunately these two areas are all that really shined for me, some things to think about before you jump into the game. • Warframe hardly ever tries to explain itself to new players. A game where the wiki is more helpful than the tutorial. Fortunately the community loves to take newer players under their wings. However when new mechanics are introduced the players are on their own to figure it out or get help from other players who simply took the punches. • Warframe is a grind that can wear down players pretty quickly depending on what their goals are. If you happen to like the wrong weapon you may be in for some punishment while you pray to the RNG gods for the right key to get that last piece with a drop rate of 0.12%. Looking at recent additions, attitudes and past experience points towards this grind only getting worse in the future. • The Dev’s for warframe (D.E.) are very fickle to put it politely. They’ll add something great only to muddy it up with ill thought out details or what feels like a rushed job. A recent example would be a new gun, the Hema, which is costing years’ worth of resources to build in an attempt to drain the player’s stock piles or force them to pump currency into the game to bypass this. On one hand stockpiles need to be drained so your players don’t chew through new content too quickly. On the other hand there are better ways of doing this than with a swift kick to the teeth. D.E. will leave the gun as is until sales drop, and then they’ll adjust the costs to avoid the community’s ire. This has happened numerous times and for some including me, these practices intentional or not are a turn off. If not for their excellent community manager Rebecca this game would not be where it is today with the way DE does things. • If you’re a solo player you will put out more effort and time for less pay off than a group of four players who do less yet gain more, many times an event has happened and it’s been impossible for solo players to even attempt due to bad design (which is thankfully hotfixed in a day or two). Warframe is made as a co-op game; it only allows you to solo as an option so keep this in mind if you have a bad internet connection. • Warframe is FILLED with forgotten mechanics and half assed ideas that were all left to rot. Heres a list within a list of some of these. 1. Clans 2. Archwing 3. Codex/Scanning 4. Syndicates 5. Relays 6. The focus system 7. Channeling 8. Invasions 9. Solor Rails and solor rail conflicts 10. Operators 11. Raids 12. Rivens 13. Rathuum 14. Soon to be: the infested room • Warframe has little to no balance to it. The newest guns will almost always be among the strongest to drive sales. This eventually phases out old favorites since they simply can’t function well enough in higher level content. A majority of the weapons in warframe have ended up as garbage thanks to power creep TLDR Is warframe a good game? Yes it is, you can see a lot of work and passion goes into it, unfortunately this is muddied by the devs themselves with their decisions and the way they handle things. I actively warn people about warframe so I cannot “recommend” it. 2016 was a bad year for Warframe and the future dosen't look too promising either.

description: Awaken as an unstoppable warrior and battle alongside your friends in this story-driven free-to-play online action game
name: Warframe
review: "Would you recommend this game to other players?" - After 2000 hours, no. The game has been available for ten years, every argument pro and contra has already been made. So for brevity's sake I'll reduce it to those four points most important to me: 1) The random number generator day-one frustrations are the same on day-one-hundred and day-one-thousand. Yes, you don't have to pay for anything with real money, but you pay with your time. DE once stated that they never wanted it to be a slot machine, but that's what it is. The majority of time is spent on you pulling the lever over and over (most prominent example being Rivens). That is the core mechanic. Not jumping and shooting, but chance. 2) The incremental release "game as a service" business model means you cannot ever know what you're getting, and the direction the game is developed towards is infamously inconsistent. My read has always been that this was intended to keep the developers engaged, so instead of them leaving to work on a spaceship game, or a Souls-like, or something with mechs, DE just squeezed a poorly-made version of those other games in here. I understand that Warframe as-is has successfully financed the company, and that the following would have been unwise from a business standpoint for DE, but tying up the game a few years ago and instead starting clean with a "Warframe 2" that has a clearly defined scope would have made for better products. Warframe does one thing very well, and a million things poorly. As another consequence of its historical growth, the game is full of (semi-)abandoned or just poorly aged content, in some cases so crude that you can't show it to anyone because it makes the whole game look bad. The years of difference are painfully visible. Players engaging with new content first (e.g. Duviri wyrm boss) and later encountering old content (e.g. Sergeant, Tyl Regor, Phorid, etc....) must feel like they've accidentally stepped into a different game - essentially, they do. There's no incentive for DE to invest time into reworking this old content, so there's a built-in "culture shock". 3) The core gameplay soon becomes completely monotonous because a) waves of uniform enemies run towards you in a straight line, to ineffectively fall over dead, and b) because most missions are not structured - there's just randomly connected rooms and hallways, with enemies spawning from thin air, and once you have pressed the button you are supposed to press or killed enough enemies to reach a certain counter, you just run towards the end of the random chain of rooms to finish the mission. But for a few exceptions (like Kuva Fortress Assault), most missions have no story, no stakes, no structure. 4) The story as of recent years. This is what did it for me. Warframe had sparks of brilliance when it comes to sifting stories out of the rich and engaging lore they have built up over the years. For example, the twist introduced in The Second Dream works incredibly well. The narrative highlight for me was The Sacrifice, genuinely one of the most satisfying stories I've seen in a videogame. But that was released in 2018. Beginning with The New War, it all crashed and burned. Using "parallel dimension to the rescue" (Eternalism), "none of it is real you just made it up, none of this matters" (Duviri), teasing big events just to skip over them entirely (New War), and inconsistently reintroducing characters (Erra, Vor) has made the narrative so thin and weak, that there's no clear threat, no clear motivation, just a tangled mess of storylines that slapped against the void-wall at full speed. Warframe is a huge sunk cost fallacy. There's a kernel of a fantastic action game with a grand sci-fi story in there, but it's buried under layers and layers of grind, distractions, meaningless time-sinkholes, and unfinished dead ends. That's the most frustrating part about it - everyone who gets deeply into it will have dozens of ideas on how to fix it - because it's obvious that it needs fixing, and that there's something there worth saving.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: Since Curse of the Dead Gods, I'm a big fan of this studio. I like their Mignola-esque art style, the enemy design, the pacing of combats, their sound design, and OSTs. CotDG became my favorite Roguelike. There's a lot to like in Ravenswatch, mostly the diverse characters/playstyles available, but I want to give an honest review about the CURRENT STATE of the game. I might switch it to positive at the end of the EA period, but right now I'm frustrated and I don't want to lure potential buyers like a fanboy. To put it simply, I think the game needs at least 3 times its current amount of content to feel like a complete, satisfying game and/or proper Roguelike. They've been creative with the open-world roguelike formula; I admire that even if the UX is a bit poor, but I can't help myself but feel I'm playing the first 20% of something that should be massively bigger. It's quite fun to play, but in some way, it plays/feels like an online Diablo-like, and if you consider all the similarities with that genre, it terribly suffers from the comparison. The progression system is very limited, and the gameplay lacks depth. There's barely anything to unlock, and in two games, I feel I've seen nearly everything I could learn about a playable character. What a shame. As I said earlier, I love their core concepts, but the experience of playing them lacks depth and variables. Playing the nameless hero from Curse of the Dead Gods is more satisfying, diverse, and deeper than all the characters I tried from Ravenswatch. In Ravenswatch, I can just spam the same combos over and over, more or less. It's very repetitive, I don't have to think that much about the fights or the builds. CotDG was much more thinky than that. The other non-negligible problem currently is the fragility of the matchmaking. There are dead hours where you wait forever (without any feedback) to find teammates. You don't even know which settings you should select to increase the odds of the matchmaking. So you're forced to use the discord to find some players currently available to play on the difficulty you want. It sucks, and I suspect it will get worse halfway between the major updates. Yes, it can potentially improve, but the truth is that it's annoying RIGHT NOW. My suggestions for the future of this game: This game doesn't need new characters. It needs depth and real variety. I checked the roadmap and based on CotDG's lifespan, I suspect the studio doesn't have the funds to support the game for multiple years of content, which is unfortunate because the game aggressively needs more content. This is why I honestly believe additional characters should be (should have been) DLCs while the content updates remain free. This is the only way I can see Ravenswatch reaching its full potential. And yes, I would pay for every DLCs because these devs are good. It's just that the game needs A LOT more to keep the players engaged. Buy the game only if you want to support the dev team. Don't buy it thinking you'll get a solid gameloop that will keep you engaged for a while. It's not there yet.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: I played solo for a bit and got my first impressions. What feels good - The visuals and sounds are top-notch — shoutout to those artists for absolutely nailing it. - Combat and controls are smooth and responsive. - The dark atmosphere and the overall vibe are authentic and unique, which is one of the most sought-after features. What feels weird/bad - A ticking timer does not contribute significantly to the fun, as when it runs out, you get immediately teleported to the boss. Your time is always ticking no matter where or what you are doing, except if you are on the map menu. So there's really no room to safely consider your options. Picking up an upgrade? Pick it up quicker as you're on a timer. Considering items in the shop? C'mon, move already, time runs out. - I still have no clue what recovering the black raven statue does. Everything stays the same visually, and no explanation is given, or I missed something. - There's no point in breaking down surroundings - tables, barrels, boxes, etc. - as, sadly, there's not even a tiny loot from it. - I played almost exclusively with Snow Queen, and it felt rather punishing. She's slow and clunky, though she might wipe the entire packs of mobs if positioned well. Some mobs (like fat worms with ray attack) may get you no matter how skillful you move, rendering you unable to avoid the attack. - The boss fight is so frustrating. It's nowhere near the feeling of boss fights in Curse of the Dead Gods, where bosses present a solid challenge, but their patterns are well-readable, and they're totally beatable. Even with destroying a tumor and reducing the boss's HP by 20%, I couldn't get it close to being defeated. Sometimes, I had a feeling of getting killed w/o noticing what hit me. Regular tendrils hit hard; the central tendril one-shots you. Plus, you need to dodge bullets, lightning bolts, and ground attacks during the fight. It's not fun and feels too much for the first boss, especially with a hero like Snow Queen. - Adding some condition icons or other visual cues to enemies with chilled status would be great. Playing Snow Queen revolves around chilling and shattering enemies, which requires you to distinguish visually who's chilled to attack/shatter them effectively. And those tiny little snowing animation isn't enough, obviously. - Cooldowns for skills should be stated in the skill description. - From what I've seen, there are just a few upgrades, just differing in order. Even though there was only one character in Curse of the Dead Gods, the variety of weapons adds to replayability and the feeling of interesting, fresh runs. Here, it starts feeling samey pretty fast. This is crucial since that's what makes roguelikes like The Binding of Isaac a timeless classic — its variety of possible item/skills/set/trinket combos. You can play for 100 hours and then suddenly get surprised with something unexpected and exciting. And it goes on and on for every room you enter. - I tried the beta branch to see the next chapter and after defeating the boss and choosing to go next, the game has closed. So there's not much to see here for the given price. Hopefully, all the bad will be refined, and the game gets better.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: After finishing the first boss I feel I must leave a negative review, though I wish there was a in the middle option. I just want to reiterate what other players have said already in hopes the devs will see this. Having the timer not stop during upgrades or at shops is such a hindrance to my experience. I love creating builds but feeling rushed while doing so is just really unfortunate. I also wish the timer would pause while talking to NPSs/at shops. I don't mind the timer mechanic as a whole but I really hope they update it to pause during those above instances. If that were to be changed I would be recommending this game wholeheartedly to all my friends in an instant. I love the game though and will continue playing it for many hours to come regardless. But it has such potential and I hope some QOL features are added in the future and if so I will gladly change my review to a positive.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: The September 7th update came filled with nerfs, and anti-QoL gameplay changes that make it so I cannot recommend this game as of right now. The game previously was difficult on it's own, even still it felt rewarding if you somewhat planned how you approached each run. Now each run feels if anything doesn't go in your favor your entire run is screwed. This is a pretty souring experience. If the devs make the game better again i'll update my review but for now stay away.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: I think the overall gameplay is fun and the characters are different enough to make each one feel unique when playing through one vs another. But I think outside of saying you completed a run as a certain character, there isn't much reason to playing further. I think the game needs a better reward system and progression loop. As you level up each character, you unlock new abilities that you can possibly get in the next run, but there's no guarantee those abilities will actually be better than the old ones. So you just have a larger pool of possible perks with no way to really pick the ones you want. In fact, if you like the lower level skills, your odds of getting them become less and less as you level up as the pool gets bigger and bigger. I feel they should incorporate some things that other similar games have already incorporated. Maybe passive stats that you can permanently unlock, or the ability to reroll or banish unwanted skills. Basically, I feel they need to add something into the gameplay loop to make you feel that by upgrading your character overall, you might have an advantage on your next run over your previous run. And you should also feel that by getting far in a given run offers a tangible reward over a much shorter run that will help you in future runs. It's the kind of mechanic look forward to the grind and keep trying. If after your 20th run you're not really any better off than you were in your first run, it kind of disincentivizes me from looking forward to the next run, let along a long grind. And maybe by adding passive upgrades, that means they need to make further stages harder to balance out later stages to keep up with the fact that players will be getting stronger the longer they play. But at least then, they will have reason to want to keep playing. This game has some really good things going for it and I hope they can add something to the gameplay loop to really make it take off.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: I'm not here to talk about the lack of content or bugs due to it being in early access, I've come here to talk about one crucial thing. (Get rid of the damn timer that forces us into the chapter boss fight) So the gameplay is good, the couple characters i played felt good. The overall gameplay loop seems like it would be really fun, but the 1 thing that makes me not recommend the game and it's a completely biased reason so take this review with a grain of salt. It's simply the fact that you are on a timer and when that time is over (which is a really short timer) you have to fight the chapter boss, there's no way around this. so unless you play sweaty af you are probably going into the boss fight under leveled. you have a relatively large map to scour, albeit, with waypoints at your disposal. I guess my gripe with this mechanic is that you don't get anytime to actually enjoy playing the game, hell even every time you level up and try to make a choice with the ability power up you want the timer still ticks down? like why??? its idle time. I'm forced to play this game a speed that is not enjoyable at all. Please get rid of this timer, keep the day night cycle, just get rid of this timer... let us initiate the boss when were done with the map to proceed to the next chapter or however its going to work, let me enjoy this game at my speed....

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: Stop charging people for one level immediately. Open a demo or a free early access. Devs these days love shooting themselves in the foot. What would be an amazing game will now vanish from first impressions alone.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: Absolutely loved this game when it came out, but the shores of the storm island patch ruined the game. They reduced the time you had to collect items and now the boss is way too hard. Previously we had reached nightmare 9 and now playing on normal we never made it to the new content. I hope the next patch makes the game fun again, but as is I wont be playing it again.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: Game is more like a demo, only one map and one boss. One run takes around 25 min. Not recomended at this price with this content.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: Recent patch was just a bunch of nerfs, also you'd think after so many failed attempts of a timer mechanic developers would stop using it, not these developers though, they decided to make the entire game revolve around a timer mechanic meaning you need to speedrun at all times. What makes it worse? The developers reduced the timer in the recent patch by 25%, you now need to speedrun it even faster. The developers are actively trying to kill the game, they're doing a damn fine job of that. Edit: So now the developer has resorted to insulting players as you can clearly see in the response to this review, "We understand that you find the game difficult with the timer mechanic"... excuse me? Want to make it any less obvious you're calling players that don't like it bad at the game? How out of touch can you be to think it's the difficulty that makes it bad, the problem is that it's simply not fun, not everyone wants to speedrun the game, in fact only a small percentage of people want to speedrun the game, the developer seems to think everyone is bad at the game, nah it couldn't possibly be that they're ruining the fun, not at all... Notice there was no response about all the nerfs? Notice how the response was just PR bullshit? The timer mechanic being so short might work if they stopped nerfing everything, unfortunately they're not even reverting the awful nerfs, the nerfs made the game less fun, but again, devs think difficulty was the only issue.

description: Fallen heroes of old folk tales and legends: you are on the verge of a crucial battle against the Nightmare invading and corrupting your world. A roguelike action game from the creators of Curse of the Dead Gods©, playable solo or in online co-op.
name: Ravenswatch
review: Though I've given this a thumbs-down at present, I'll note that I have it wishlisted despite having played it just shy of two hours and gotten a refund for now. The game overall is pleasant and enjoy the dark fantasy aesthetic paired with characters from classic stories and myth. At present in February 2024, however, it's still too unpolished to really be worth buying. You are dumped into the game without any tutorials or descriptions of what things do. It wasn't until I watched some videos on how to play online that I realized the healing wells not only heal you but raise your health level. The present gameplay design is a bit counter-intuitive. The way to play, as described in many videos, is to avoid the mobs all over the map in favor of getting the events that add skills and enhancements in the same way drops did in Hades. This means that, in a game littered with mobs everywhere you go, your objective is to ignore them instead of fighting them. So you have a combat game with combat skills that ideally involves... er... avoiding combat. The problem is that fighting mobs wastes the 20 or so minutes you have before the Big Bad shows up and you have to fight it. The result is that it becomes a fetch quest kind of play in which you're basically trying to gather up goodies while not getting pulled into fights. It's like a mix of combat without engaging in combat and stealth without any actual stealth. This problem is exacerbated by the Fog of War covering the map, meaning you're also supposed to explore to find the things you actually want while avoiding all of the mobs around you. It's a lot to do in 20 minutes. There will probably be many that enjoy this style of "F- around and find out" gameplay and that's totally valid. It actually is kind of interesting to kick the tires of this game and see what does what. But it can also leave you feeling pretty lost. It'd be nice if the developers could find a sweet spot between absolutely no real guidance and being led about by the nose in an annoying series of tutorial pop ups. Ultimately, it just feels like the game is a big mess with no real clarity as to what kind of game it's supposed to be.
