description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: I wanted to like this game. I loved Persona 4 Golden when I played that in 2020, but I felt torn when I played this game in late 2022. It’s not a case of the gameplay formula growing stale or me growing out of it, I played Persona 3 Portable for the first time ever in January 2023 when it had its Steam port released and I loved that too. It’s Persona 5’s writing and runtime that ruin it for me. First, Persona 5’s character writing ranges from alright to forgettable. None of it is necessarily bad, but most of it isn’t quite on par with P3 or P4, save a select few characters. This is just a minor issue though, as my real problems lie with the overall story. My second issue is with the writing for the game’s overarching story. The story in P3 and P4 aren’t incredibly groundbreaking, but they have their moments, and mesh well with the style of those games and their other systems. P5 definitely has the style, and even has a few interesting bits, but its story is just bad. It refuses to commit to anything, be it character deaths or even a conclusion to the game’s events, and it’s genuinely exhausting. Even this wouldn’t be too bad if the game had the 50 to 70 hour playtime range that 3 and 4 do, but this one clocks in closer to 120 hours. A lot of this time is consumed with menial filler, too. Animations that play too often or take too much time, too much empty dialogue that refuses to progress the story or develop the characters, the frequent traversing of Mementos (a required P3/P4 style dungeon with 82 floors and almost no actual substance), etc. With some cutting, Atlus could have made this game shorter, denser and honestly much better. I don’t hate this game. It has a fantastic soundtrack, and it has a lot of style. The gameplay itself is a huge improvement over P3 and P4. Unfortunately, its flaws weigh it down enough to the point where it’s hard to say I really like it, either. Overall, it left me with a foul aftertaste. Not because it’s irredeemably bad, but because it was so close to being good. I tried to go in with low expectations, but I still found myself annoyed at the game for these omnipresent flaws.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: Eeeuuuuurrrrgggghhhh Persona 5 is a thoroughly, extremely, excessively competent JRPG. What is good? The presentation is brilliant. The visuals - beautiful! Striking! Delicious! The soundtrack is delightful and fun (if lacking in variety considering the game's scope) The setting is pretty cool. It's a cute version of Tokyo, full of life and activity. What else is unique? Three things. First, the dungeons in this game take place inside villains' heads. You fight within their unconscious. A great idea! But most of the time this consists of fighting pumpkins and endless variations of sexy women with wings. The villains also each represent one of the seven deadly sins. As you can imagine, these different ideas - the unconscious, funny little odd creatures, and bad concepts from medieval Catholicism - don't match up. Second, you play up against a turn limit. Each day is divided between day and evening and you can take one main action in each. This could mean that you are tasked with making deliberate choices about which skills and relationships to prioritise. I started playing like this. But over time you realise that most of the time you do the activity with the person when they invite you, otherwise you do the skill that has a bonus right now. You can't push relationships forward much outside of this. There's not much to be gained from either optimisation (not needed) or specialisation (you can't. You're pretty much the same regardless of playthrough). Third, you fight with personas, which are a bit like Pokemon, and can merge them, sacrificing one in the process. The Persona menu is unwieldy, and collecting Personas doesn't work well, because you can only have a limited number at a time. And if you move too quickly through the menu then a character shouts at you, which got annoying. I got 30 hours in, up to the third dungeon (of 7 I believe) and I was tired of the core of the game. Everything else about it is *fine*. The characters are fine, the story is fine, the gameplay is fine, the dungeons are fine. But you can't spread mediocrity over tens of hours and create an engaging experience. The aesthetics can only take it so far. There are clearly lots of people for whom "RPG of average quality story & gameplay with brilliant presentation spread over 100+ hours" is appealing. There is a lot of game for your money. If that's your cup of tea you will like this! I feel like if I were younger, had less alternative choice, and hadn't read the equivalent of generic YA stuff many times this could appeal. But for me, it did not work. If I gave it a rating out of 10 it would be a 6.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: Well. I gave it a shot. While I love the style of Persona 5, the game feels like a miserable slog to me. Just under ten hours in, I defeated the first major boss and closed the first small story arc. I like the characters and the story is interesting. Despite that, I found myself blasting through dialogue out of sheer impatience. I know time is a theme of the game and mundane daily routines between action is another sort-of theme, but it made me care less about the good things in the game when I was spending 3-5 minutes clicking through dialogue that adds nothing to the story and just boils down to "Who do you want to get a +1 relationship point with?" or "Which stat do you want to go up by 0.1?" Nearly everything I've done so far has had one path to follow. If I even try to explore the world outside of that path a little bit, I get stopped by invisible walls and some dumb dialogue from my character like "I shouldn't go there yet" though my character usually has no reason to know they shouldn't go there. He's new in town and somehow already knows where everything important and unimportant is? Yet I still need to listen to 20 minutes of exposition, explanations, and tutorials between every decision point. Speaking of which, every decision point I've seen so far is a choice between: a. Hell yes! b. Well… OK c. Yes, but say something dickish for no reason There's just so much fluff. Nothing I do feels like it matters. I don't discover anything on my own. I'm dragged to every solution for every problem. The entire game feels like it's on a rail. Maybe later on I can lean in one direction or another and it might matter, but I have no reason to believe that based on my first 10 hours. I value my time too much to keep dumping it into this. I'd rather just watch an anime. It'll take much less time to get to the point and probably tell a more interesting story. So that's what I'm doing now. Watching other people play the rest of the game on YouTube.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: Game feels very dragged out. I didn't hate the story or characters, but I feel like there isn't enough meaningful gameplay or interactions. I liked quite a few of the character bondings but it's very bloated and you often spend a lot of filler time which makes a lot of the interactions lose a sense of importance. I wasn't able to drag myself to finish the game but the gameplay is too simple and repetitive for too long; even if I was slowly introduced to new mechanics I felt like so little of it mattered. The core gameplay mechanics themselves function fine, even if it is a bit simplified. But the day to day activities, bonding, and fusion mechanics are very tedious (example: needing to bring corresponding Arcana for bonding) and filled with trial and error (mostly fusions) to the point of wanting me to unleash my persona; P3 style. I feel if they just removed 80% of the filler days I'd enjoy a much more condensed experience. I also hate having to prioritize bonds between characters I am more fond of vs characters that have actual useful benefits as a game mechanic. I put off playing P5 for over half a decade because I felt like the game wouldn't fit me; turns out I was right. Although I know a lot of people enjoy the game. If you're looking for a very casual experience. TLDR: Game is a dragged out experience and tedious. AKA this game suck -Penesilio

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: Good game, a good port even. Wait until they remove denuvo or at least fix the way it's implemented because it ruins the game's performance. Freezes that take 5 seconds and insane fps drops in open areas that I didn't experience even with the ps3 emulator.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: Picked it up P5 to play on my steamdeck. The game itself is awesome but the DRM is shit. The game forces you to connect to the internet at random intervals, so when you boot it up it forces you to go online or not play the game. So if I want to play my SINGLE player game i need an internet connection. Cannot recommend because of that

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: no yusuke romance option

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: cant romance ryuji

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: Was troubleshooting game not working, and Denuvo locked me out for 24 hours. But piracy is bad, don't forget that.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: I love this game, it's one of my all-time favorite games ever. THAT BEING SAID, I immediately regret buying this version due to 1 thing: DENUVO DRM FUCK DRM, all it does is make the game THAT I BOUGHT harder to play. Currently, despite being Steam Deck Verified, the game DOES NOT work on Linux via Proton. It ONLY runs on the Steam Deck's SteamOS Linux distro. Denuvo also limits you to only being able to be verified 5 times per 24-hour period. Screw you if you wanna play 6 times in a day! Buy this game on PS4 if you can, the game itself is AMAZING (I've played it twice for 300+ hours on PS4) but the DRM ruins it on PC.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: I had a wonderful experience with the game, it's a masterpiece. But I can never recommend, encourage and support denuvo, or any kind of intrusive DRM. I will make sure to change my rating the moment they remove it.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: I suspect Persona is one of those series that the first entry you encounter ends up the one you enjoy the most. With that regard I had already played P4 on playstation 2 a few years ago and found that 5 just never managed to click for me. That's not to say 4 is a better game than 5, if coming in fresh it is mechanically a far better, smoother, and more interesting experience than 4, but I never felt as engaged in the stories or characters as I did in 4 (with exception to the great Sojiro/Futaba plots). One grinding annoyance throughout the playthrough is P5's seeming total lack of respect towards the player's memory, repeating every single piece of information 10 or 15 times just gets absurd across 80+ hours. I just never felt like the absurdly long length was worth it or earned.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: Loved Persona 4, maybe I've just changed over the years but this game feels extremely flat by comparison. The characters are pretty one note. I don't know why this game is so highly rated and I guess I never will, but if you enjoy it more power to you. Edit: Finished game, original opinion has largely not changed. The characters never really get interesting, the dialogue is laughably bad at times. Mechanically it's entertaining enough but aside from aesthetics it's really not all that special.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: It just feels like P5R improved every superficial element that was subpar in P4G (mainly in the presentation department) at the cost of elements that made P4G special. Yes, the dungeons are hand crafted set pieces now instead of P4G's corridor marathon, but they're still the same repetitive game-play loop of ambushing shadows and opening doors. The trivial puzzles that are occasionally sprinkled in hardly breakup the monotony. And in any case, P4G's corridors make a return in Mementos, only now longer and more monotonous than before. Yes, the combat and interfaces look flashier but the game is even more shy about presenting any kind of challenge than P4G. Yes, your new gang has some interesting moments but there are much less special events with them than in P4G, and there are so many monotonous dialogues about the rotten adults in charge that would surprise even the Kids Next Door. It doesn't help that most boss fights consist of equally monotonous monologues about how rotten they are. There's more problematic elements I could gripe on & on about: Yusuke's creepiness ("Pose nude for me or I'm calling the cops"), Haru coming in too late in the plot, Makoto & Futaba dominating the party too much, the fortune teller that predicts what your friends want to hear in exchange for money, etc. etc. Finally, P5R adds a third semester & while the main story of this extra leg is fairly compelling, there is almost nothing new to do here. It's "Go to the Gym or Jazz Club until the timer runs out" semester, because none of the other daily activities are worth doing at this point. Overall, it just feels like I spent 150 hours on an experience that would have been better if it lasted 40 hours. I don't doubt the skill & commitment dedicated to make this game, I'm just skeptical that the end result is still slight downgrade from Persona 4.

description: Don the mask and join the Phantom Thieves of Hearts as they stage grand heists, infiltrate the minds of the corrupt, and make them change their ways!
name: Persona 5 Royal
review: Did I enjoy Persona 5 Royal? Somewhat.Would I recommend it? No. Not when Persona 4 Golden exists. I had been excited to play P5R ever since I immersed myself in P4G. My biggest dissatisfaction with P4G was that the dungeons & combat were not enjoyable, but this was remedied by the fact that the main story intrigued me and I enjoyed the character-writing. Was it the best? No, but there were many moments where the characters felt believable. I enjoyed their interactions not just with you, but each other, thus making the game’s finale bittersweet. The big thing I kept hearing from fans of P5R was that it effectively 'fixed' the dungeon-crawling. I found that to not be the case. In fact, the dungeons and combat somehow became worse, and it all comes down to one factor: Quantity, not quality. P4G's dull, randomly-generated dungeons were tiring, but, the hand-crafted dungeons of P5R are twice as long in length per Palace. This, with the added factor of fights becoming extraordinarily repetitive because of the dungeon-size and lack of variation between encounters, caused me to need frequent breaks just to endure. This is especially frustrating when you learn after the first dozen hours of P5R that P4G's randomly-generated dungeons do exist in addition to the palaces, known as Mementos, a location that must be completed as part of the main story’s true ending. If the combat and dungeons aren't an issue for you, that means the main story and characters are still going to have that strong P4G charm, right? In my opinion, no. Had this been the case, I might have been forgiving like I was towards P4G, but this is where P5R became a deal-breaker for me as I reached the 60th hour: It was excessive. P4G's mystery-plot was enticing to me, because I couldn't really guess who the main villain was going to be until the big reveal. It was a fun shock, and it made the confrontation feel all the more satisfying when the party finally dished out justice. Meanwhile in P5R, I pin-pointed the masterminds as they were becoming apparent, which made the grand-reveals tiresome, since there was no room for any surprise other than the amusing payoff for the interrogation that follows the prologue. A fun moment near what could have been the game’s climax, only for the game to continue going for 30 more hours. What about the characters? Well? What about them? In my opinion, all of them are hollow by comparison to P4G's cast, and when I kept internalizing over this, I came to the conclusion that, unlike P4G's cast, you barely experience the lives of the cast in P5R. Sure, you social-bond with them, but I don’t feel like I’m learning more than what you infer from their presented tropes. They rarely do their own activities or bond with each other. Actually, one of the big missed-opportunities is the development of their Showtime moves, which is one of the only times you see these characters do anything with one another. By comparison, in P4G’s cast, several sections of the game are devoted to their enjoyment of doing fun shenanigans together outside of dungeon-crawling. It made them feel like real teenagers and not just a group of one-dimensional tag-alongs. Another factor that led me to this conclusion is that the characters In P5R feel like they are shackled to you. Wherever you go, they are there to spew their one or two lines of input, which leads to repetitive banter. When I think about a character like Chie from P4G, I remember the times she ruined nights with her cooking, or when she discovered that the easiest way to defuse Yukiko was to send her into spiraling laughing-fits. When I think about Makoto from P5R, I remember that… She’s smart? I don’t remember her favorite foods, and I only remember that her dream is to become police commissioner because she reminds you about that dream at the end of the game; something I completely forgot about by that point. She was also my romance-option, which …Speaking of, the last detail I will bring up is the romance. In P4G, the chosen partner you go with is not only prone to having moments with you throughout the story, but other characters react to your pairing. It wasn’t overly-done, but it was there, and I would argue more pleasant than what you get out of most RPG romances. In my P5R play-through, your pairing means nothing to the party and dialogue doesn’t change between you and the chosen partner. The only time I recall that your pairing has a tangible bonus to the story-telling are three moments near the end of the game. Your chemistry may as well just be pretend outside of these few moments. This should not be a big deal, but when one of the defining pillars of the Persona games focuses on the relationship between characters, I should think romance would, at the very least, match P4G’s detail. What I ended up liking from P5R were the little things. I liked the music, the setting tone (despite the weak plot), and the interface, which is fantastic. Even just the menu screens have a way of really hyping you up for the boredom you are about to undergo. I’m sorry if I seem harsh on the game, and I respect that a lot of people cherish it, but I just can’t ignore that P5R made me miss P4G more than I thought I would. I gave it a fair shake out of respect and stuck by it until it ended, but now I’d like to move on. Saying goodbye to the cast in P4G was tragic. Saying goodbye to the cast in P5R was a relief.

description: The world has been thrown into chaos, and it's up to you and your friends to battle the corrupted beasts of the Rotwood. Upgrade your gear, choose your preferred weapon, and hone your skills to defend your safe haven.
name: Rotwood
review: I really like the game and the gameplay, but not the direction they took since the original version (pre-2023 sept). The EA version feels like a dumbed down version of the old playtests (2023 june and sept). The pre-EA versions had better UI, better camp, better inventory system (camp chest), better crafting ohh and even an intro. Now there is no way to see your stats, to change your gear you have to run around the camp like a headless chicken, gear crafting was dumbed down, there are no sets anymore ... everything is just worse.

description: The world has been thrown into chaos, and it's up to you and your friends to battle the corrupted beasts of the Rotwood. Upgrade your gear, choose your preferred weapon, and hone your skills to defend your safe haven.
name: Rotwood
review: The only reason I wanted this game was to play with my friends but PROBLEM 1 arises when I play with friends my game data does not save I keep weapons and armor but not my levels my masteries reset and I just don't have fun when I realize I can play for over 2 hours but haven't made any progress. I have beat the tree boss 8 times now and none of them have counted. I have ran as administrator and tried multiple other fixes but still yet nothing changes when this is fixed for me I will let you know and if anyone else is having this I'm sorry.

description: The world has been thrown into chaos, and it's up to you and your friends to battle the corrupted beasts of the Rotwood. Upgrade your gear, choose your preferred weapon, and hone your skills to defend your safe haven.
name: Rotwood
review: No matchmaking queue. Gotta have friends to play this with or you're out of luck.

description: The world has been thrown into chaos, and it's up to you and your friends to battle the corrupted beasts of the Rotwood. Upgrade your gear, choose your preferred weapon, and hone your skills to defend your safe haven.
name: Rotwood
review: This game is good but the optimization is really bad. The occasional stutter and fps drops during online play is disappointing. Even during solo play the game stutters. I'll wait until they fix this issue if ever

description: The world has been thrown into chaos, and it's up to you and your friends to battle the corrupted beasts of the Rotwood. Upgrade your gear, choose your preferred weapon, and hone your skills to defend your safe haven.
name: Rotwood
review: While a fun roguelike game made by reputable developers, as it currently is the online matchmaking they're attempting to do is convoluted and unnecessary where it involves pinging discord users or requires a code to play with others. Instead of the simple yet effective random match making or having a hub to choose from in game. As other games have tried this and failed due to making it overly complicated to play with people I feel this one will fail as well. For a single player experience though or playing only specifically with friends willing to pick it up you'll enjoy it.

description: The world has been thrown into chaos, and it's up to you and your friends to battle the corrupted beasts of the Rotwood. Upgrade your gear, choose your preferred weapon, and hone your skills to defend your safe haven.
name: Rotwood
review: Have you ever played a game called "Rampage Knights"? It is just simple and fun. Your game is full of boring and meaningless tasks, less is more, right?

description: The world has been thrown into chaos, and it's up to you and your friends to battle the corrupted beasts of the Rotwood. Upgrade your gear, choose your preferred weapon, and hone your skills to defend your safe haven.
name: Rotwood
review: The loot grind to level up weapons and armor has felt very slow. It's a concerning sign of this game's content now and to come with how long it's taken for me to only partially upgrade any one gear set only to a mix of level 2 and base level 1 out of level 3 max. I got to Frenzy 2 of the first area in a couple hours, and I've spent 3 or 4 times that long to not yet get any of the first area armor and weapon sets up to full level 2 for each upgrade. And I've had to play Frenzy 1 of the first area probably 10 times just to get that far, as you only get certain items off the proper enemy tier, or from random item rewards that you might not even see on any given run. My Rillo helmet is 2 and 3, and legs are max, but my armor is still 1 and 1 because I just haven't gotten enough Rillo hides to upgrade it in about 7 or so hours of actual active game play time. My Yammo set is 1&3, 1&3, 2&3 with no upgrades to any of the weapons yet. Fortunately to beat Frenzy 0 of the second area, max base defense on the Yammo set and the fact I like the Claw spear that I have been able to get to 2&2 got me through Frenzy 0. I haven't crafted all of the decor yet that needs Rillo drops, only 2 and that was 1 Rillo drop each. There's still at least 1 more, and also tier 2 Rillo drops to take into account for armor, weapons, and decor first craft cores to buy other things. At least in something like Rogue Legacy, you start reliably bringing back stuff to upgrade every run, you feel the progress every run. You also have choices of farming the easier areas each run vs. taking on the harder areas first. Each run you can experience the harder content and learn strategies while still getting progress from the easier areas. This game, no, you want to level up with maximum chance to get the lower tier items, you will do the easy area, and only the easy area, that you're already crushing into oblivion again, and again, and again. I know the game is early access, and I didn't play Rogue Legacy until it was done, so hopefully things will improve. If not, I doubt my interest will last, which fortunately it's only $10. The combat is generally fun, and has the "Klei style" (if you can even say they have a brand style), polish, and bizarre excellence they usually show in every single genre they try is present in the actual combat mechanics. But the initial pacing looks like a game that will have X hours of unique content that takes 5 to 10 times longer to actually complete. I played a bit more after typing a lot of this up, wanted to look at a few more things. And trying out Frenzy 1 of the second area just felt very sluggish, especially the first boss, which isn't helped by being encouraged to be heavy or at least medium weight. And I feel I was close beating Owlitzer, but I can't just keep trying like Nioh or Dark Souls, gotta go back to town, run to the copter again, load up the stage again, fight through all the areas again. Thinking about playing it 15+ times just like area 1 Frenzy 1 to level up any gear I may want eroded away my desire to keep going through it. I felt maybe if I leveled up the Claw spear, maybe I could get enough damage boost to keep going, but it seems I have to farm at least Frenzy 3 for one of the items to drop, and the pacing is very slow to hopefully get 2 more of that item, and I'm prone to dying a couple sections in so far.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: I feel conflicted about this game so far and would rather give it a "neutral" review than either a positive or a negative one. I want to enjoy the game. I don't mind the silly level of writing, sometimes it's kinda refreshing to have something that I can just shut down my brain to. That part is not an issue for me. I don't mind that, for the most part, character stories are separated from each other. I always enjoyed games like SaGa Frontier, Live-a-Live and such. So that's fine for me. I really, really like the combat system. It's among the best turn-based combat systems in the genre, for me, probably only behind Gust newer turn-based games and maybe some of the Falcom games. And yet playing the game feels like a chore. Moving from one place to another means going through areas where you get a random encounter every 4 steps - or every 5 steps if you equip the skill that reduces the rate, barely any difference. This makes exploring the world and getting all those hidden chests and stuff, something that should be fun, become a drag. Worse, this makes the fun combat, that is the strongest point of the game for me, start to get tiresome. Yes, the combat is good - but facing the exact same enemy for the 300th time isn't. And when you do arrive in a town, there's around 15 people for you to interact with up to sixteen different field skills. Getting to a new town is a major "I'll stop here and continue later, too tired for that now" moment for me. Now, I'll fully concede that this is heavily due to my own playstyle - I could probably simply ignore the NPCs instead of interacting with all of them. So if you are not a completionist in wanting to see all the dialogues and descriptions and sidequests and such, you may ignore that last bit of complaint. For now, I think I'll set the game aside and wait for a mod that reduces encounter rate, or see if I can find how to make one. Maybe there's a memory address that can be reliably modified with a cheatengine table or something, dunno.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: This game has shown me how much I've grown away from the grinder, turn based games. The voice is really good, but the pacing of the dialogue is so slow I found myself moving things forward before they could deliver the lines and grunts. The stories themselves, of what I've seen, are very mediocre and cliche. The combat is sort of interesting, but the amount of encounters you need to do make it feel tedious quickly.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: Amazing music. Amazing visuals. A very satisfying combat system and it really feels good to shred resists, boost dmg, break enemy, then slam for several dozen thousand damage. You can mug the elderly and steal literal candy from children and it's a great time. There's a demonic stuffed toy trying to devour a child's soul and it wants you to play with it. That was fun. I don't know if I'll be bothered to finish the game after 70 hours because the writing is just so cheesy that it feels like the writing was made for a 9yr old, but also has decidedly not-child topics such as suicidal thoughts, prostitution, and some other stuff. Fun game, but if you're like me and you're progressively getting less tolerant of bad writing as you get older, this one might be painful. I finished Osvald's and Throne's story. Maybe I'll come back to finish the rest eventually.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: As the first chapter I think the game shines in the graphical and soundtrack aspect, but has a very bland and mediocre gameplay. I don't think this is a bad game overall, but it's definitely not of my tastes. I dislike the fragmented narration, going back and forth from one character to the other to obtain little glimpse of their story, which until now, have been very bland and clichè, is very rhythm breaking. Exploring the world is beautiful , until you don't get stopped every 10 seconds for a random encounter (even with the reduced encounter buff, they are still too many), this makes walking around incredibly frustrating if you are not trying to farm. One positive aspect I like about the game is the job system and a couple of mechanics from characters (yes I'm looking at you monster trainer girl). after around 15 hrs of gameplay (Steam Deck offline hours are not counted), I just find myself not wanting to continue anymore, i'm not invested in the characters, story, or gameplay. I'm sorry I played Chained Echoes before this one, that game probably ruined most of classic JRPG out there, introducing quality of life improvements to the genre that now can't be overlooked.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: I really disliked the original Octopath Traveler, but read enough word-of-mouth reviews to give the second game a shot. I don't feel this review has to be as lengthy as the review for the first game, considering this game is essentially just more of the same. It has the same strengths; it's extremely pretty, the music is fantastic. And it's got the same weaknesses; weak character interplay, strange balancing. What I noticed more in this title than the previous is just how god-awful the caliber of writing is. The stories are essentially very standard, very stale JRPG fare. Characters do monumentally stupid things or make mistakes they shouldn't make in order to arbitrarily create some sort of weak, ineffectual conflict. For example, lifelong successful merchants will suddenly not realize there's a clause in a contract that robs them of all their wealth, and now they have to get it back and right the wrongs! It's all so very eye-rolling. This is a pretty simple review to write because it's a relatively straightforward sequel: If you liked the first Octopath Traveler, go ahead and buy this because you'll probably love it. If you, like me, were bored by the first game, this one will likely not do anything to change your mind.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: As overrated and overpriced as the first one. I got baited by the comments from people that said that it got rid of the flaws of the first one. It didnt. If you didnt like the first Octopath you will not like this one.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: I'm pretty far into this game and more and more I'm finding it a chore to play. I never find myself wanting to pick this back up. I basically only fire it up when I'm bored. I'm not enjoying it. Gotta give it a thumbs down.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: Let's get the non-bad things out of the way Graphics and sound fit, no complains there. Combat system is solid, progression system works....done. Now for the bad. In short: they have neither learned from nor improved upon the issues of the first game. Party Story There is neither. You have 8 solo characters that have absolutely nothing in common and that have virtually no interaction either. You have 8 mini stories that are outright crap. Stories are cut into chapters and intentionally made so you don't play 1 characters story without interruption. There is no connection between either story and the chapter design is...sh*t. Enter area, get popup, confirm you wanna do the chapter, get hit by walls of text, use the characters path action at least once, get hit by more walls of text and occasionally you get to fight a bit...story chapter done. How low can the developers of Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest fall ?... Path Action ..is like 90% of the game. Every single character story chapter revolves around the characters path action. There isn't a single side quest you can finish without using at least 1 path action, several can't even be started without. And even the skills for 2 jobs (inventor and armsmaster) are locked behind path action. This leaves you with the "choice": pick a party that has all relevant actions..or constantly switch members...but neither is actually an option. Choosing a party with all actions leaves you with like 1 party setup, constantly switching fails because path actions are not limited to towns where you can change party members and more (example at the end). Adding day and night means you have 2 options for each result for day and night (e.g. 2x steal for day, 2x steal for night)...except it doesn't work. The game does not allow you to beat up children (sadnes...). The warrior's day action knocks out NPC blocking your path...by beating them up...can't use it on children. Can be worse... The priests night action gains information..by beating the NPC up...again can't use it on kids. Only way to get info from kids during the night is ...bribing them with the warrior which wastes money. Even better is the scholar who has a "steal" night action...by beating the target up. => not on kids. Only way to get items from kids during night time is the dancer...but her path action depends on her level. There is the next problem: only the characters in your active party get xp. So you can't just switch in the dancer for her path action...nope, you have to lvl her first. Example The promised example: A sidequest requires you to get a new lens for a lighthouse. Every normal game allows you to talk to the NPC and offer to buy it...not this pile of **. You have to use path action...and out of the 4 steal path action only the one from the merchant is allowed to be used. So you run back to town, switch in the merchant, run to the docks, board your ship, sail across the sea to the island, walk up the island to the lighthouse, buy the damn lens and go back to town to switch out the merchant.....truely great design....

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: 5/10 - Average Octopath Traveler 2 is a turn-based JRPG that I unfortunately can't recommend. My experiences with the game are mixed. Octopath Traveler 2 has great pixel art, the OST is outstanding, and the combat system is one of the strong points of the game. Why is this game a 5/10 then? Well, it comes down to several areas: [*]The 8 playable characters have entirely separate individual stories. There's barely an overarching story that involves crossover between them. They join your party because you just happen to be walking by. [*]Most of the character's stories are poorly written. A few party members have good pay-off, but the amount of time spent on bad or cliché stories made me skip or fast forward through the dialogue. [*] Whether you're in a dungeon or out in the field, every 5-10 seconds you will be thrusted into combat. The frequency of random battles is unacceptable. The skill that lowers the frequency of battles makes the encounter rate more reasonable. [*]The character you choose initially can't be changed out of the party until you fully complete their story. [*]Characters not in the party receive zero experience. This results in you having to grind party members at different times from lower levels. [*]Banter skits between party members only appear during a story chapter, and they have no voiceover. [*]The mini-map only shows the general direction of the next areas, and not any detail of the current area you're in. I did not play Octopath Traveler 1. My expectations of this game were elevated initially by seeing the overwhelmingly positive reaction. In the end, I believe Octopath Traveler 2 could have been a much better game with a reason for these 8 characters to be in a party with one another. The game's story format and writing are ultimately a detriment.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: all plot lines save for temenos are predictable and very cliche, you have no time to enjoy the music or scenery outside of towns as you're constantly put into battle, this game is just not for me, I can't even bring myself to finish the final chapter

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: There are lots of improvements to the game mechanics compared to the first one, and the art is beautiful. The game is weighed down by terrible pacing. The cut scenes last too long and have bloated dialogue, and on multiple occasions I couldn't believe they bothered to deliver some information to me in the form of a cut scene. The whole flow would interrupt for an absolutely pointless information dump. I know it's sort of a feature of the JRPG that the writing is a little lackluster, but the obnoxious voice acting on multiple characters makes it unbearable for me. If I hear a baby voice one more time I am going to scream. The stories are also flat and predictable. Really trope-heavy and empty. I feel no connection to any character, and actively hate several. I set it down a few weeks ago and just cannot find the motivation to come back. The idea of playing through multiple chapters of these character's stories started to feel like a chore. If you don't care about any of that it did take me 16 hours to get through the first chapters (and one or two second chapters) for all eight characters so there's content forever.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: Suffers from the same issues as Octopath Traveler I. There is no party interaction whatsoever - All the characters are strangers to each other, despite being in a party. The game is essentially 8 side stories, with no main story. If you're looking for good JRPGs, I recommend playing Chained Echoes instead. Great graphics, though. Edit: And to recruit main characters, you sometimes still need to help complete strangers do dubious things without questioning their motives. Also, with Temenos you play a massive asshole that goes around, beating up innocent townspeople to obtain infos. Ochette captures beasts, makes them fight for her, and then turns them into Jerky once they are of no more use to her. Her main companion animal must be constantly on the edge, always wondering when it's her time to become shashlik. Hikari likes to force innocent grannies into duels. Like wtf, lol. It's kinda funny, but nonsensical. Edit2: It's strange that commenters defend these issues by saying that the final chapter resolves them. It doesn't matter if the final 10% has a unified story and character interaction, when the first 90% don't. It's just weird to have 8 protagonists that do not interact with each other in any meaningfull way. Still playing this game because I already played all the better games, but it's anything but great. Edit3: There is also this weird part where you've got a party of 4 heroes, but in cutscenes there is only ever the current side story's main protagonist present. As if the others did not exist at all. It's especially strange when the protagonist gets in trouble and there is seemingly nobody to aid, even though you just fought a battle with a party of four. Edit4: It seems like the writers gave up completely during Ochette's chapter 3. The storytelling keeps getting more nonsensical. I wish they'd make a with the same game mechanics and graphics, but a different set of writers.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: Hate to not like this game - but the pacing of the game is pretty slow. Decent amount of natural grind to the game. Story pacing is slow and uninteresting. The dialogue is pretty difficult to listen to. The RPG combat elements have an interesting foundation - but just didn't connect for me. If the enemies in the game scaled to your party better, it might be more interesting - but 90% of the fights in this game are one-sided beat downs that take you far too much time to execute. You never really feel threatened as the player and thus the system is largely uninteresting. The gameplay loop is extremely repetitive with no difficulty anywhere to be seen. You spend your time ferrying your squad through an exhausting number of random encounters to reach really poorly written story segments that drag on longer than they are welcome. I will confess - I did not make it deep into the jobs system that is available in the game and only hoovered up 6 of the companions - but I just could not see how they were going to ultimately make the combat interesting, and it looks like I was a good 20-30 hours of grind away from being able to evaluate it. This is not even including the large amount of faffing about you can do in town using your character's skills to steal stuff you don't need or find rumors about stuff that you don't want to know. Glad people have been enjoying it - but definitely not for me.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: Octopath Traveler 2 does some things well and others poorly: Pros: *Great music, satisfying sound effects *Gorgeous pixel art *Lots of customization options for your characters Cons: *Most customization options are traps, in practice you have 4 characters who have to be built as DPS, two as healers and two as supports. Anyone stepping out of their lane will suck. *Bad voice acting *Really bad writing *Grindy I'd recommend this game at a steep discount, but I paid full price for it and it definitely isn't worth that much. The best jRPGs on the market today were not made by Squeenix, if you're looking for a great jRPG, you should look at these games instead: Chained Echoes: Similar to Octopath Traveler 2, but with more freedom on how to build your characters, better writing, a combat system you can't sleepwalk through, and for MUCH cheaper. Yakuza: Like a Dragon. Yes, it's a jRPG. Visual style is very different, combat system is good but not great, but the writing is absolutely phenomenal. Also MUCH cheaper.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: Octopath Traveler II is a pretty enjoyable game with some issues. Despite its issues it's still a step above the first game. Has some QoL stuff such as quick travel, while adding in some amount of interactions with party members. The music itself is really good. Likely will find myself listening to the soundtrack on occasion, basically put it into my rotation. Gameplay wise the game is decently standard. Once you find your combos you start destroying things and doing massive damage. The joys of these games is to destroy bosses as hard as possible. It's hilarious deleting 45 level bosses, watching the in fight cutscene happen, then slapping them for however little damage and they just disintegrate. Some characters also feel stronger than others. Agnea feels like she does very little while in comparison Hikari is just tossing around big numbers like it's going out of style. Ochette does too but not on the same level. Other than all that the game is your very typical jrpg flair, not much unique besides the final boss. A lot of it still feels disconnected, namely only having 4 people at once, so typically it only ends up being one on ones or very rarely involving 3 characters. I have yet to see one with 4. On top of the fact that they're also unvoiced so there is a disconnect there on top of it. It feels weird knowing this has been a solved thing having all 8 characters all together, yet the devs decided to make it a issue. Not sure why. Story wise the game struggles. Due to the aforementioned nature of the story being overall disconnected, some things feel random at times. But it's okay, by nature the game is mostly pretty freestyle, but now that I'm talking about story, I technically have 9 stories I need to think/cover. So I'll just... go into spoiler territory now and give a list of best to worst. - Spoiler Territory - 1. Castti, 2. Throne, 3. Partitio, 4. Hikari, 5. Temenos, 6. Ochette, 7. Osvald, 8. Extra/Final, 9. Agnea Favorite Character: Castti Starting Character: Ochette Main things to note: Agnea's story felt like nothing. The "villain" kinda just felt like they shoved her in there because they forgot to make one. " All For You" is mid. They could have easily talked about how the industry notoriously abuses stars/idols, but opted not to. Although I can't recall if the first game did this, either way. Castti's was the only one that got a emotional response out of me. Osvald standing there like a idiot for two chapters was dumber than rocks. Ch4 was mostly fine, ch5 was some next level "what the hell are you doing?" tier shit. Throne hyped me up, killing those assholes felt so good. Partitio is a good man, although I would have preferred a ethical capitalism vs late-stage capitalism approach. Hikari was typical anime stuff, although I did like how his latent ability changed names and color scheme. Temenos was better than expected, the detective stuff was neato. Ochette dropped the ball with its final boss. The start of darkness was technically in the beginning when the (animal not chosen) attacked unprovoked. The rest was clearly manipulative and tried to get some "oh, the poor thing" points. The final story, well... I just think the typical "depressed villain doesn't find their life worthwhile, so clearly life in general is meaningless" thing has run its course. This seems to be happening more actively. Each time it's a eye roller. I cared nothing for it. I did find it sweet that Partitio being how he is was Ori's reason to keep on living. Odd how she didn't see other characters like Ochette and especially Castti in a positive light like that, but it's nice. - Out of Spoiler Territory - That's about it. Mostly it's a fine game. The grind is a bit excessive, especially if you want to fight the super boss. Although I'll be honest it's not a fun fight so I wouldn't recommend going for it anyway. Despite my gripes maybe you'll end up liking the story beats. Personally I see these types happen time and time again that I'm a little just tired of it all. There ARE better RPGs out there, but this game is pretty. Although I would recommend turning off the blur/bloom in the engine.ini file, seriously you won't regret it. The game can be pretty uneasy on the eyes. In the end this felt more like a expansion of the first, with nerfs here and there. There are definite improvements that can be made, especially to reduce grinding. Also, the banter should be voiced imo. Breathe some life into the characters and their interactions with eachother. Especially when they all have different stories, they are the life of your game. In my case I got it 20% off, so that helped my decision in getting it. If I had to pay 60 for this though? Yeah, nah. I can't recommend the game at this price point. Get the game on a sale if you can. The improvements aren't enough to warrant another $60 price tag imo. Your mileage may vary though. Dear god Valve you really need to give us a neutral option.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: I tried so hard to give this game a chance. The plot holes are just too atrocious for me to give it a shot anymore. "yeah, i know you put me in jail for life over a crime you KNOW I didn't commit and now you just tried to kill me but screw it, I'm not gonna kill you over something so trivial. You can go free." - Sums up nearly every character in the game including the ones who are supposed to be of a darker nature.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: I want to recommend this game, but at least on steamdeck it's a hot mess. I've tried all sorts of settings, updates, and fixes. Still getting routine and random freezing. I've beaten on particular boss duo four times and it has frozen at different points before i can save each time. Developer has serious work to do, this should not be steamdeck verified.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: This is an above average game marred by inconsistencies and questionable design. It's almost like for every good decision made there is one either not carefully thought out or hashed together. I want to mostly speak on the writing aspect of the game as it's the one that I had the most problems with. I think that if the game did not try to lean on this aspect and was just a fun explore-at-your-own-pace with minimal story in the background thing then it would be better off. It is not that though, and it is always wasting your time to give bits and pieces in the form of cut-scenes that drag you out of the world. 1) Story feels only like events happening instead of something that has cause and effect You cannot have an overarching plot that fumbles it's way through sectioned bits of storytelling. The beats themselves are passable, but this world in particular feels so lifeless as (I dare say it) your immersion is throttled when you are taken out of a town to hear another tale from one of the 8 party members you recruited. Seeing a little bubble pop up from one of my members with 'I have something to do here' feels like railroading than something that organically happened from exploration. The individual stories themselves are..fine. They're not terrible but never once did I resonate with the dialogue or felt particularity intrigued. It is not that 'the stories are simple' rather they are unevenly distributed as writing for 8 characters separately means that you cannot possibly have the time to flesh them out appropriately. I was stunned when I did a chapter for another character and it only took me roughly 40 mins to an hour. "That's it?" It took me 10 hours to gather them and 1 hour to resolve one of their chapters. 2) The characters are markedly unimpressive as a cohesive whole, and separately they don't have enough devoted presence to really establish them. Now this is my opinion, but I'd rather have a cast of 4 really strong party members with great stories than 8 party members who have middling stories and personalities that are carbon cut-out tropes. Don't get me twisted however, a good trope can go a long way. Tropes exist because they are familiar and can do a lot of foundational work. Example: Tenemos is snarky and I like that. Partitio seems like a good guy. However, the issue reveals itself where I watch these stories unfold and I can pretty much guess the behavior of these individuals because they never grow beyond what is already laid out for them. Yes, they go through trial and tribulation but they will always default to their prologue behavior as the game does not want you to spend more time than it chooses to patch things together eventually. That's the impression I got. The writing suffers due to it's unevenness, which is ultimately a letdown. There is always that sinking feeling of 'it could get better!' Maybe the stories become more in-depth and there's some great payoff but I just don't think I have the patience for it. If the writing were more thoughtful, if the cut-scenes were more engaging, and if the characters stood out I could get through it and feel satisfied. Instead, I feel distracted by any attempt of plot. A real shame too because the music is absolutely wonderful, visuals too. The actual GAME is fun but I do not consider these lopsided intermissions of storytelling to be a game activity as I'm just sitting there in my chair and watching it unfold with sometimes a button prompt or two. I hope that the next iteration of this franchise continues to grow. I think the concept here can absolutely work but it needs more dedication in some places (mayhaps highlighted in this very review!) instead of compromising to deliver a 'finished' product.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: I liked a lot of elements from Octopath 1 and I'm glad to see those return in 2! As always the music is great and the artstyle is lovely. Unfortunately, after playing Chained Echoes the contrast in quality of the story is immense. (So far, 10hrs in) the story is VERY bland and extremely predictable on top of this the story is hurried up too much to make the characters and side characters feel like they matter. I'm fully aware that Octo = 8 = 8 different stories that overarch, but the reason for the main characters to join up is just lazy and awful, having your character die in D&D and having your 2nd character randomly join the party makes 100 times more sense than all the characters here. I will be playing the game to it's end and change my review in case my opinion changes. But right now it's too predictable, too bland, boring abilities, WAY to easy, the stories are cliché and what's up with ALL the bad guys being in caves and manors? I recognize most of the layouts and visuals of the caverns from OCTO 1. The characters have some cool personalities but have been showed into unoriginal and lackluster stories. I LOVE rpgs like this and I honestly hope the story and characters soon does a 180.

description: This game is a brand-new entry in the OCTOPATH TRAVELER series, the first installment of which was initially released in 2018 and sold over 3 million copies worldwide.
name: OCTOPATH TRAVELER II
review: This game is a very expensive letdown. Let's start with the good -- very talented voice cast and very good music The Bad -- Horrible, shallow story-lines. In some cases, I even skipped through because they almost made my brain bleed (looking at you Agnea!) Very jarring to be forced to switch between different character stories ... however, if you focus your grind and cheese, you can basically roll the game and its bosses by focusing and completing a few chapters of 2 characters. This game is nothing more than a forced grind. It's fun for the first few hours, and then you feel like a chinese farmer going through the motions, listening to the same catchphrases, music, spells over and over -- which becomes really annoying when you have to backtrack as a level 55, but are stopped by level 2 mobs, with no way to auto-resolve or dodge non-xp fights, even with Osvalds "evasive manuever" ability -- to dodge fights. For a game that is being touted as "difficult gameplay" I have beaten every boss on my first try, without guides, except for 2 -- and even then it only took me a second or third try. Ironically, one of the main bads ... the POWERFUL HARVEY!!! (that's the villains name, for reals) with the dumbest name in recent history, gave me the biggest issue. Bosses are pretty easy, with the ol' Deus Ex Machina nukes, that come out of nowhere, without reason, as you wear their HP down. It's the most cliche play and does not an interesting/challenging fight make. It's fine, you just expect it and hold your breaks/stuns. I've found the game so easy, that I have used less than 5 magical items/potions, besides the basic HP/Mana/Res items. No need. I stumbled upon the Foresaken Graveyard, grinded for an hour, got some good items and my level 40 toons are hitting level 45 bosses at 9999, without a crit, numerous times in a row, with cheesed companions who hit ungodly hard, while my buffers/healers support. Save for the first boss, I don't think I've gone longer than 15 rounds before beating any boss. The pixel art is pretty for a little bit, and then it all starts to look the same. I get it, it's retro. Cool story. With that said, I'm done with 4/8 toons stories. I know this goes to chapter 8, for an ending ... and then of course, you have to complete every sidequest and grindy, un-intresting obstacle they throw at you to finish the "REAL" ending. I don't care. I don't care about any of these over-dramatic, shallow characters or story-lines. I don't care about the silly grind. I don't care about any of the empty side-quests. I don't even care to finish the game. So ,,,, $60 not to care to finish the game. At least I have Divinity 3 to look forward to, someday.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: One of my favorite Rockstar games to-date (next to Max Payne). The negative review is for the awful DRM they've implemented, where you can't play SINGLE player if the Rockstar Launcher servers are offline. The fact that there are people who pirated this game who can play it forever, while the people who payed for it are at the mercy of Rockstar and their DRM servers being online (for an offline game) is a joke. Buyer beware.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: Please note I do NOT blame Steam for my poor experience. The Rockstar launcher simply prevented me from launching the game or it crashed. I updated everything and tried many of the fixes suggested by the community but no luck. For a NEW and FULL PRICE game, users shouldn't have to fight with it to make it work on their systems. For 80$ and a 110GB download I should be able to press play and not worry about it launching or crashing. To anyone reading this review, I would strongly suggest waiting until all the bugs are fixed and Rockstar gets their act together.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: The game itself is great and I doubt my negative review will impact the overall score, but I don't care much for Rockstar's shitty little launcher. I don't like giving them my email, creating an account so they can sell me stuff or the extra layer of DRM on top of Steam which treats paying customers like potential criminals. I hate the always online BS (on an offline, single player game) that requires validation every time I launch it, insinuating that their $20 is somehow more important than my time. I hate the fact that I can't play the game right now because their shitty little servers are down. It basically means I don't own the game because I can only play it when they so graciously allow a mere peasant like myself to play it. It also pisses me off that while their crappy launcher is jerking off in the background, it may be harming performance and I could potentially increase some settings and get the experience I paid for. Putting a small warning about 3rd party DRM on the store front isn't enough. It should be outright banned from Steam and it's a practice which shouldn't be tolerated.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: Okay, so to get the elephant in the room out of the way, the singleplayer campaign is REALLY, REALLY good. It absolutely deserved its status as a popular Game of the Year contender/choice. A few highlights I want to make are: [*] Many of my major gripes with Grand Theft Auto V are actually solved in RDR2. The game's economy is far better-balanced instead of everything revolving around the one-time Heist payouts and the stock market, combat isn't overly reliant on having cover (and thus making combat in the wilderness unfairly challenging), and the heat system is MUCH better as opposed to GTAV that punishes you from doing too good a job escaping the cops by spawning more nearby. [*] R* games are usually well-scripted, but RDR2 is well written and it's almost immediate in how quickly you tell the difference. While previous R* games still had intricate stories, details and loveable characters like RDR2, this game features far better integration of narrative themes and character arcs. Dutch Van Der Linde is probably the single greatest character in Rockstar Games history and RDR2 has a story I think can stand on its own as not just a good, but a fantastic story- If this was a classic cowboy movie, it would've been remembered as one of the greats. [*] I also really like the life simulator aspects to the game, too. I was surprised by how little the body looting/animal skinning animations actually bothered me, especially as both actions are extremely optional (which I did do, by the way, I just never found it too annoying). While it's a bit eeeh, I think the game does a good enough job maintaining its immersive atmosphere that I accept some degree of eeeh for the purposes of realism's sake, and the life sim stuff REALLY makes this game feel like a role-playing game of sorts where you are legitimately rewarded with both a richer experience and gameplay rewards if you actually get invested in being your character- The Honor system helps play into that, too. I also think the Cores system is a pretty genius way to implement a kind of soft "hunger" system to the game and add some fun resource management without being even remotely annoying or troublesome. [*] Easter eggs and oddities are 100x more common in RDR2. You can pick a direction, ride in that direction, and find something interesting in the wilderness that always feels fresh, not just an ubiquitous collectable to find. Practically every player will find SOMETHING that leaves a massive impression on them, and you can explore this world for hundreds of hours still finding new things. Re. Performance errors, I did encounter the dreaded NVIDIA stutter, but after tweaking with options and trying the Rockstar-approved fix, I was able to solve it and everything else was smooth for me. The game's never crashed on me in my time playing it, but my PC is on the higher end of the spectrum and I don't speak for everyone. So, why the negative review? I'm not actually saying you shouldn't buy this game, this is a review in protest of the Online mode in general and intended to be a warning if you are purchasing this game with Online being a factor in your purchase. (either for moral reasons or because you're actually interested) I honestly think Red Dead Online is a better experience than GTA Online, as you can walk for more than a minute without getting killed by the dozens upon dozens of ludicrously overpowered vehicles that roam that abomination- This is partially due to RDO's more grounded setting/feel, and because the open-world is better designed and doesn't cluster damn near everyone in one tiny tenth of the map. (though Saint Denis is usually pretty populated if that's what you're looking for) Plus, the playerbase is generally less interested in senseless murder and 9/10 people you meet won't kill you on sight. And, quite critically, instead of most people spending their time in scripted missions, RDO does a better job juggling between missions and openworld gameplay for moneymaking. It ACTUALLY feels like an open-world game gone online. Admittedly, these missions are largely ruined by forced public matchmaking with no option to solo, so the "mission" is more you running around killing things being constantly pressured by the level 200 hardcore grinders to move faster, skip every cutscene, ecetera, but hey, the open-world gameplay is okay enough. And, here's the BUT... Take Two are a bunch of greedy assholes who are certainly not even remotely happy with making some of the best-selling games of all time with ludicrously profitable microtransactions. Nope, the in-game economy needs to either get people dedicated and invested in the game (and therefore willing to spend money on it), OR for whales who want to actually have fun without hours upon hours of grinding for basic necessities, the spending of as much $ as possible. Many items cost several times more than they do in the base campaign (especially cosmetics, 100 RD$ is relatively cheap for a single hat, and hanging up a small picture in your moonshine shack can cost quadruple that), money is much harder to make, and most insidiously, the secondary Gold Bar currency that's extremely tough to earn outside of doing Daily Challenges every single day to keep up a Streak is used not only for things like exclusive cosmetic items, but to bypass level gate requirements and the Roles, which are the primary moneymaking methods and to be frank CONTENT the mode has to offer, are gated behind extorbitant amounts of Gold. Each of the four Roles costs 15 Gold Bars (except for Moonshiner, which costs 25 AND requires the Trader Role to be unlocked and levelled, so you need a total of 70 Gold Bars to unlock every Role and actually experience what the full game has to offer), and to put that into perspective, completing a Daily Challenge earns you 0.2 Gold Bars. You do get multiple Daily Challenges a day, the aforementioned Streaks can help, and you can get around 0.08 Gold Bars per open-world Stranger Mission you do, but it's REALLY horrible, blatant content-gating behind huge paywalls designed to psychologically manipulate people, and there's also the "Outlaw Pass" (guess what that is) if all that wasn't enough money lining Take Two's pockets. I'm not sure which system between GTAO or RDO is worse, GTAO's inflated currency resulting in unbelievably excessive money burning pits like the Yachts, or RDO's incredibly stingy economy that has created a system where its players are deathly terrified of investing money in anything they won't make regular use out of, but I seriously dislike both and I can't give a positive review in good conscience to a product that employs either system to extract money from players. Look, I'm not against grindy games, I'm not even wholly against microtransactions, and I actually would LIKE the appeal of a world in which every dollar felt precious and like an achievement and where I have to work my way up from a broke cowpoke to an untouchable gunslinger badass- But the presence of a BUY GOLD BARS button immediately obliterates that and is a complete breakdown of player trust. I can no longer assume stupidity when such a massive motivation for malice is present, and I can't go ten minutes in Red Dead Online without being reminded once again that I'm playing a psychologically manipulative scam. Feel free to buy this game for its single-player mode, but I cannot recommend it when it's attached by the hip to Red Dead Online.

review: It shows that I've "played" for 28 hours, but the game constantly crashes, so I've only actually experienced about 15 minutes of play in the game so far, and because the Rockstar launcher was open overnight, Steam thought I was "playing" the game still, therefore I am not eligible for a refund. So while I would love to review this game, first I must be able to play the game, which I cannot at this juncture, therefore I do not recommend buying this game until Rockstar decides to get their shit together. Edit: People asked what my PC's specs are. I have an HP Omen laptop. i7-8750H, 32 GB DDR4-2666, GTX 1070. Oh, and this was installed on my SSD. If my laptop can't run this game, nobody's laptop can run this game.
