name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: I would have preferred to mark this as mixed, but since there are only yes or no, I'm inclined to no. If you waited this long for PC release and extra for Steam, then surely you can wait a little longer until they polish things up and maybe for a discount. Right now game runs OK, but performance could have been better and I've encountered more than a few bugs like disappearing NPCs and invisible walls, stuff like that. Things you don't usually expect from RS games. I had crash too. I would say I feel rather disappointed with the way the game was delivered to us. I'm still gonna play, probably gonna change review to positive, but right now, if I were you, I would wait for a few months.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: If you have ever updated your email address with Steam like I did, you may not be able to launch the Rockstar client because it keeps asking me to verify an old email address I used to have on Steam that I no longer have access to.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: Well it's sad it's come to this, but I have to now rate this game down. After struggling for hours past the refund point with a few random crashes, terrible optimization and strange keybindings, this game now crashes every single time trying to load the story. I have tried all the fixes listed by Rockstar as suggestions, opened a support case with them, and done basic PC troubleshooting. Also tried safe mode when launching the game. No controller plugged in. It just hard crashes every time I try to load my single player campaign which is a grand shame, considering I was just starting to get really into the game and look past it's technical issues. Well, no more. This review is staying negative until a patch is released or a fix is otherwise found, because this is ridiculous. EDIT (fix): I got it working by using DX12 and not Vulkan, turning off Windows defender, clearing the local save/config files, and re-installing rockstar launcher Edit 2: For all the morons saying these are simple fixes, YES THEY ARE, but I had to do all of them in addition to all the other basic fixes and tinkering I tried first. So kindly ride a barbed dildo if all you have to say is "u DuMb GamE rUnS FiNe" Edit 3: Specs are i7 7700k/1080ti/16GB RAM/M2 SSD so no, not potato Also game is now randomly crashing to desktop with no error, so this review is staying negative because apparently making a stable PC port is too much to ask. Final edit: I just want to clarify (since this review blew up) that RDR2 is a GOOD game when it WORKS. I'd recommend waiting for a patch to increase stability but when ti works for me, it is a genuinely enjoyable and immersive experience. I love all of the details in the game. To summarize, good game, terrible port.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: The game itself is great. Arguably the most ambitious game they have created to date. However, I cannot currently recommend it for multiple reasons. I decided to wait for the Steam release, due to reports of the game being riddled with bugs and other issues. Although the wait really didn't make much difference. Regardless of the fact I can typically run it on a mixture of high/ultra settings @70-90FPS (1080Ti / i7 8700k), I still encounter the ERR_GFX_STATE crash, and the proposed workaround does absolutely nothing to remedy it. Another known issue I encounter is a weird smudging effect with objects in the distance, and with hair/beards. After a bit of searching online, I've deduced this could well be an issue with the Anti-aliasing (TAA in particular). It's not as noticable on higher resolutions, but it's still something that should be addressed. While the game is now "serviceable", it still runs like shit for a lot of others, even after several patches with R* insisting the game is fixed. Is this really the acceptable standard for AAA titles on PC? Surely not. To add insult to injury, a week after it released on Steam, the game is now on sale @ -20% for the standard edition & -25% for the Special and Ultimate editions. Apparently this is how R* treats the Steam user base. If it wasn't for the fact I'm over the 2hr mark, I'd consider getting a refund, and waiting for some optimisation and a more appropriate price tag. Like I said, it's a great game, but I would hold off until they resolve the current issues, and perhaps wait for a big sale.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: If you ever intend to play offline, which as a sailor, I have to... Do not buy. Rockstar have taken it upon themselves to force you to use their crappy, buggy launcher that crashes constantly and is incapable of operating without an internet connection. When it does work, upon opening the game you'll be greeted with an 'Activation Verification Failed' message, which quits you from the game. 3 hours of researching later, there are no fixes for this, and at 6 months from launch, I expect that there never will be. It is utterly criminal. Do not support greedy, horrendous developers like this. Developers that force their audience into a grim situation with zero compromise. Couldn't care less about the game itself, I can't stand another second of trying to troubleshoot this buggy piece of shit. fuck you rockstar.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: One of my favorite games, but Rockstar has locked me out from playing this. Offline. I can no longer sign in to my Social Club account (required for offline play), and after going through a ticket for over one month with Rockstar, they can't determine I am the owner of the account and have stopped. In this ticket I have proved 3 times I have purchased the game and provided the receipt, I have proved to be the owner of the Steam account, and yet I'm locked out. My Social Club account is connected to my Steam account. Since I can't login, I can't disconnect it and create a new Social Club account. I can't rebuy the game because it would be on my Steam account connected to my Social Club account I can't access... I can't access the old email in any way, so I'm just stuck. Amazing that even proving I have purchased the game and own the Steam account it's not enough to show I am the owner. Ridiculous I need to be signed in to play offline story mode and there's nothing that can be done to let me play again. It was fun while it lasted. >>> Update: I made a second ticket. I gave all the info and screenshots that I knew was needed and others have mentioned. Immediately comes back with questions asking to provide those things. Now I have to acknowledge I can't play these games from either Steam or my Social Club account after they unlink them. I think that means I just need to reconnect using my new Social Club account with the email I can access. I'll try that because I have nothing to lose.

name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: FIX at end: Crashes for me! :Wont start. Out of hundreds of games I have downloaded on steam. This is the first one that will not start and states to contact Rockstars games for support. I waited to buy this specifically on Steam and the Rockstar launcher doesnt work through Steam. After contacting Rockstar games. Doing a reinstall of the game it worked fine after one start up. I did some graphical adjustments and it asked me to restart from the RDR2 menu. Upon relaunch it started crashing again and would not reopen. Rockstar told me to rename my settings folder to whatever I wanted under documents files and reverify the integrity of the files through the Steam launcher. It did not work, they told me to reinstall the game and not change the graphics settings, even though they were lower graphical settings and it would not start to begin with. FIX: After installing musltiple times and doing anything in the handbook. A guy in the commments stated to unplug the controller and that fixed it for me! So stupid!

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: I got banned for being force teleported around the map and having money forced onto my character. Now, you might ask, "Well why didn't you tell Rockstar?" Well apparently you can't submit tickets for suspension or banning, their staff saying the decisions are final. The modder who did it also happened to blow me up, interrupt missions I was in and kill all the NPC's around me, and a plethora of other issues. Ever been surrounded by like six people and then get teleported while they all watch you? Well it's all the more infuriating when the person who teleports you starts yelling in Korean, and then laughs. It's even more irritating when Rockstar still hasn't patched the nonsense where people can make themselves look like other people, and change their display name in a server where you can't report them. I get caught in the crossfire, and some idiocy happens. Rockstar doesn't care. I got blammed for getting cougars spawned at me, and then I'm the bad guy cause I managed to kill them despite the hacker constantly hitting me. Hell, at one point I just ran to Blackwater, started blasting the fuckers and then selling the pelts. Before anyone decides to tell me, "Well you were cheating then!" have you ever had dozens of cougars try and rip you apart, and then have to kill your way through them all? I felt like my cash was well earned from those pelts after getting good at throwing them off of me, wasting my tonics on staying alive, and then blowing their brains out. Get your shit together, Rockstar, and stop banning innocent people.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: I can't leave a positive review for this game because I can't even start the game. If you want to play this game you have to use the social club launcher. I have 2 different social club accounts. One works just fine, the other one doesn't. I lost the email for that account six years ago. But this is fine, right? You should just log in your social club account that works and start the game, right? WRONG You don't even get to CHOOSE the account that gets linked to steam. I tried to start the game, and it just randomly chose the old account. The game just tells you it sent a verification email to an e-mail adress that doesn't work without giving you any choice or options at all. Think about that; I have a functioning steam account and a functioning social club account and I still can't start the bloody game. I logged in to the social club account to try and link it to steam. But the option isn't even there. You can link your account to Xbox live, playstation network, games for windows live, twitter, twitch and even facebook. But steam isn't there? why the fuck is steam not there? How a triple a developer managed to pull that off is just mind-blowing to me. Can't recommend until Rockstar gets their shit together. Will be getting a refund

It's funny that I can enjoy the rainbow, beautiful sunsets&sunrises or thunderstorms. But I can’t read signs or look at the photo, cause it looks like minecraft style. :D But this is insignificant for me.

description: Winner of over 175 Game of the Year Awards and recipient of over 250 perfect scores, RDR2 is the epic tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan and the infamous Van der Linde gang, on the run across America at the dawn of the modern age. Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.
name: Red Dead Redemption 2
review: Requires Rockstar Games Launcher. Crashes on start. Update: Found a workaround - launching under a clean local administrator account. Countless other solutions did not help. Create a local user account Select the Start button, select Settings > Accounts and then select Family & other users. (In some editions of Windows you'll see Other users.) Select Add someone else to this PC. Select I don't have this person's sign-in information, and on the next page, select Add a user without a Microsoft account. Enter a user name, password, password hint or choose security questions, and then select Next. Change a local user account to an administrator account Under Settings > Accounts > Family & other users, select the account owner name, then select Change account type. Under Account type, select Administrator and OK. Sign in with the new administrator account. P.S. To be clear, I have no issues about Rockstar Games Launcher. Just warning that it's there. And it clearly gives extra layer of issues as I can't get past it. Despite the fact that I had it working with Max Payne 3 on the same PC.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: The man who designed the Square Enix account system will answer for his sins.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Don't buy this game on Steam! Get it directly through Square Enix (which regularly has it on sale unlike Steam) or another site that does not lock in future purchases to only one vendor (Steam). The game is registered as a Steam version on the Square Enix site, and only Steam-based expansions can be registered onto that account if you buy the base game here. The game is great, but I don't recommend buying here for the sole basis of being locked in to a single system where you cannot buy expansions elsewhere if they are on sale. Please buy elsewhere! Addendum: Another reason to not buy on Steam: if you need to change countries, Square will not accept payment from a Steam store from a different country. You'll essentially be locked out of being able to pay for a subscription.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Great MMO with a wonderful community. Strong recommend. Only, don't buy it on Steam that's just adding another layer of complexity where something can go wrong for basically no benefit. I'm constantly having to restart my whole Steam client because the FFXIV launcher can't "connect" to it. And it's not like for that hassle I get anything like auto login or achievements or updates. And, once you bought on steam, you can't unhook from Steam. Go to Square Enix's site and buy from the source.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Do NOT buy this before getting to level 60 with the demo, which is free. That's ~40-80 free hours of content, which can translate to ~3 months worth of subscription time depending on how often you play. It turns out that when you do buy it, you are locked out of that "free until level 60". People defend this by using the semantics of it being a "free trial" to get around the fact that it's a noob trap. The game is solid and otherwise not so predatory from what I've seen, but it's disappointing that it essentially punishes you for buying it too soon. I do not recommend purchasing it, at least not until you've played through the entire free trial (you may have to do some research to find it, as it seems to be intentionally hidden from this page).

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Less to do with the game and more the steam client for it. If you have an old account do NOT purchase anything through steam. Accounts are branded permanently either windows or steam and purchases do NOT cross over/codes cannot be redeemed for the other. You will also NOT be able to login the steam version with a windows account etc and all purchases are NOT refundable for this game on steam. The game itself is solid but I felt a proper disclaimer should be out there.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: You already know the game's great, so here's a downvote for the clumsy, unwieldy, positively archaic launcher, registration and Mogstation. Learn to 21st Century, Squeenix.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: An overall good game for any type of player. I am not an MMO fan. I definitely recommend trying it. BUT. There are a few PSAs. ***DO NOT BUY- THERE IS A FREE TRIAL** https://store.steampowered.com/app/312060/FINAL_FANTASY_XIV_Online_Free_Trial/?curator_clanid=34459938 ***YOU WILL NOT be eligible for the free 1-60 trial if you buy the game here!*** !!!!!!!! IF YOU WANT TO PLAY WITH FRIENDS YOU MUST BE ON THE SAME DATA CENTER !!!!!!!! There is EASILY 100 HOURS of content you can get out of this game WITHOUT PAYING. You can play ALL content of levels 1-60 with no limit on playtime by signing up for the free trial. Level 1-60 content includes: *Around 3/4 of all combat classes, with the exceptions of: Gunbreaker, Dancer, Red Mage, Samurai, Sage, Reaper *All crafters/gatherers- sewing, smithing, fishing and mining to name a couple *~50 4-man dungeons, all featuring unique gear for all classes, environments, music, and bosses *~40 8-man "Trial" boss only fights, emphasizing mechanics, with unique rewards and arenas *6 24-man Alliance raids, where you fight series of bosses from previous titles How square handles accounts and licenses is awful so I will try to explain: -IF YOU BUY ON STEAM, you must download the game via steam, make a Square Enix mogstation account, and register the steam key to the account. You will have ONE FREE MONTH and then you MUST pay a sub to continue playing. -IF YOU BUY FROM SQUARE, you must make a freetrial.finalfantasyxiv account, then download the game. You will use this account to log in from the client. -IF you want to play on ps4/5- you will have to buy another copy and any DLC. Only one subscription. --- Now, with that out of the way, I will review in brief and then go over more details. (Leave comments for input/questions!) PROS: + 90% OF PLAYERS ARE HAPPY TO HELP YOU: Many people talk about the supportive and friendly playerbase, but I can't emphasize this point enough. If you have a question, you can /shout a question in the local chat and somebody nearby will probably help. But because its other people, not everyone has this experience. + CULTURE: People legitimately stand around in hubs and have discussions with strangers, show off fashion, RP, and craft. There are many clans and discords to join and find a community. RP, housing, fashion, photography, ERP are popular and easy to find. You can play this like a solo game if you do not want to talk to anybody- there isn't anything important or useful that is locked behind clans or friends. + RESPECTS YOUR TIME: There is nearly no grinding and no time pressure. If you stop playing, your gear and unlocks are going to be exactly how you left it when you come back. While you wait to get into a dungeon (DPS queues are the longest but during regular hours are around 15 minutes), you can fight, watch cutscenes, do quests, and even play as any other classes. If a cutscene is going to take a long time (10 minutes+) there is nearly always a warning beforehand. If you have to skip, disconnect or forget, you can rewatch every cutscene in the game at any time. There are daily dungeon reward bonuses, but you can get that same currency in abundance with no weekly cap, and is only relevant every 10 levels after 50. The most "premium" currency is earned nearly exclusively by these dailies is for nearly best in slot lv 90 gear, but the weekly currency cap is so low you can hit it easily in 2 or 3 days of casual (1-2 hour/day) playing. +THERE IS NO PAY TO WIN. You can buy emotes, clothes, and mount. + PLAY EVERY CLASS WITH ONE CHARACTER- instantly change out of comba + NO FOMO: Every piece of content is there for you to experience it, and the content that has been cut were a handful of old boring quests for the main story. While you might want to rush get to the endgame content, everything is self-paced. There are no useful "seasonal events" / "season passes". Those events that do exist often happen yearly, go on for around a month, give out cosmetic gear or mounts (which can sometimes be bought for real dollars later) and are ALWAYS accessible from level 5-10 (which takes probably less than an hour to get to). + AMAZING MUSIC: a MASSIVE range of AMAZING music written by one composer, Soken. Just go to youtube and listen for yourself. Search "ffxiv" with any following (there are no spoilers in these fights): "Fiend" "Ink Long Dry" "Down the Up Staircase" "Answers" "Footfalls" "Beauty's Wicked Wiles" "To the Edge""Dancing Mad" + DIFFICULTY FOR ALL LEVELS: LOW- you don't have to worry about bringing down the team. Dungeons and bosses are generally a breeze as long as there is one player who isn't new. Even then, if you are still worried, there are MANY new player youtube guides for each dungeon and fight. HIGH- there are more than 40 "Savage/Unreal" boss fights that require careful gear selection, stat boosts, precise positioning, movement, and reaction (around 3 seconds at the highest end), mastery of your class abilities and damage output, and close coordination with teammates. There are many "statics" with open recruiting that practice multiple hours while in call on the same fight for weeks to work towards a single clear of one of these fights. However I MUST emphasize THESE ARE OPTIONAL, and only done by the top 0.01%. While they give best gear, the stat increase of this is negligible to most players, and no content requires it. + MINIMAL TO NO BOTTING + 100% CUSTOMIZABLE DISPLAY AND HOTBARS- any size, anywhere. + Awesome controller support --- Neutral / more subject to opinion * No in-game mic * Main story (MSQ) is REQUIRED for unlocking all locations and dungeons. You do not get XP/items by killing overworld enemies, but by doing dungeons. Your class level is independent of your current MSQ, but important class abilities are locked behind class quests. You cannot "main" a crafter or gatherer to progress the story. Everyone has to go through the MSQ before getting to the new content. While level and MSQ skips to level 70 or 80 (not sure which) are available for purchase, they are frowned upon because early level story and skills are fundamental to enjoying 70/80+ content. *MULTIPLATFORM- Play with people of all ages and experience on ps4, ps5, windows, mac, at any time *DATA CENTERS- Although there are data centers in NA, EU, JP, and now Oceania, it is not uncommon to find UK and AU players on NA servers. Ping is never an issue. Load times vary between device and ISP. *PLUGINS- 3rd party plugins and analysis tools are forbidden, and your account can be terminated if you are caught using them. --- CONS: -BAD START- It is to be expected but low level gameplay is boring. You only have about 3-5 very simple combat abilities. 90% of time is spent having to read dialogue, teleport/walk around towns or walk to a spot in the wilderness. You don't get a mount until around msq level 30, so for the first couple of hours you are mostly walking. Teleports cost $ (which is only a problem in the first 20 levels) and can only be done when you have walked there before, so there are even times when you might have to search for a boat or gate to travel to a different city. I actually quit playing at level 30 3 years ago because the story was boring and all the going back and forth for hours on end when I wanted to explore combat. However, I was doing sidequests that do not reward or unlock anything so I was legitimately just wasting time and stalling. -MASSIVE download- When trying to play this game at home, I spent an entire week just trying to download the game. You download the client, and then EVERY PATCH in sequence. For the majority of the users, your download might take 2 or fewer hours with 500MB-1 GB/s fiber optic. At home, I had spotty 9MB/s, so the download time was 8 hours. Any time the connection dropped, the download had to restart at the beginning of that patch.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: I want you to play this game do not get me wrong, DO NOT BUY IT ON STEAM YOU WILL REGRET IT, BUY IT ON THE SITE. You will find more deals for the game and expansions more oft on the square site, not to mention steam has had a reputation of running this game worse than if you got it on square, but you are stuck with one or the other as if you buy on steam you can only buy expansions on steam.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: This is not the version that will give you the Expanded Free Trial, despite it being the Header and all over the page. Read the page carefully so you know what you're getting. Especially since I've been told it's non-refundable and my new account can't ever be linked to said free trial now.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Read this part (found near the bottom of the store page) before you buy: Note: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online game packages available on Steam may only be registered and added on a Square Enix account that has the base game “FINAL FANTASY XIV Online Starter Edition" (or formerly known as "FINAL FANTASY XIV: A Realm Reborn”) purchased on Steam. In other words, if you have an existing FFXIV account NOT through Steam, DO NOT BUY any expansion packages through Steam - unless you want to create a new account and start all over (good luck there, too - all the servers are somehow full). This expansion is non-refundable, meaning that if you missed that bit on the page, you're screwed: you just bought an expansion you can't play, because Square Enix will not allow you to register a Steam expansion code with a non-Steam base game account.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Probably the worst account management and registration I have EVER seen in a video game.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Worst signup process ever invented, comically bad. You need a steam account, a SE account, a MogStation account, a registration key which can only be applied to one SE account. You can link a steam account to an SE account but can't then unlink it if it's not the SE account to which the registration key was applied sending you in an endless Catch 22 loop. I played this once when I first bought it, haven't been able to log back in again since and give up each time after 45 minutes of this nonsense.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Heads up those who lives in undeveloped countries and/or don't have a salary in dollars, the monthly payment for a subscription needs to be done from the Square Enix web page, which let's you pay using your steam wallet BUT that payment IS NOT regional. I learned it the hard way when the SE site wanted to charge in my steam account TEN TIMES the ammount of money i payed in my first purchase here in steam, and also said purchase it's only for the trial version, you will not get anything else except the "free trial" in your purchase of FF XIV Online Starter Edition. Now, the game? it's amazing, so if you have a salary in dollars go ahead because it's totally worth, the music, the graphics, the story, the gameplay, everything it's great. But i will leave a negative review just for that shitty low move from SE advertising one thing and selling you another and for the total absence of a warning about regional prices don't being supported by SE. Edit: Thanks a lot for all the awards and upvotes, i hope my review and all the others warning about the same problem can at least help a little to make SE change things on their end.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Registration is a bloody nightmare

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: Do not purchase this game on steam. The amount of times I have not been able to login due to issues is absolutely absurd. Get the PC launcher, independent of steam.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: I've never seen a game that made it so friggin' hard to set up an account and get logged in.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: The game is fine - if you've ever played an MMO you know exactly what to expect, and it's one of the better ones out there (as evidenced by the subscription requirement). This company is ridiculously difficult to do business with, though. Here is my sordid tale: I was in the mood for an MMO so I fired up FFXIV thinking I'd do the free trial, fully expecting to quickly cap out and shell out for the subscription. This was basically a free sale for them - I was absolutely their intended sucker for the trial levels. After repeated failures to even install the demo, I discovered that I had once participated in a free weekend/trial event and already had a level 15 character, which completely precluded me from activating the trial to level 35. I did several hours of research and found no way around it, and finally gave up. No free sale for Squeenix. Fast forward a year and myself, my husband, and some friends all have a week off. It was suggested we all dive into FFXIV together. I knew the trial wouldn't work for me, but I figured eh, why not drop the 20 bucks on the base game and subscription for a month. I logged into my old account to confirm it was still there, purchased the started pack on Steam, and tried to activate it. No dice. All sorts of billing errors occurred. Searching for the codes suggested I would need to call support. You know what? I'm really not invested in my decade-old trial character, so I tried to register a new account. -- email is in use. I guess that makes sense. So I plugged in a different email and successfully created a whole new account. Then my husband tried to join me and ran into errors. He tried three different email addresses and got locked out of each one, being told the email was in use but when he tried to log in being told no account is associated with that email. He contacted support and was told that because an account was registered at this IP (my account...) he could not make an account for 24 hours. Seriously? They've never encountered a situation where two people at the same residence want to create an account together? I am absolutely boggled by this. Furthermore, support absolutely refused to help him. The only response was "Wait 24 hours", but all of us were playing *tonight*. That was unacceptable when there must be a solution for them to remove a lock on account creation. If they don't have that in place I don't know what to say. The starter pack is non-refundable, and he was completely unable to play, so at that point they had essentially stolen his money (for a minimum of 24 hours). He tried to register using a VPN but that was detected and blocked too. He finally registered from a different location entirely, then came back to log in to install the game. It was the most ridiculous process I've seen. What possible evils are they preventing by being so restrictive about account creation? Oh no, someone might give them money :( The game is fine. We're playing and getting our starter pack's worth out of it. I'm terrified to actually do any more business with this incompetent company, though. --- UPDATE after 100 hours: The game is really good, and lives up to its reputation as one of the better Final Fantasy stories. The MMO portions of it are fine too, and live up to their reputation as one of the better MMOs. This game is worth your money. BUT. Do not buy it through Steam. The entire purpose of purchasing a game like this through Steam is to gain the protection of my locked down Steam account, consolidating my accounts in one area, and lessening mess and clutter. I thought I would be able to use the Steam subscription features like I did with Elder Scrolls Online, which was quite convenient because I don't like handing out my credit card to website. You cannot use the Steam subscription features with this game. You can pay through your Steam wallet, but you still must pay through (and enter all payment details into) the Mog Station website. Paying with the Steam wallet works the same way paying with a credit card does. It does not let you use the subscription feature. Buying this game on Steam only gives you a link to the launcher and a CD key, which you then have to take to their website to create an account with. Steam cannot even keep your game updated, because it only links to the launcher. Worse, once you purchase through Steam and pair it with your account, you are locked to purchasing through Steam. You gain NO BENEFIT for doing this. All it does it lock your options and add a secondary layer of DRM to your gaming experience. This game is worth your money, but they should be forced to provide their own customer service and update their aging systems, not leech off Steam for advertising with no additional benefit to the consumer. --- UPDATE 2022: I have two weeks off for holidays and I finally finished Cyberpunk and wasn’t sure what to waste all my time on, so I thought “Hey maybe I should check out the new FFXIV expansion!” But then, remembering how difficult it was to give this company money, I decided I should secure a subscription before spending money on the expack. The Steam experience of this game continues to impress in all the worst ways. I “installed” the game and, of course, Steam just provides a link to the launcher. So I launch the launcher figuring I can at least get all 80GB of the game installed and such, only to have the launcher tell me I cannot install the game because I do not have a subscription. Awesome. So I wander into the Mog Station and clicked on the pay with Steam option and it prompted me to add money to my Steam wallet. So far so good. I loaded money into the wallet, and I even generously figured why not pay for 6 months, and then I don’t have to deal with this for a while and I will (maybe) feel less pressure to log in and play all the time since I’ve already paid in advance and got a teeny tiny discount. (I know it logically doesn’t make any sense but that’s psychology for you). So I loaded 120 dollars into my steam wallet and headed back to pull the trigger. When I attempted to subscribe I got an error. Fortunately this error happens BEFORE it takes your money or I’d be really pissed, but it also means I’ve loaded a shitload of money into my steam wallet and I can’t actually give it to them now. I tried all sorts of different things, including different browsers, and no dice. I googled the error code and it suggested the problem is that I am Canadian and there’s an issue with the exchange rate. But Steam already handled the exchange rate when I loaded the wallet… ugh. It also wasn’t an error code about insufficient or unrecognized funds or anything like that, it was literally just “There’s a problem. Contact support.” I futzed around for a bit and then finally followed the error code’s advice and opened a support ticket. Or tried to. The link on the error code said “Contact support”, so I clicked on it, but instead of taking me to the contact page it took me to a FAQ. I had to click through a bunch of troubleshooters that had nothing to do with subscriptions before it would believe I actually had a problem that required support to solve, and finally, begrudgingly, took me to a support form. The support form wouldn’t let me submit my question unless I filled out my home address. They did not provide any options for Canada, so I literally couldn’t fill out my address. I picked a random state and hoped it would go through. I also very explicitly stated in my problem description that I am from Canada and the error code might be linked to the exchange rate with Steam. This was on a Friday night, so I had no real expectations of hearing back quickly, and found a different game to play. I heard back from them on Monday morning. Their advice was to run a virus scan and try again. Seriously. WHY is it so difficult to give these people money?? So I guess I won’t be buying Endwalker in the Steam holiday sale…

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: The MMO was okay, I am strictly not recommending that you purchase it through Steam since it complicates a lot of account-related stuff (like if you wanted to play in another platform). I recommend buying it on another platform, like the website directly.

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: The steam version is riddiculous, I just want to play this game on my steam account and I cant even do so, It ask me to create a new account so I do it, then it tells me the new account is linked to my steam, but then it tells me to enter a reg code, I enter my reg code but my reg code is linked to another existing account that I used in 2016, It doesnt allow me to change account since now its linked to my steam, I buy a code from their website, It says the code is only valid for the pc client and not the steam client, their website doesnt sell a steam code, steam says i already own the code, GG

description: Join over 27 million adventurers worldwide and take part in an epic and ever-changing FINAL FANTASY. Experience an unforgettable story, exhilarating battles, and a myriad of captivating environments to explore.
name: FINAL FANTASY XIV Online
review: If you, like I, started playing this game on Windows through the normal installer, it appears that you cannot attach the Steam version to your account, and if you try to log in from your "regular" account, you will be told that you don't have a valid subscription or that your subscription has expired. It seems a while back, Square Enix made the choice to strongly-separate the Steam and Desktop versions, akin to how Desktop and PlayStation versions are separate; except that you cannot have BOTH Steam AND Desktop licenses for whatever arbitrary (I'm assuming "lazy", I think they claim "security" or some nonsense) reason. So while I would normally give this game an enthusiastic thumbs up, since I'm unable to actually play the Steam version I own without setting up a second Square Enix account (I guess I could dualbox?)... I have to give it a thumbs down and hope that this saves someone else from wasting the... whatever $20 or so that I've wasted without researching it thoroughly. In my defense, this really doesn't seem like the kind of thing that one should be expected to research -- it should just work, and the fact that it doesn't makes me disappointed in the FF14 team... who I'm normally not at all disappointed in. For background, I was hoping to play in my Steam Deck without messing around installing Lutris or XIVLauncher; but I guess that's just the world we live in. EDIT: I did reach out to Square Enix, as one comment suggested they could fix this for me. But the final response I got was: "...a Steam version of the base game, as well as any expansion cannot be registered on the same Service Account if a Windows version is already registered on said Service Account. The only way to register the Steam code is by creating a second Service Account." Which means that I COULD set up a second account for my Steam copies -- even using the same login, I think -- but I think I wouldn't be able to play characters from my original account using Steam (and vice versa).

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: The forest was loads of fun. This one however is extremely frustrating. To make a long story short it comes down to balancing issues at the moment. *Having end game armor and getting 1 tapped *Hostiles can block your attacks but you can't block theirs *(More you build more they attack) Builds 1 tent gets 6000 man horde... obviously embellishing but have a base with 500 logs worth of wood vested and roughly get 12-24 rather difficult mobs every 6-12 hours (in game days NOT RL so it's about every what feels like 30 mins but its WAY too often) *Island is massive but every single square inch of this place has mobs. Unlike the first where it felt more balanced and the shock of running across a hunting party was thrilling and scary. This one it becomes absolutely annoying because its shoved down your throat everywhere everytime. *The need for base building in any way shape or form is purely for the sake of doing it. It has no contribution to quality of life what so ever. SURE you can store food/items BUT the amount of mobs/difficulty increase because of those mobs is not balanced. The game is enjoyable early on but as you get more gear you feel weaker and weaker as the horde is blown WAY out of wack against you. idk hopefully they address much of these balancing issues. There are loads of little bugs too but most are manageable just remember to save all the time. I will change this negative review into a positive review when I feel like I have breathing room in the game at day 30. 20 man horde spawns every real life 30 mins to 1 hour is just too often. I hardly have time to gather resources, repair, heal, ACTUALLY WORK ON MY PROJECT before I'm doing it all over again. I play for hours now and hardly get anything done because I'm constantly defending/repairing/healing. Hence the base just not being worth it at all. Defenses ? Yeah right... they will blast through your walls like they don't exist. Half of the mobs just glitch on through. Spikes and traps ? good luck for whatever reason they do like no damage and the aI routing just avoids it.

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: Game looks incredible. In terms of graphics I give it 11/10. Combat is a bit clunky, but I'm a Skyrim kid so I actually kind of enjoy it. Adding a companion that is actually useful is a first in a game like this as far as I am aware, and I think it adds a nice pace. That's about where the fun stops for me. My first night, I built the recommended lean-to with my tarp and a stick. Apparently this game runs on a "more you build the more enemies appear" system. Knowing that, I shudder to think what some of these players who have like 600-700 log bases, because my one little tent caused 7 difficult cannibals to hunt my ass on day one. The building is also really, and I mean REALLY clunky. I'll give it a pass on some of the structure glitches. I played ark for a long time so those don't bother me at all; however, the fact that the enemies can destroy half my log cabin in 2-3 hits is ridiculous. The fact that damaged support beams will render me unable to fix or replace floors, ceilings, etc. without taking apart my entire build is also stupid. Unlike the first game, there are enemies behind literally every tree on the entire map. So many to the point that there isn't even a horror element anymore, the enemies are just annoying. Adding to that, the fact that you still get a ton of damage when you block an enemy's attack but they don't even move when they block is unbalanced and dumb. And not Soulslike unbalanced, I'm talking "the only thing that makes the enemies difficult is the fact that they one tap you while you have to mash them like a boiled potato" unbalanced. I also made the mistake of picking up all the little things I found on the ground on my first save, only to find out there is NO way to quick transfer items to a shelf. I had hundreds of leaves, and I had to transfer them one by one, and sit through the 1-2 second animation for Every. Single. Leaf. And its more than just leaves, there are printer inks, rocks, sticks, berries, etc. all which come in bundles by the dozen that you have to slowly place on the shelf one by one. Biggest complaint by far. As small as it is, it is such a fundamental and frequent part of the game that it is probably going to keep from playing unless the devs add a quick transfer feature. Overall the game is just kinda mid and not worth anywhere near $30 in its current state. I understand it's still in "Early Access" but I'm getting really tired of all these game devs and publishers coming out with early access as an excuse to release an unfinished game just to collect on the cash earlier. Finish making the game and maybe I will change this review to a positive one. You hit it off with the first game, do better with this one. Disclaimer: If you enjoy the game this review is not for you. I do not in any way think that everyone should hate this game, or stop enjoying it because of these things, I'm just saying that I dislike this game in its current state because of them. These are my personal opinions, shared on a public board for like-minded players to think about before dropping $30 on a game.

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: This game does such a great job of making you think that there is much more to it than there is.

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: The thing that I dislike the most about Sons Of The Forest is that you literally get zero peace. The cannibals get so annoying because as soon as you start walking about in the woods they're just constantly making noises and attacking you literally ALL THE TIME. You're never left alone for 5 minutes and it ruins the game's immersion of a "mysterious forest" when your base just gets flooded with mobs for no reason.

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: 10th March 2023: I've not had chance to play this new update, but I will AND I'll update my rating accordingly. Looks nice, played ok, but just like a takeaway it left me unfulfilled. Ultimately it's a disappointing survival experience. Methods for survival are limited - because the sole purpose is to follow the story. Water collector? Gone - got to drink from a stream until you get to a 3D printer (yes, a 3D printer) and even then carry two 3d printed flasks? Nope - apparently that breaks a fundamental law of the universe or something. You can build, yes, but you can't really 'craft' anything. Essential items have to be found through the storyline - for instance, only one shovel has ever been brought on to the island apparently and that selfish bugger who had it took it with him to his demise. How about clawing at the dirt with your bare hands? Nothing that requires a shovel is deeper than 6 inches. Nope. You must get the shovel, lest your podiatrist beats the ever loving crap out of you I guess. Keycards. Think Doom, but over 9 square kilometres. 3 keycards which each open a different area. Again, only one of each on the entire island. Now, that's fine but it's just indicative of the reasoning behind a lot of the 'logic' behind SOTF survival - it is just 'busy' work, for the sake of it ('it' being the e-longlongman-longation of the story). There are buckets, for goodness sake, on the beach when you first spawn in. Can't use them at all, not even to store small rocks or berries (let alone water). Want to store those small stones? Can't drop them - build a set of shelves and carefully store them in neat cairns of 30. I mean, what the hell... If you're coming direct from The Forest you'll probably love it. If you've played anything else in between then you're likely to be very disappointed because like the discoveries that require that shovel, it's all very shallow. They (Endnight) could draw out the survival aspect by allowing a full tier of rudimentary equipment, from diy glue, duct tape, water containers, cooking equipment (to actually cook actual combined meals), stone/scrap metal tools, leather etc that could provide many hours of initial gameplay before you get in to the story - setting up camps at tactical locations around the map as you explore, for example. Not only that, it might also provide some replayability because as it stands, within 10-20 hours the story is over and there's nothing left worth doing and no reason to play again - the story will be the same and so will the limitations. (disclaimer, I have not played multiplayer). My opinion: wait for mod support - if it arrives (modding tools and workshop support) then have at it - the location is superb and empty - ripe for filling. If mods can bring proper survival crafting (gear, food and even more prefabs) then this could be a prime blank canvas. As it stands, unless they're going to revamp the story arc I can't really see what else they're hoping to bring to the table, other than a few fixes, dedicated servers, optimisation, a fricking turtle shell water collector and rafts. Goddamit - will no one think of the rafts?! If you want to sling Endnight 30 bucks and it's nothing to you, then by all means do so. If it's going to be a choice between a week of good meals and plain pasta and ketchup then don't. Hell, if it's a choice of another game or this one, then think carefully. If you're still undecided, stick the $30 in a jar, hide it under your bed and find it around September time.

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: The game in its current state is not worth 30$ I understand its an early release but there is so much missing from this game and way too much left to be desired when comparing it to the first game. My friends and i found every item and beat the story in 10 hours with an extremely relaxed pace. The map is pretty big and ill say it does look great but It seems that once you stumble upon 1 key card you get launched through the story and in a couple hours you're seeing credits. The game ended so fast we were kinda just sitting there on the beach speechless and confused for a while thinking "there's no way that's it". The game teases you in a lot of areas giving you tons of food/meds and explosives making you think 'oh man something big is coming' but no. no boss fights.. no special enemies.. just loot. Its funny but I had just started to use guns the last hour of game play because i was holding onto the stronger weapons for something meaningful to use them on. The game ended so fast that the base we built at the start of the game was never even used. It honestly felt like a free demo. tldr: As wide as an ocean but as deep as a puddle.

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: I wanna start by saying that i have looked forward a long time to this game, since i absolutely LOVED the first game. But i dont recommend buying it in early acces and to wait for the game to be done. I will write my review, stretched out in positive and negative points to make the overall view more clear. POSITIVES : - The surroundings and audio is abolutely gorgeous. - The basebuilding is super smooth, fun to do and MUCH easier then forest 1. Also more building options. - Interaction with the cannibals, observing their 'behaviour' is really well done. - The inventory looks really cool and is well made. Easy and smooth to use. NEGATIVES : - There is not really a true ' adventure' feeling as you literally get guided to all the points u need to be by a GPS tracker. In Forest 1 u had to actually go find all the caves yourself and it felt more rewarding. - A LOT of big areas where u find literally 'nothing'. Just feels like a big map with no real purpose. If there isnt a GPS tracker, most u find will be some loot containers. - Documents u find can not be viewed again( exept for books). I´d like a journal for those, like Forest 1. - The story ending feels extremely rushed. ( U put in lots of gaming hours, to just see a short cinematic at the end, thats it). - No boss fights. ( not even one ? Come on.) - A lot of unnessasairy equipment, stuff u will never use. - Too much recourses to find like food/meds/drinks. This doesnt feel like a survival anymore. - The cavesystems that u find are overall kinda boring compaired with Forest 1. - Not enough cavesystems. ( In Forest 1 the underground is almost just as big as above. Not in this sequel). - I was waiting for a " WOW moment". A jaw dropping moment. Like when u find that massive sinkhole in Forest 1. There is literally nothing like that here. Was constantly waiting for that feeling like ' OMG WTF' ?? but it never came and i feel dissapointed. - Things got added to the story that have absolutely no place there. Its about an interdimensional shift the whole story,but in the end u get 'demons' from hell that u cast away with a cross" ??? It just doesnt fit there and it feels really confusing. Its feels like they wanted to almost force a religous component to the story, tho it has nothing to do with that. - At the end, i got really confused. Like i said before, it was really rushed. So much that i had to google if that was the end or not. - The developers blame the rushed ending to the early acces. But in my personal opinion, in early acces u can expect bugs, maybe bad visuals, not enough audio.... stuff like that. But i dont feel it should be an excuse for a bad ending. They said that they will add things to the ending and try to make it more better over time. I hope its true, but i wont be playing this a second time. They gave the game an overall bad feeling at the end and they should have put more effort into the end stage. Not only a first impression makes your game good, but also the feeling wich u end it with. I feel dissapointed and left hungry for so much more. - I hope the review helped to get a perspective on it ! ( And sorry for the spelling mistakes xDD, hope it was still clear).

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: The game is fun, don't get me wrong! Surviving in the unknown, full of cannibals gathering loot, constructing a base, and attempting to figure out what the hell is going on in this place, hooked me! The visuals and physics are also very good! But I don't recommend this game in its current state. There are a lot of bugs and stability issues (which is to be expected for early access), but what killed it for me was going caving and discovering that most of the caves were small and had no good loot. I'd basically walk across the map, not finding anything in most of the caves. That was a huge letdown and a waste of my time. Then the ending happened to me very randomly and quickly. It didn't make any sense. I got no answers as to what was going on in this place. It was extremely anticlimactic and made no sense. I was shocked that it was the end because it felt like I didn't really do anything. After that, it seemed very pointless to play, and the game got super boring. The game has a good foundation and has a lot of potential, and I hope it gets better. As of now, the story and lack of things to do make it very boring.

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: It's releases like this that make me wish there was a "50/50" option, and I'll preface my review saying that my rating is based on the Early Access, first version of the game—so things may change. I loved The Forest, having spent hours with friends creating a bunch of memorable experiences, and it still holds my interest all these years later. In a vacuum, Sons of the Forest is a decent survival game with an absolutely beautiful environment and a satisfying construction and crafting system. Enemies are detailed with complex and interesting behavior patterns. In comparison to the original game, however, Sons of the Forest is a poor follow-up that left me severely disappointed. There are many positives in the game (which I know other reviews will touch upon), but I'll list some of the many issues that come to mind below: - Unlike the original game (which required you to find and explore points of interest all on your own), Sons of the Forest provides you with a GPS from the very beginning, with several markers to explore. This absolutely kills the sense of adventure that the first game had, and players end up just going to and from one of the ~8 points on the map since there's no reason to look elsewhere. - While the map itself is much bigger than the original, the few points of interest mean that the forest feels extremely sparse and feels like a slog when going from one point to another. - The caves in this game are so much less interesting to explore. Where The Forest had a complex, interconnected network of tunnels that went throughout the island (creating many "wow, look where we ended up" moments), Sons of the Forest opted to have much fewer and very linear caves that simply had one defined entrance and exit every time (with one-way mechanics), ensuring you'd never be interested in returning after doing a fine-enough sweep through it the first time. - The caves not related to your marked objectives are little more than caverns for you to pop into for 1 minute, collect cloth, and leave. I genuinely wonder why they were even put in the game without offering much of anything that contributes to the experience. - Building materials are abundant and weapons easily available. Halfway through, you'll have way more than you'll ever need. - Where The Forest had many animals, each with their own kinds of hide for specific items (Spear bag, Rock bag, etc), Sons of the Forest barely has half of those as its predecessor, only has one kind of hide, and only allows you to make hide armor out of it. Wildlife is no danger at all, and hunting animals is not necessary (not even for meat). - Enemy variety is severely lacking. As interesting as the cannibals are in this game, the non-cannibal enemies were more of a threat in the first game should they find you, and made building a shelter essential. The vast vast majority of non-cannibal enemies are only one of two, which aren't too hard to dispatch. The deadlier, more interesting ones were so rare that I only encountered them a couple of instances over the course of the whole game (on normal difficulty, I cannot speak for the other modes). - Because of the above issue, and the ability to set up and break down camps anywhere with the tarp, building a shelter feels completely unnecessary, especially when you know where all of your objectives are ahead of time. - The story and ending were extremely underwhelming. Watching the trailer for this game would have had you think it would be more or less a direct sequel to the first, but left me feeling mislead. This game gives you very little context throughout, with only a handful of scenes contributing to the story (which on its own is fine, but by the end makes you feel like there could have been much more). While the original had a much better exploratory nature, providing you with numerous ominous photos and artifacts, this game provides extremely little in comparison. If you're like me, you'll get to the end, full of supplies expecting a challenge, only to be met by the last cut scene thinking "is that it?". The Forest's ending was way better! I could keep going, but I think I highlighted the most important issues I currently have. I know the game is a work in progress, and is why I didn't mention the many bugs I encountered (geometry issues when building structures, meat being reset to raw, etc). I expect these will be fixed in future updates. However, a lot of the problems I have were design decisions that I don't anticipate will be altered. The game itself is a fun enough, fantastic looking survival game (seriously, it's one of the best forests I've seen in a video game), but it just doesn't measure up to the value I got out of The Forest. Since finishing the story, I don't feel compelled at all to keep playing. I wouldn't have bought it full price, Early Access had I known what I know now, and if not for all of the positive review-bombing this game got on release. I don't understand why the developers made some of the decisions they did. With all this in mind, I really can't recommend the game in its current state if you were a fan of the original. See what they do with the next few updates or just wait for a sale.

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: The same game as The Forest, but even more walking with only 3 caves being decent, the rest are just crates filled with cloth and canned food (all of the ones in the snow biome). Less content than the original game, and all the blueprints are copy-pasted from the first game. Don't even need to build a shelter, it's just a waste of time because there is no survival aspect as mobs only actually spawn on like day 15, you'd complete the game by then. Heavily underwhelming combat, exactly the same from the first game. The new mobs contribute absolutely nothing as they all have boring attacks but look different. The core game is the same, similar 'find items in caves' as the first one. If you've played the original, don't buy this, if you've never played The Forest, then yeah it's not bad. 90% of all sounds are used from the previous game, which doesn't seem like a big deal, but when you actually play it, it's highly irritating and also the mobs have no footsteps and so you don't hear them coming until they've actually hit you. All it is, is the original 'The Forest' but with improved graphics and less content. The appealing 'seasonal' cycle in the game isn't dynamic, when you sleep on day 10, you wake up and it's suddenly winter for 5 days, which isn't even difficult because there's about 100 cans of cat food and 100 MREs which respawn in the numerous boring caves and camps that exist in the game. The inventory system added really cool lights! This is to hide the fact that it's actually worse to use as you have to rotate your camera to find the item you want and if you have too many items then it just reduces your FPS dramatically. The inventory system is WORSE, but they did improve the crafting animations when making or combining items. When you've finally got the sled to enjoy some mountain sledging, it's actually comical because you're going faster than the speed of sound so you actually have no clue about what's going on until you've hit a tree. I can't emphasise enough that the appealing '4x map size' makes the game worse, it's 4x the size with 4x less content, so you're walking through the forest with absolutely nothing there, the only part which is populated is the first quarter island you spawn at, the rest is just emptiness. Also Unity in 2023? Come on now, you're taking the mick, it's terribly unoptimised and the general gameplay is just poor. Unsure how it's got 'very positive' reviews, when it's literally the same as the first game, but worse. Edit: Finished the game, the story is comically bad, don't waste your time. People are also complaining how I didn't mention the 'improvements', the crafting animations, the core building mechanics is more more intuitive (but once again, base raiding happens pretty much late game when you've got everything and the ONLY resource is logs). Kelvin is cool, but is so buggy he almost becomes useless, the amount of times I've told him to go and collect sticks to then walk straight into a cannibal like a buffoon or runs off into the sunset collecting that one stick he found 200 metres away. Honestly there's literally to no improvement from the first game and is in most aspects a step back, mainly because it's copy-paste with some more eye candy fauna/flora. kind regards, trot888

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: Another situation where I wish Steam had a middling review option. I do like this game and I do recommend it to fans of The Forest. Just not at its current price point compared to the available content. For years, The Forest has been the game I use as an example of Early Access done right. The latest patch release of Sons Of The Forest inspired me to throw my opinion out there. I was a huge fan of The Forest and have walked many friends through the story and caves. Sons Of The Forest has a lot of improvements over the first while also taking a few steps back in some areas. It feels pointless to list all these issues because just like the first game, its Early Access. They are all subject to change and will most likely be fixed up quite a bit a year from now. As it stands, there is currently no reason at all to build a base aside from testing the games functions and your own creativity. However, my biggest problem is this extremely strange approach to Early Access they've taken this time around as opposed to the first game. The first game released onto Early Access with one cut scene, a handful of items and craftables and grew from there to encompass a feature complete game with a solid story for those who were interested in finding it. The story elements here in the sequel are as deep and interesting as the first game. The issue stems from the fact the story and its elements are fully completable from the outset, bugs and all. In my experience this has put quite a damper on my excitement going forward because I already know exactly what is going to happen for the most part. I'm sure they will add in little twists and turns here and there as the details to the story are further developed but it can't change the two available endings. Both of which are currently nowhere near as peak as the first games available endings in my opinion. The cut scenes as they exist now, aside from the opening cutscene, are extremely jarring. Sound and dialogue seem to be missing and the animations are very stilted and awkward. This is just a symptom of a bigger problem. The problem being that this game should have just released when it was ready. I don't believe there was any reason for this game to launch in EA aside from laziness and it sort of shows in the game and patch releases. If you play and complete the game, it becomes glaringly obvious that the developers are well aware of the game they are making and where it is headed, but for some reason they insist on dragging out its development time. The latest patch which came out just prior to writing this adds a few new items, a couple cave extensions and some new craftables. Having completed the game already, knowing that I do not need these new items or mechanics to complete any gameplay or story elements is a huge disappointment and is not bringing me back to play more. At this point only the full release will bring me back for another playthough and thats sad. The Forest was EA done right. Almost every patch had me coming back to find new items and experiment crafting as the story progressed, patch after patch. A perfect example of how this was done properly in the first game was the patch that added the climbing axe. Before the patch, the player could find walls in caves that were clearly there to be scaled with some sort of tool. These caves had items the player either wanted or needed to complete the story in both the sense of item progression or plot progression. Sons Of The Forest has none of this. The only item you NEED to complete the game is a cosmetic item that currently holds little to no plot value. For fans of The Forest, I recommend you hold off until the game is more feature complete so you don't burn out your curiosity like I did. For the curious and uninitiated I give the same advice. Pickup the original The Forest in the meantime. Sons Of The Forest needs more time baking in the oven before its ready. 6/10

description: Sent to find a missing billionaire on a remote island, you find yourself in a cannibal-infested hellscape. Craft, build, and struggle to survive, alone or with friends, in this terrifying new open-world survival horror simulator.
name: Sons Of The Forest
review: TL;DR Game rests very much as a 5.8/10 for me in it's early access state. I honestly have no clue why this game has 81% positive reviews, even if it's in EA. That said, obviously the game is subject to potentially change heavily during it's 6-8+ months of continued development time. Though, if this is what we get after 5 years, I'm not very optimistic. Good Stuff - The world is very pretty even running on medium settings. This is one of the best looking forest environments in any game to date. - The building (while janky in some areas) is very awesome, probably my favorite part of the game (but see additional notes on building below). - The cannibals have some really interesting behaviors. You will see them climb trees, mourn their dead, capture other cannibals, react to having a weapon pointed at them, stalk you, etc. Some of the coolest parts of this game are the interactions with them (especially early on). - Some (not all) of the weapons are very satisfying to use! - Caving is enjoyable about 60% of the time. - Custom difficulty options are largely solid (though a few additions are needed.) - The changing seasons keep things visually interesting. - The AI assistant the game gives you is pretty awesome. Really didn't use him all that much, but very cool nonetheless. I hope this becomes a standard for future games of this genre. That pretty much covers everything I liked about the game unfortunately. Bad Stuff - The world is basically empty. I have absolutely no idea why developers continue to build these large maps that have nothing in them. While yes, there are interesting landmarks (i.e camps, caves, secret/story areas, etc) these are unfortunately few and far between. At 15 hours, I've seen the entirety of what the game offers in this regard and it's pretty lackluster. - The price. Why this game is sitting at $30.00 USD is beyond me. Unless you plan on continually building an ever expanding settlement, there is at best 16 hours of content here (if you go pretty slowly through the majority of the game as I did). This game really should be priced at the $20.00 mark in it's current state as it just doesn't hold up to other equally priced titles in my opinion. There just isn't enough content here to justify the price imho. - The game gives you WAY too many consumables WAY too fast. At first, I thought this was simply due to playing the game in normal mode. However, this appears to also be the case in the hard mode as well (maybe to a slightly lesser extent, but still). Thankfully, this is easily fixable. Mind you, I'm not saying I want to have to eat/drink 24-7, but it got to a point where I was leaving the majority of loot behind as I had so much in my play-through. Towards the end of the game, my character pretty much ran exclusively on energy drinks/bars and didn't sleep for multiple in-game days. This pretty much makes hunting/scavenging largely pointless. I'd very much like the developers to add a way of adjusting this via the custom difficulty settings. - The story was a major let down for me. The whole plot surrounding the artifact/cube was overly confusing. Following the end of my play-through I had to watch a few analysis videos to figure out what that ending even was. Speaking of the ending, this game ends super abruptly, feels rushed. I have no clue why the devs decided to give you perm gold armor right before the ending, but it really made the whole thing a massive cake walk. Additionally, the whole key-card system for accessing different areas kinda falls apart when they put all of the story areas RIGHT next to each other. My friend and I were able to complete the story in about 6 hours starting from zero progress once we got done building our base. The ending really doesn't give a satisfying answer to any of the questions asked (and yes...I read ALL of the emails throughout the game). The vast majority of our time spent in this game was building...which is unfortunate because.... - The building in this game (while very fun) is totally pointless. When my friend I first started, we took our time constructing an awesome fort with spiked walls, a cabin, fish traps, fires, skulls on sticks, and additional fortifications. This is where the first 5-7 hours of playtime went. However, once you begin traversing the world you realize having a base is totally pointless! You can literally just put a tarp in the woods to sleep (with no fortifications of any kind needed) and sleep through the night without any real risk. As far as food goes, as mentioned earlier, the game gives you so many consumables you don't even really need to setup any sort of fish traps or have a base to hunt from. Again, this is pretty fixable, and I'm hoping this will be fixed with continued development time. - The inventory system is absolutely terrible and annoying to use.
